choices.text: Increase of lipid synthesis by adipose tissue
Down regulation of low-density lipoprotein (LDL) receptors in the liver
Inhibition HMG-CoA reductase activity in the liver

questions.text: A 24 year old woman suffering from familial hypertriglyceridemia was screened with a blood lipid profile during a routine visit. Relevant laboratory test results were total cholesterol 170 mg/dL, triglycerides 1230 mg/dL. A suitable lipid-lowering drug was prescribed by her physician. Which of the following is the most likely the mechanism of action of that prescribed drug in the reduction of triglycerides?
questions.solution:
• The prescribed drug was most likely a fibrate.
  • The fibrates primarily activate lipoprotein lipase which is a key enzyme in the degradation of VLDL resulting in lowering of circulating triglycerides.
  • This effect is exerted through nuclear peroxisome proliferator-activated
    receptor α (PPARα) that is a gene transcription regulating receptor expressed in liver, fat and muscles.

Activation of PPARα

  • Enhances lipoprotein lipase synthesis and fatty acid oxidation.
  • Mediate enhanced LDL receptor expression in liver
  • Fibrates decrease hepatic TG synthesis as well.

Drugs in this class primarily

  • Lower TG levels by 20-50%,
  • 10-15% decrease in LDL-CH
  • 10-15% increase in HDL-CH.

Summary of Anti-Dyslipidemic drugs

Key takeaway

The fibrates primarily activate lipoprotein lipase which is a key enzyme in the degradation of VLDL resulting in lowering of circulating triglycerides.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi 8th edition, page no. 685

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with a sensation of dryness and grittiness in both eyes, which worsens throughout the day. She reports a history of rheumatoid arthritis and uses a computer for extended periods. On examination, the tear break-up time is decreased, and there is conjunctival hyperemia. What is the most appropriate initial management for this condition?
questions.solution:
• Artificial Tears: The initial and most appropriate management for dry eye disease is to use lubricating eye drops. These help to alleviate symptoms by supplementing the tear film and providing relief from dryness and grittiness.

Additional Points:

  • Assessment Tools: Schirmer's Test and TBUT are useful in diagnosing the severity of dry eyes.
  • Lifestyle Modifications: Can significantly impact symptom management and overall ocular health.

Dry Eye Disease (DED),

keratoconjunctivitis sicca, is a condition where the eyes do not produce enough tears or the tears evaporate too quickly, leading to inflammation and damage to the ocular surface.

Etiology and Risk Factors:

  • Inadequate Tear Production: Associated with conditions such as Sjögren's syndrome, aging, or certain medications.
  • Increased Tear Evaporation: Often due to environmental factors, such as dry climates or excessive screen time, and eyelid disorders like meibomian gland dysfunction.
  • Hormonal Changes: Menopause, pregnancy, or hormonal therapies.
  • Autoimmune Disorders: Sjögren's syndrome and rheumatoid arthritis.
  • Systemic Diseases: Diabetes and thyroid disorders.

Clinical Features:

  • Symptoms:
    • Dryness: Sensation of dryness or grittiness in the eyes.
    • Redness: Hyperemia of the conjunctiva.
    • Burning: Burning or stinging sensation.
    • Foreign Body Sensation: Feeling as if something is in the eye.
    • Visual Disturbances: Blurred vision, particularly with prolonged reading or computer use.
  • Signs:
    • Tear Film Instability: Observed during slit-lamp examination.
    • Conjunctival Hyperemia: Redness of the conjunctiva.
    • Corneal Staining: Using fluorescein dye to highlight areas of dryness or damage.
    • Meibomian Gland Dysfunction: Gland expression and examination may show blocked glands.

Diagnosis:

  • Patient History: Assessment of symptoms and contributing factors.
  • Ocular Surface Evaluation:
    • Schirmer's Test: Measures tear production.
    • Tear Break-Up Time (TBUT): Assesses the stability of the tear film.
    • Fluorescein Staining: Identifies areas of corneal damage or dryness.
  • Meibography: Imaging of meibomian glands to evaluate gland function.

Management:

  • Artificial Tears: Over-the-counter lubricating eye drops to alleviate dryness.
  • Prescription Medications:
    • Anti-Inflammatory Drops: g., cyclosporine A (Restasis) or lifitegrast (Xiidra).
    • Steroid Drops: For short-term use in severe cases to reduce inflammation.
  • Lifestyle Modifications:
    • Environmental Adjustments: Use of humidifiers and avoidance of direct airflow from fans or air conditioning.
    • Screen Time Management: Regular breaks and use of computer eyewear.
  • Surgical Interventions:
    • Punctal Plugs: To reduce tear drainage and increase tear film retention.
    • Scleral Lenses: Large-diameter lenses that trap moisture over the corneal surface.
  • Meibomian Gland Dysfunction Treatments: Warm compresses, eyelid hygiene, and massage.

Other options

  • Oral Corticosteroids: While effective for reducing inflammation, they are not typically the first line of treatment for dry eyes due to potential systemic side effects.
  • Topical Antihistamines: Used primarily for allergic conjunctivitis, they do not address the underlying issues in dry eye disease.
  • Systemic Immunotherapy: Not commonly used for dry eyes unless there is an underlying systemic autoimmune condition that is unresponsive to other treatments.

References: Kanski's Clinical Ophthalmology: A Systematic Approach, 9th Edition, pg: 720-735.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male with a 15-year history of poorly controlled diabetes presents for a routine eye examination. Fundus examination reveals microaneurysms, intraretinal hemorrhages, and hard exudates, but no neovascularization is observed. Fluorescein angiography shows areas of capillary non-perfusion. Based on the findings, what is the most appropriate classification of this patient's retinopathy?
questions.solution:
• Mild NPDR: Characterized by the presence of microaneurysms only.
  • Moderate NPDR: Includes more extensive findings, such as microaneurysms, intraretinal hemorrhages, and hard exudates, but without the 4-2-1 rule features for severe NPDR.
  • Severe NPDR: Follows the 4-2-1 rule, which means having one of the following:
    • More than 20 intraretinal hemorrhages in each of the four quadrants.
    • Venous beading in two or more quadrants.
    • Intraretinal microvascular abnormalities (IRMA) in at least one quadrant. Since the patient shows capillary non-perfusion, which is associated with more severe stages of NPDR, this suggests the diagnosis of severe NPDR.
  • Proliferative Diabetic Retinopathy (PDR): Involves neovascularization, which is not present in this case.

NPDR(non proliferative diabetic retinopathy)

Pathophysiology:

  • NPDR results from damage to the small blood vessels in the retina due to chronic hyperglycemia, which leads to a breakdown of the blood-retinal barrier.
  • Key Features:
    • Microaneurysms: Outpouching of capillary walls.
    • Intraretinal hemorrhages: Leakage from damaged retinal vessels.
    • Hard Exudates: Lipid and protein deposits in the retina.
    • Cotton Wool Spots: Represent retinal nerve fiber layer infarcts.
    • Venous Beading: Abnormal dilation and beading of retinal veins, a sign of worsening ischemia.
    • Intraretinal Microvascular Abnormalities (IRMA): Shunt vessels that form due to capillary closure.

Classification of NPDR (ETDRS Classification):

  1. Mild NPDR:
    • Microaneurysms only.
  2. Moderate NPDR:
    • More severe retinal changes, such as hemorrhages and exudates, without meeting the criteria for severe NPDR.
  3. Severe NPDR(4-2-1 Rule):
    • Hemorrhages in all four quadrants.
    • Venous beading in two or more quadrants.
    • IRMA in one or more quadrants.

Investigations:

  • Fundus Photography: To document retinal findings.
  • Fluorescein Angiography: To assess capillary non-perfusion and leakage.
  • Optical Coherence Tomography (OCT): To check for macular edema.

Management:

  • Glycemic Control: Strict blood sugar control to slow progression.
  • Ophthalmic Monitoring: Regular fundus examinations to monitor disease progression.
  • Laser Photocoagulation: In case of macular edema or risk of progression to PDR.
  • Intravitreal Injections: Anti-VEGF agents (e.g., ranibizumab) for diabetic macular edema.

Reference: Kanski's Clinical Ophthalmology: A Systematic Approach, 9th Edition: Pages: 537-539.

questions.text: A 46-year-old anxious man was brought to physician with complaints of insomnia, nightmares, fatigue, diminished libido, and blanching of the fingers when exposed to cold. The man, recently diagnosed with exertional angina, had been taking an anti-anginal drug for 1 month. Which of the following drug most likely caused the patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
• All β blockers benefit angina of effort.
  • Taken on a regular schedule they Decrease frequency of attacks and increase exercise tolerance.
  • High doses, however, may worsen angina in some patients by increasing ventricular size and reducing coronary flow.
  • Beta blockers are not suitable for variant (vasospastic) angina
  • Adverse effects of beta blockers

Mnemonic [BALD FISH]

  • Bronchoconstriction
  • Bradycardia
  • Arrhythmia
  • Lethargy
  • Disturbed glucose metabolism
  • Fatigue
  • Insomnia
  • Sexual dysfunction
  • Hypotension

Option B, C & D: All of the above drugs are suitably used in acute as well as other forms of angina.

Key Takeaway

Propranolol is a non-selective b-blocker. It can cause vasoconstriction by antagonizing b2 mediated vasodilatation and by unopposed α actions. So it is not a suitable choice for any kind of angina. Selective b-blocker can be tried in some forms of angina.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi 8th edition, page no. 161

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy presents with severe itching, redness, and a mucopurulent discharge from his eyes, particularly worsening during the spring. On examination, he has large cobblestone-like papillae on the upper tarsal conjunctiva and Horner-Trantas dots on the limbus. What is the most appropriate initial treatment for this condition?
questions.solution:
• Topical Antihistamines: This is the most appropriate initial treatment for VKC as it helps alleviate itching and redness associated with allergic reactions. Antihistamines like olopatadine or ketotifen are commonly used to control symptoms.

Additional Points:

  • Papillae and Horner-Trantas dots are classic signs of VKC, distinguishing it from other forms of conjunctivitis.
  • Management should focus on both symptomatic relief and allergen avoidance to effectively control the condition.
  • Vernal Keratoconjunctivitis (VKC) is a chronic, allergic eye disease characterized by inflammation of the conjunctiva and cornea, typically occurring in the spring or early summer.

Signs for Limbal Type


  • Horner Trantas spots: degenerated epithelial cells and eosinophils.
  • Pseudogerontoxon

Signs for palpebral type


  • Giant papillae

Complications


  • Shield ulcer
  • Limbal stem cells deficiency--> Corneal neovascularization
  • Developing Keratoconus

Etiology and Risk Factors:

  • Allergic Reaction: VKC is an allergic condition triggered by environmental allergens. The exact allergens can vary but include pollen, dust mites, and animal dander.
  • Age: Commonly affects children and young adults, particularly those with a history of atopy.
  • Climate: More prevalent in warm, dry climates.

Clinical Features:

  • Symptoms:
    • Itching: Severe itching is a hallmark symptom.
    • Redness: Conjunctival hyperemia and redness.
    • Discharge: Mucoid or mucopurulent discharge.
    • Photophobia: Sensitivity to light.
  • Signs:
    • Conjunctival Papillae: Large, cobblestone-like papillae, especially on the upper tarsal conjunctiva.
    • Corneal Changes: Horner-Trantas dots (whitish-gray, elevated lesions on the limbus) and potential corneal epithelial damage.
    • Eyelid Swelling: Swelling and thickening of the eyelids.

Diagnosis:

  • Allergy Testing:
    • Skin Prick Tests: To identify specific allergens.
    • Serum IgE Levels: Elevated in many cases of VKC.

Management:

  • Avoidance of Allergens:
    • Environmental Control: Minimizing exposure to known allergens, such as pollen.
  • Pharmacologic Treatment:
    • Topical Antihistamines: E.g., olopatadine or ketotifen.
    • Topical Mast Cell Stabilizers: E.g., cromolyn sodium.
    • Topical Corticosteroids: For severe inflammation, but used cautiously due to potential side effects.
    • Non-Steroidal Anti-Inflammatory Drugs (NSAIDs): E.g., ketorolac.
  • Surgical Intervention:
    • For Complications: Surgery may be required for significant corneal damage or to manage complications like severe scarring.

Other options

  • Oral Corticosteroids: While effective, they are generally reserved for severe cases due to potential systemic side effects and are not typically used as first-line therapy.
  • Systemic Immunotherapy: Not usually the first approach for VKC. It is used in severe or refractory cases.
  • Topical Antibiotics: Not appropriate as the condition is allergic rather than bacterial, and antibiotics will not address the underlying allergic inflammation.

References: Kanski's Clinical Ophthalmology: A Systematic Approach, 9th Edition, pp: 556-560.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male with a 15-year history of uncontrolled diabetes presents with gradually worsening vision in both eyes. On fundus examination, there is significant retinal thickening with hard exudates seen near the fovea. Optical coherence tomography (OCT) shows retinal thickening within 400 microns of the foveal center. Which of the following best describes the current condition?
questions.solution:
• Clinically significant macular edema (CSME) is defined by the ETDRS criteria. The case mentions retinal thickening within 400 microns of the fovea, which meets one of the diagnostic criteria for CSME.
  • Diffuse diabetic macular edema (A) refers to widespread thickening of the macula without necessarily involving the center of the fovea. However, the involvement of the fovea in this case makes CSME the more appropriate diagnosis.
  • Non-proliferative diabetic retinopathy (C) refers to the early stages of diabetic retinopathy, which may accompany DME but is not the primary condition described in this case.
  • Proliferative diabetic retinopathy (D) is characterized by neovascularization, which was not mentioned in the clinical findings.

Clinically Significant Macular Edema (CSME):

  • Defined by ETDRS as:
    1. Retinal thickening at or within 500 microns of the foveal center.
    2. Hard exudates at or within 500 microns of the foveal center with adjacent thickening.
    3. Retinal thickening of at least 1 disc diameter within 1 disc diameter of the fovea.
  • Treatment: Anti-VEGF agents (e.g., Ranibizumab) are the first-line treatment for center-involving CSME. Focal/grid laser is also an option, particularly in non-center involving CSME.

Diabetic Macular Edema (DME)

is a complication of diabetic retinopathy (DR) and refers to swelling of the macula caused by fluid accumulation due to leakage from retinal blood vessels. It is the most common cause of vision loss in patients with diabetic retinopathy.

Pathophysiology:

  1. Breakdown of the blood-retinal barrier:
    • Chronic hyperglycemia leads to capillary damage, endothelial dysfunction, and pericyte loss.
    • This results in increased vascular permeability, causing leakage of fluid and lipoprotein exudates into the macular region.
  2. Role of VEGF:
    • Vascular Endothelial Growth Factor (VEGF) is a key factor driving vascular leakage and neovascularization.
    • High levels of VEGF are associated with increased macular edema.

Risk Factors:

  • Poorly controlled diabetes: Long duration of diabetes and high HbA1c levels.
  • Hypertension and hyperlipidemia: Contributing to retinal vessel damage.
  • Pre-existing diabetic retinopathy: The more advanced the retinopathy, the higher the likelihood of DME.
  • Renal disease: Increases risk of macular edema due to fluid imbalance.

Clinical Features:

  • Symptoms:
    • Painless, progressive blurring of central vision.
    • Visual distortion and difficulty reading.
    • Often bilateral but may be asymmetric.
  • Signs on Fundus Examination:
    • Retinal thickening and hard exudates in the macula.
    • Microaneurysms and hemorrhages in surrounding areas.
    • Cystoid spaces or subretinal fluid may be seen on OCT (Optical Coherence Tomography).

Investigations:

  1. Optical Coherence Tomography (OCT):
    • Provides cross-sectional imaging of the retina, showing retinal thickening, cystoid spaces, and fluid accumulation.
    • Helps in monitoring response to treatment.
  2. Fluorescein Angiography:
    • Used to evaluate the leakage from retinal vessels and the extent of macular ischemia.

Treatment Options:

  1. Anti-VEGF Therapy:
    • First-line treatment, especially for center-involving DME.
    • Agents such as Ranibizumab, Bevacizumab, and Aflibercept block VEGF and reduce fluid accumulation.
  2. Intravitreal Corticosteroids:
    • Used in patients unresponsive to anti-VEGF or in cases of inflammation.
    • Dexamethasone implant (Ozurdex) or triamcinolone can reduce macular swelling.
  3. Focal/Grid Laser Photocoagulation:
    • Used mainly for non-center-involving DME.
    • Aims to seal leaky microaneurysms and prevent further fluid leakage.
  4. Combination Therapy:
    • Anti-VEGF combined with focal/grid laser therapy is often more effective in reducing macular edema.

Prognosis:

  • Early treatment significantly improves visual outcomes.
  • Regular follow-ups and tight control of blood sugar, blood pressure, and lipid levels are critical to prevent recurrence or progression.

Differential Diagnosis:

  • Retinal vein occlusion (can also cause macular edema).
  • Age-related macular degeneration (AMD).
  • Uveitis-associated cystoid macular edema.

Reference: Kanski's Clinical Ophthalmology, 9th Edition, Pages: 545-548.

questions.text: An 18 year old male patient was brought into the emergency department with a seizure that lasted 30 minutes without resolution. After securing airways & administering oxygen, which of the following pharmacologic agents is most appropriate to arrest the seizure?
questions.solution:
A short-acting benzodiazepine such as lorazepam is usually the best choice in the acute setting to arrest status epilepticus.

BZD In Status Epilepticus :

  • Lorazepam
  • Diazepam
  • Midazolam

Option A: Lignocaine is the most commonly used local anaesthetic agent. It is the drug of choice for the treatment of ventricular arrhythmias due to digitalis toxicity (ineffective in atrial arrhythmias) and ventricular arrhythmias after myocardial infarction.

Option C: Chlordiazepoxide is often combined with other drugs in psychosomatic disorders, and has been the commonest BZD used to cover alcohol withdrawal.

Option D: Triazolam A very potent short acting BZD who's peak effect occurs in < 1 hour; good for sleep induction.

Key Takeaway :

A short-acting benzodiazepine such as lorazepam is usually the best choice in the acute setting to arrest status epilepticus.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi 8th edition, page no. 428,445

choices.text: Immediate fitting of contact lenses or glasses to correct the refractive error
Strict adherence to amblyopia treatment protocols, including patching of the non-affected eye
Regular monitoring for secondary cataract development and timely YAG laser capsulotomy if necessary
Early initiation of strabismus surgery to prevent ocular misalignment

questions.text: A 6-month-old infant is diagnosed with a unilateral congenital cataract. You plan to perform cataract surgery. Which of the following is the most critical postoperative intervention to ensure optimal visual development?
questions.solution:
Pediatric cataract

Diagnosis

Clinical Presentation:

  • Infant Cataracts: Often detected by parental observation of a white reflex (leukocoria) or during routine newborn screening.
  • Older Children: May present with decreased vision, strabismus, or amblyopia.

Diagnostic Tests:

  • Slit Lamp Examination:To assess the cataract's location and density.
  • Retinal Examination:To check for associated abnormalities.
  • Ultrasonography: Useful for detailed assessment of the cataract and associated conditions, particularly if the view is obscured.
  • specific tests in case of bilateral cataracts: For bilateral cataracts without a family history, the recommended workup includes a urine test for reducing sugars, TORCH(toxoplasmosis, rubella, cytomegalovirus, varicella) screening, a Venereal Disease Research Laboratory (VDRL) test for syphilis, and a blood test for calcium, phosphorus, glucose, and galactokinase Dysmorphic features may suggest the need for involvement of a geneticis

1.Surgical Intervention:

Timing:

  • Infant Cataracts: Early intervention is crucial to prevent amblyopia and promote normal visual development. Surgery is typically performed within the first few months of life.
  • Technique:
    • Phacoemulsification: The preferred method for children over 2 years of age.
    • usually Lens aspiration is enough as the cataract is soft
    • they will need a posterior capsulorhexis

Postoperative Care:

  • Visual Rehabilitation:
    • Amblyopia Treatment: Includes patching of the non-affected eye to stimulate the amblyopic eye, along with corrective lenses.
    • Glasses or Contact Lenses: Typically required to correct refractive errors post-surgery.
  • Follow-up:
    • Regular Check-ups: To monitor for complications such as glaucoma, secondary cataract (posterior capsule opacification), and ensure proper visual development.
    • Additional Surgeries: May be required for secondary cataract or other complications.

Complications:

  • Postoperative Glaucoma: Regular monitoring is essential.
  • Posterior Capsule Opacification: Can be treated with a YAG laser capsulotomy.
  • Strabismus: May require additional management if present.

Management Protocols

Classification of Cataract:

  • Congenital vs. Acquired: Understanding the etiology helps in planning the treatment.
  • Monocular vs. Binocular: Bilateral cataracts require a more comprehensive management approach.

Other options:

A) Immediate fitting of contact lenses or glasses: While essential, it is not as critical as treating amblyopia to ensure proper visual development.

B) Strict adherence to amblyopia treatment protocols: Amblyopia treatment is crucial to stimulate the affected eye and ensure the child achieves optimal visual outcomes. This should be initiated as soon as possible post-surgery.

C) Regular monitoring for secondary cataract development: Important but not as immediate as amblyopia treatment.

D) Early initiation of strabismus surgery: May be necessary if strabismus develops, but it is not a primary postoperative intervention immediately after cataract surgery.

Reference: Kanski's Clinical Ophthalmology, 9th Edition, pp: 335-337.

questions.text: Which of the following is remnant of green coloured structure?
questions.solution:
The arrow marked structure is Allantois.

Allantois

It is small diverticulum that arises from caudal wall of the yolk sac on day 16 and extends into connecting stalk.

After folding of embryo, the allantois is connected with dilated terminal part of hindgut called cloaca.

Function:

  1. It is vascularised by Allantoic vessels that later become fetal umbilical arteries and veins.
  2. It is represented by median umbilical ligament in adults.
  3. It also contributes a bit to formation of urinary bladder.

Option wise explanation:

Option B: medial umbilical ligament: is remnant of umbilical artery.

Option C: Meckel's diverticulum: is remnant of vitello intestinal duct.

Option D: Ligamentum teres hepatis: is remnant of left umbilical vein.

Option A: Median umbilical ligament

Reference: Textbook of Clinical Embryology, Vishram Singh, Third edition, Page no. 95.

questions.text: The device shown in the picture below is used in which of the following condition ?
questions.solution:
The device shown in the picture given above is called Grommet. Grommet is a ventilation tube or tympanostomy tube for ventilating and draining the middle ear, the same function as that of eustachian tube.

The Grommet is used in the management of serous otitis media SOM. Myringotomy with grommet insertion along with treatment of causative factor I.e. adenoidectomy or tonsillectomy etc. Hence option C is correct.

The main management of ASOM is medical management including antibiotics and anti inflammatory. Hence Option A is not correct.

The main management of safe csom is Tympanoplasty with or without ossicular reconstruction. Hence option B is not correct.

The main management of Unsafe csom is Mastoidectomy either canal wall up or canal wall down depending upon extent of disease thus option D is also not correct.

Reference: Disease of ear nose and throat by PL dhingra 8th edi pg 70.

questions.text: A 45 year old male patient with a history of mild hepatic impairment brought to the medicine department with seizure disorder. His physician has prescribed oxcarbazepine instead of carbamazepine. Which of the following adverse effects is more with oxcarbazepine as compared to carbamazepine?
questions.solution:
Risk of hepatotoxicity is estimated to be lower with oxcarbazepine than with carbamazepine; but that of hyponatremia is more.

Side effects of Carbamazepine & Oxcarbazepine:

Drowsiness, diplopia, ataxia, GI disturbances, headache, dizziness, sedation, idiosyncratic reactions (skin rash, aplastic anemia), hepatotoxic, thrombocytopenia.

All These side effects are more with Carbamazepine than oxcarbazepine.

Key Takeaway:

Risk of Dilutional hyponatremia is more with oxcarbazepine than with carbamazepine

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no. 442

questions.text: The Basilar membrane in the inner ear separates which of the two structures?
questions.solution:
Membranous cochlea or Scala media is a coiled tube, coiling over a bony axis which is known as Modiolus. It takes 2 and ½ to 2 and ¾ th turns around the modiolus.

The Scala media is triangular in cross section and is bounded by

  • Basilar membrane : it separates Scala media from Scala tympani. The organ of corti rests on the Basilar membrane.
  • Reissner membrane: it separates Scala media from Scala vestibuli.
  • Striae vascularis : it is the site of production of endolymph. It plays an important role in cochlear homeostasis by generating the endocochlear potential.

Option B - Scala vestibuli and Scala media are separated by Reisner membrane .

Option C -Scala tympani and Scala vestibuli are separated by entire Scala media

Option D - Striae vascularis is a part of Scala media .

Reference: Disease of ear nose and throat by PL Dhingra 8th edi pg 10.

questions.text: Impedance audiometry is an objective test used for assessment of middle ear. What is the frequency of the probe used in impedance audiometry?
questions.solution:
Impedance audiometry is a measure of condition of middle ear with intact tympanic membrane. It measures the resistance to the flow of sound energy through the middle ear on pressure changes in the EAC.

In Tympanometry probe there are 3 channels:

  • Through one channel a sound of 226hz or 220hz Is delivered to TM. In infants and neonates a high frequency probe of 1000hz is used.
  • Whenever a sound strikes the TM some of it gets absorbed and some of it gets reflected back. The 2nd channel picks up the reflected sound.
  • The 3rd channel changes the pressure of EAC from +220 to -400. When the pressure of EAC and middle ear becomes equal, maximum mobility of TM happens.

Reference: Disease of ear nose and throat by PL Dhingra 8th edi pg 24.

questions.text: A 34 year old patient visits an otolaryngologist with complaints of recurrent sinusitis. The surgeon decides to perform sinus surgery to debride the scarred sinus tissue. During the procedure, the surgeon elects to use an agent that has good local anesthesia as well as vasoconstrictive properties. Which of the following agents is most suitably surgeon has used?
questions.solution:
Cocaine is ideal for such surgery because of its topical activity; it does not require the addition of epinephrine, as it has intrinsic vasoconstrictive activity that aids in hemostasis.

  • All LAs are vasodilators except cocaine which is a vasoconstrictor. Therefore all LAs decrease BP except cocaine (increases).
  • Cocaine should NEVER be given by intravenous route or with adrenaline.
  • Cocaine is the only ester which is not metabolized by pseudocholinesterase. It is metabolized in the liver.

Cocaine blocks uptake of NA and Adr into adrenergic nerve endings

Results in higher concentration of the transmitter around the receptors

Sympathomimetic effect,

Potentiation of directly acting sympathomimetics and suppression of indirectly acting sympathomimetics

Local vasoconstriction, tachycardia, rise in BP and mydriasis:

Option B & C: Similar to cocaine, both procaine and tetracaine are ester-type compounds but without Vasoconstriction properties; however, procaine is not topically active and tetracaine is used primarily for spinal anesthesia and ophthalmologic procedures.

Option D: Lidocaine is an amide anesthetic preferred for infiltrative blocks and epidural anesthesia without Vasoconstriction properties.

Key Takeaway:

  • Cocaine has topical LA activity & has intrinsic vasoconstrictive activity that aids in hemostasis.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no. 392

questions.text: A 45 year old female presented with complain of Hearing loss and pulsatile tinnitus. On examination Red reflex sign was seen on Tympanic membrane. Pneumatic otoscopy examination showed brown s sign was positive. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Origin: Paraganglioma (Usually non chromaffin) :

  • Tympanic plexus : Glomus tympanicum (M/c)
  • Jugular bulb (CN 9, 10, 11) : Glomus jugulare

C/F :

  • Pulsatile tinnitus + CHL.
  • Aquino sign (Glomus jugulare) : Blanching of Tumor on carotid compression.
  • Brown's sign/pulsation sign : On siegalisation.

Investigation:

  • CECT (Best) → Phelp's sign : Erosion of crest of bone b/w ICA & jugular bulb.
  • Preop Ix : Urinary VMA ↑ as 10% tumors are multicentric.

Mx :

  • Slow growing tumors → Observation.
  • Small tumors → Stereotactic radiosurgery.
  • Surgical excision.

Note : Classification of jugulotympanic paragangliomas : Fisch classification.

Glomus tumor in middle ear

Option B - Osteoma appears as a single bony pedunculated swelling in the external auditory canal. Thus option B is not correct.

Option A - Squamous cell carcinoma appears as an ulceroproliferative lesion and does not shows any of the above signs. Thus option A is not correct.

Option C - Acoustic neuroma develops in the inferior vestibular nerve deep inside the Internal acoustic meatus. It shows no signs on Tympanic membrane and EAC.

Reference: Disease of ear nose and throat by PL Dhingra 8th edi pg 129- 130.

questions.text: A 56 year old female came to medicine opd with complaints of cough and sore throat. She was prescribed different medicines to curb the symptoms, following which she came back with a maculo papular rash over arms & legs as given in the below image. Which of the following drug is most likely implicated for these adverse effects?
questions.solution:
Adverse effects of Penicillins:

Penicillin G is one of the most nontoxic antibiotics; up to 20 MU has been injected in a day without any organ toxicity.

Local irritancy and direct toxicity

  • Pain at i.m. Injection site,
  • Nausea on oral ingestion and
  • Thrombophlebitis of an injected vein are dose-related expressions of irritancy.
  • Accidental i.v. injection of procaine penicillin produces CNS stimulation, hallucinations and convulsions due to procaine.

Hypersensitivity:

  • Individuals with an allergic diathesis are more prone to develop penicillin reactions. Frequent manifestations of penicillin allergy are:
    • Rash,
    • Itching,
    • Urticaria
    • Fever.
  • Wheezing, angioneurotic edema, serum sickness and exfoliative dermatitis are less common.
  • Anaphylaxis is rare (1 to 4 per 10,000 patients), but may be fatal.

Adverse Effects of Penicillins

Option A & D: These drugs can be used to prevent/manage allergic reactions.

Option B: Salbutamol does not cause allergic reactions instead it is associated with Muscle tremor and tachycardia.

Key Takeaway:

  • Individuals with an allergic diathesis are more prone to develop penicillin Hypersensitivity reactions.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no. 769

questions.text: A 2year old female child presented with bilateral profound sensorineural hearing loss. Her parents were advised that patient requires to undergo cochlear implantation. Which of the following structure is required to be intact for successful cochlear implantation?
questions.solution:
Option C - cochlear implant as the name implies bypasses the defect in the hair cells by directly stimulating the Auditory nerve fibers.

In other words it replaces the organ of corti so it will not be useful where the defect is in the Auditory nerve. Thus Auditory nerve requires to be intact and functioning for successful cochlear implant.

Cochlear implant :

  • Replaces organ of Corti : Stimulates auditory nerve.
  • Indication : B/L severe to profound HL (No benefit by hearing aid trial).
  • Insertion : Mastoid → Facial recess → Middle ear → Round window →Scala tympani (Inner ear).
  • C/I : Michel aplasia, central auditory lesions.
  • Should be implanted as early as 1 year of age.

Option A and Option B are wrong because outer hair cells and inner hair cell defect is the reason for which cochlear implantation is required. Hence they both are incorrect.

Reference: Disease of ear nose and throat by PL Dhingra 8th edi pg 147.

questions.text: A 65 year old male patient with a history of borderline leprosy was receiving multi drug therapy (MDT). Later he developed skin lesions and presented to dermatologist with features shown in the figure below. What should be the treatment for this patient?
questions.solution:
Reactions in leprosy:

Lepra reaction

  • This occurs in LL, usually coincides with institution of chemotherapy and/or intercurrent infection.
  • It is a Jarish Herxheimer (Arthus) type of reaction due to release of antigens from the killed bacilli, and may be mild, severe or life-threatening, i.e. erythema nodosum leprosum (ENL).
  • Temporary discontinuation of dapsone is recommended only in severe cases.
  • Clofazimine (200 mg daily) is effective in controlling the reaction (except the severe one), probably because of its antiinflammatory property.
  • For severe reaction, prednisolone 40-60 mg/day is started immediately and continued till the reaction subsides. The dose is then tapered over 2-3 months

Reversal reaction

  • This is seen in TT and BL cases, and is a manifestation of delayed hypersensitivity to M. leprae antigens.
  • Cutaneous ulceration, multiple nerve involvement with swollen, painful and tender nerves occur suddenly even after completion of therapy.
  • Reversal reaction is treated with clofazimine or corticosteroids in the same way as ENL, but thalidomide is ineffective.

Option A & C: MDT is not stopped in Lepra reaction hence false options.

Option B: Lepra reaction is treated with Steroids hence thalidomide is incorrect option.

Key Takeaway:

  • Reversal reaction is treated with clofazimine or corticosteroids in the same way as Erythema nodosum leprosum

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no. 837

choices.text: The mucosa appears pale and there is bleeding on removal of crusting
Alkaline nasal douching is given containing Sodium chloride, Sodium bicarbonate, Sodium biborate and Glucose
Kimicetine solution containing Chloramphenicol, propylene glycol, estradiol and vitamin D2 is used

questions.text: A 35 year old female patient presented with complain of nasal discharge and nasal obstruction. On examination nose was found to be filled with crusting and the nasal cavity was found to be roomy. The discharge was foul smelling. Which of the following statements about this condition is not true?
questions.solution:
Based on the clinical picture and symptoms given above the diagnosis in this case is Atrophic rhinitis.

Clinical features:

  • Nasal obstruction develops despite roomy nasal cavities mainly due to excessive crusting and loss of nerve supply due to atrophy.

Option. -B - Generalized atrophy of mucosa submucosa blood vessels and nerves leading to crusting which gets secondarily infected.

  • Nasal discharge which is foul smelling but the irony here is patient is not able to smell the nasal discharge due to atrophy of nerves hence it is called merciful anosmia.

Management :

Medical :

  • Alkaline douching containing Sodium chloride, Sodium bicarbonate, Sodium biborate. Glucose is not present in the Alkaline douching .
  • Option D - Kimicetine solution containing Chloramphenicol, propylene glycol, estradiol and vitamin D2 is used. Thus option d is not correct here
  • Oestrogen spray.

Surgical management :

Option A - Young s operation and Lautenslager s operation in which the nasal cavity is partially or completely closed temporarily.

Reference: Disease of ear nose and throat by PL dhingra 8th edi pg 199.

questions.text: A 71-year-old woman who underwent hip replacement was discharged from the hospital with an appropriate post-discharge therapy that included daily subcutaneous injection of regular heparin. Which of the following laboratory examinations should be performed frequently during the heparin treatment?
questions.solution:
High-molecular-weight heparin (HMWH) causes transient thrombocytopenia in up to 15% of patients and severe thrombocytopenia (which is antibody-mediated) in up to 5% of patients.

Because heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT) is a serious adverse effect of heparin, a platelet count should be performed weekly during heparin treatment.

Any thrombocytopenia appearing during treatment should be considered suspicious for HIT.

Side effects of heparin:

  • Alopecia
  • Osteoporosis
  • Hyperkalemia: It inhibits aldosterone synthesis.
  • Activates lipoprotein lipase: reduces triglycerides level.
  • Heparin Induced Thrombocytopenia (HIT)

(It is the most dangerous side effect of heparin)

Leads to Increased risk of thrombosis: venous (DVT/PE) > arterial (MI/Stroke)

Diagnosis & treatment of HIT

Definitive diagnosis: Serotonin assay (released by destroyed platelets)

Treatment: Stop heparin (HMW>LMW)

  • Start direct thrombin inhibitors parenteral like Argatroban > Lepirudin
  • (drug of choice)
  • Fondaparinux (synthetic ULMW heparin) by injection
  • Danaparoid (oral synthetic heparin)
  • Which is specially made for heparin induced thrombocytopenia
  • No role of platelet transfusion (antibodies are already present against platelet)

Option A: Heparin doesn't alter RBC Count.

Option C: Heparin causes Hyperkalemia but It doesn't Required Periodic Checkup.

Option D: Heparin action is monitored with aPTT. (Vs BT Not Required)

Key Takeaway:

  • Heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT) is a serious adverse effect of heparin, a platelet count should be performed weekly during heparin treatment.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no. 665

choices.text: Start ART now, continue throughout pregnancy and till 6 weeks after delivery
Start ART now, continue throughout pregnancy and till lifelong
Start ART after First trimester, continue throughout pregnancy and till 6 weeks after delivery
Start ART after First trimester, continue throughout pregnancy and till lifelong

questions.text: A pregnant lady was found to be HIV positive in First trimester. Next line of management is:
questions.solution:
• Antiretroviral therapy (ART) should be initiated immediately in all HIV-positive pregnant women, regardless of the trimester. Early initiation of ART helps reduce maternal viral load, preventing mother-to-child transmission (MTCT) of HIV.
  • Triple Drug Therapy: The standard regimen typically involves a combination of three antiretroviral drugs from at least two classes. Common regimens include:

Tenofovir + Lamivudine/Emtricitabine + Efavirenz (or other integrase inhibitors like Dolutegravir).

  • Current guidelines recommend that ART should be continued lifelong in HIV-positive women to maintain viral suppression and prevent further transmission to the child and others.

Incorrect options:

  • a. Start ART now, continue throughout pregnancy and till 6 weeks after delivery: ART should not be stopped after delivery; it must be lifelong.
  • c. Start ART after First trimester: ART is recommended to start immediately, even in the first trimester.
  • d. Start ART after First trimester, continue throughout pregnancy and till lifelong: ART should begin immediately, not after the first trimester.

KEY TAKEAWAYS- ART is started as soon as diagnosis is made and continued lifelong.

Reference: National Guideline for HIV Care & Treatment, MOHFW,GOI, section no.- 5a, Page No -62-66

https://naco.gov.in/sites/default/files/National_Guidelines_for_HIV_Care_and_Treatment_2021.pdf

questions.text: A 38 year old farmer is brought to the emergency department by his wife with symptoms of sudden difficulty breathing, sweating and anxiety. On history taking he was spraying insecticide when this happened. The patient is emergently intubated and given atropine. Which of the following medications should be added along with atropine?
questions.solution:
ANTICHOLINESTERASE POISONING

Clinical features:

Treatment

  1. Termination of further exposure to the poison-fresh air, wash the skin and mucous membranes with soap and water, gastric lavage according to need.
  2. Maintain patent airway, positive pressure respiration if it is failing.
  3. Supportive measures-maintain BP, hydration, control of convulsions with judicious use of diazepam.
  4. Specific antidotes:

(a) Atropine

It is highly effective in counteracting the muscarinic symptoms, but higher doses are required to antagonize the central effects.

It does not reverse peripheral muscular paralysis which is a nicotinic action.

All cases of anti-ChE (carbamate or organophosphate) poisoning must be promptly given atropine 2 mg i.v. repeated every 10 min till dryness of mouth or other signs of atropinization appear

(b) Cholinesterase reactivators

Oximes are used to restore neuromuscular transmission only in case of organophosphate anti-ChE poisoning.

Pralidoxime is ineffective as an antidote to carbamate anti-ChEs (physostigmine, neostigmine, carbaryl, propoxur)

Treatment should be started as early as possible (within a few hours), before the phosphorylated enzyme has undergone 'aging' and become resistant to hydrolysis.

Other oximes are

  1. Obidoxime --> more potent than pralidoxime
  1. Diacetyl-monoxime (DAM) - lipophilic.

Option A: Physostigmine is a cholinesterase inhibitor that is occasionally used in atropine or scopolamine poisoning.

Option B: Propranolol is a beta-blocker used for hypertension as well as other indications.

Option D: Phenylephrine is an alpha-agonist used for hypotensive emergencies.

Key Takeaway

  • Pralidoxime and diacetyl monoxime are cholinesterase regenerator compounds used for organophosphate poisoning.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no. 123

questions.text: Interval between Primary case and secondary case is known as
questions.solution:
• The gap in time between the onset of the primary case and the secondary case is called the 'serial interval'.
  • The primary case is followed by 2 or 3 secondary cases within a short time. By collecting information about a whole series of such onsets, we get a distribution of secondary cases from which we can guess the incubation period of disease.

KEY TAKEAWAYS- The gap in time between the onset of the primary case and the secondary case is called the 'serial interval'.

REFERENCE: Park's Textbook of Preventive & Social Medicine, K.park,27th Edition, Chapter -3, Page no.107-108

questions.text: DNA hybridization, where DNA is detected using specific probes, is called:
questions.solution:
Applications of Southern Blotting:

  • Genetic Testing: To detect specific mutations related to genetic diseases.
  • Forensic Analysis: In criminal investigations to match DNA samples.
  • Gene Cloning: To confirm the presence of specific gene sequences in recombinant DNA studies.
  • Option A: Southern blot
    • Correct: This technique detects specific DNA sequences through hybridization with labelled probes. It involves digesting DNA with restriction enzymes, separating the fragments by gel electrophoresis, transferring them to a membrane, and hybridizing with a complementary labelled probe.
  • Option B: Northern blot
    • Incorrect: The Northern blot is used for detecting RNA sequences. It follows a similar process as the Southern blot but focuses on RNA instead of DNA.
  • Option C: Eastern blot
    • Incorrect: The Eastern blot is used for detecting glycoproteins. It is not related to nucleic acids but instead focuses on analysing post-translational modifications.
  • Option D: Western blot
    • Incorrect: The Western blot is used for detecting proteins. This technique involves separating proteins by gel electrophoresis, transferring them to a membrane, and probing with specific antibodies.

KEY TAKE AWAY: The Southern blot technique is used for DNA hybridization to detect specific DNA sequences using labelled probes.

Reference: Sastry, A. S., & Bhat, S. K. (2022). Review of Microbiology & Immunology (With DVD) (4th ed.). Jaypee Brothers Medical Publishers. Chapter: (Blotting Techniques), Page no. 95-100.

questions.text: Which micronutrient deficiency will be responsible for Keshan's Disease?
questions.solution:
• Keshan's Disease is a dilated cardiomyopathy closely related to a diet deficient in the mineral Selenium.
  • Cardiomyopathy with myocardial necrosis results from a combination of selenium deficiency from poor dietary intake and secondary viral infection. It is named for the northeastern Chinese country Keshan, where the disease prevalence is high because of selenium-deficient soil.

Option A: Zinc deficiency can result in skin conditions include acrodermatitis enteropathica.

Option C: Copper deficiency causes fatigue and weakness.

Option D: Iron deficiency leads to Anemia.

KEY TAKEAWAYS- Keshan's Disease is a dilated cardiomyopathy closely related with a diet deficient in the mineral Selenium.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive & Social Medicine,K.park,27th Edition,Chapter -11,Page no.746

choices.text: It has a cyst stage with a single nucleus.
The trophozoite form is larger than that of Entamoeba histolytica.
It causes severe gastrointestinal disease in humans.
The cystic form lacks a prominent glycogen mass.

questions.text: Which of the following is true about Entamoeba coli?
questions.solution:
• Entamoeba coli trophozoites are significantly larger, measuring 20-50 µm in diameter, which distinguishes them from the smaller E. histolytica.
  • The cyst stage of E. coli features multiple nuclei (up to eight), which aids in identification and classification; thus, option A is incorrect.
  • E. coli is a non-pathogenic commensal, meaning it typically resides in the intestines without causing disease, contradicting option C.
  • The cystic form of E. coli indeed contains a prominent glycogen mass, particularly during the early stages, making option D incorrect.

Why Not Others:

  • Option A: The cyst stage has multiple nuclei (up to eight), not a single nucleus, indicating a critical identification feature of E. coli.
  • Option C: As a commensal organism, E. coli does not cause gastrointestinal diseases in humans; this is a key distinction from E. histolytica, which is pathogenic.
  • Option D: The presence of a prominent glycogen mass in the cystic form is a characteristic feature of E. coli, not absent as suggested.

Key Takeaway: Entamoeba coli is a larger, non-pathogenic intestinal amebae with unique features in its cyst and trophozoite forms, especially in comparison to Entamoeba histolytica.

Reference: Paniker, CK Jayaram. Paniker's textbook of medical parasitology. JP Medical Ltd, 2017, Chapter 3: Amebae pg - 26

questions.text: The amount of sewage flowing in a system in 24 hours is called:
questions.solution:
Sewage: Is waste water from a community, containing solid and liquid excreta, derived from houses, street and yard washings, factories and industries

Composition of sewage: 99.9% water + 0.1% solids (organic & inorganic)

Dry weather flow: Is the average amount of sewage that flows in sewerage system in 24 hours

Strength of sewage is expressed in terms of:

  • Biological Oxygen Demand (BOD): Is defined as the 'amount of oxygen absorbed by a sample of sewage' during a specified period (Generally 5 days), at a specified temperature (generally 20° C) for aerobic destruction or use of organic matter by living organisms
    • BOD is the most important test done on sewage (done through the Dilution method and Manometric method)
    • Strong Sewage has BOD > 300 g/liter and Weak Sewage has BOD < 100 g/liter
  • Chemical Oxygen Demand (COD): Measures oxygen equivalent of that portion of organic matter in a sample, which is susceptible to oxidation by a strong chemical oxidizer Potassium dichromate is best for COD estimation
  • Suspended solids: Amount in domestic sewage varies from 100 - 500 mg/liter
  • Strong Sewage has suspended solids amount > 500 mg/liter and Weak Sewage has suspended solids amount < 100 mg/liter.

KEY TAKEAWAYS- Dry weather flow: Is the average amount of sewage that flows in sewerage system in 24 hours

REFERENCE: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine 27th edition, Chapter 15, Page No-890-892.

questions.text: Which species of hookworm is most commonly associated with cutaneous larva migrans?
questions.solution:
• Ancylostoma braziliense is the most common species associated with cutaneous larva migrans (CLM), which occurs when hookworm larvae penetrate the skin and migrate through the epidermis, causing visible, itchy tracks.
  • The condition is primarily seen in individuals who come into contact with contaminated soil, especially in warm, coastal regions where the larvae are prevalent.
  • CLM is characterized by serpiginous (snake-like) lesions, and while it can cause discomfort, it typically does not lead to severe systemic illness.
  • In contrast, Ancylostoma duodenale and Necator americanus are well-known for causing hookworm disease, leading to symptoms such as anemia, abdominal pain, and diarrhea, as they attach to the intestinal lining and feed on blood.
  • Strongyloides stercoralis is a different type of parasitic worm that may cause skin symptoms upon penetration but does not lead to the distinct serpentine lesions associated with CLM.

Why Not Other Options:

  • A) Incorrect. Ancylostoma duodenale is associated with intestinal infections and not skin conditions like CLM.
  • B) Incorrect. Necator americanus does not typically cause cutaneous larva migrans; it leads to gastrointestinal symptoms.
  • C) Incorrect. Strongyloides stercoralis can cause skin penetration symptoms but is not classified as a hookworm and is not a common cause of CLM.

Key Takeaway:

  • Ancylostoma braziliense is the primary species linked to cutaneous larva migrans, marked by larvae migrating under the skin, producing itchy, serpentine tracks, while other hookworm species primarily cause intestinal issues.

Reference: Paniker, CK Jayaram. Paniker's textbook of medical parasitology. JP Medical Ltd, 2017, Chapter-197, Hookworm, pg - 187

questions.text: Vector for Crimean Congo hemorrhagic fever (CCHF) is:
questions.solution:
The vector for Crimean-Congo Hemorrhagic Fever (CCHF) is a tick, specifically from the Hyalomma genus. These ticks transmit the virus to humans and animals.

KEY TAKEAWAYS- The vector for Crimean-Congo Hemorrhagic Fever (CCHF) is a tick, specifically from the Hyalomma genus. These ticks transmit the virus to humans and animals.

questions.text: A 40 years old male presents with productive cough with profuse expectoration. He also reports dyspnoea on exertion which is insidious onset gradually progressive. Xray shows tram track sign. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Bronchiectasis:
    • Definition: An irreversible airway dilation, which can be focal or diffuse.
    • Types: The most common form is cylindrical or tubular bronchiectasis.
  • Clinical Manifestations:
    • Persistent productive cough: Characterized by the production of thick, tenacious sputum.
    • Dyspnea on exertion: Gradually progressive, indicating worsening respiratory function.
  • Imaging Findings:
    • X-ray: May show tram track sign, which indicates parallel linear opacities due to bronchial wall thickening, but is less sensitive.
    • HRCT Chest: The imaging modality of choice, showing:
      • Airway dilation (tram tracks or signet-ring sign)
      • Lack of bronchial tapering
      • Bronchial wall thickening
      • Inspissated secretions (tree-in-bud pattern)

Why Not Other Options:

  • A) Chronic bronchitis:
    • Typically presents with a productive cough and sputum but does not show tram track sign and involves different pathological changes.
  • C) Emphysema:
    • Characterized by the destruction of alveoli and leads to different clinical and radiological findings, such as hyperinflation.
  • D) Both A and B:
    • While chronic bronchitis may coexist with bronchiectasis, the presence of tram track sign and the clinical presentation strongly point to bronchiectasis.

Key Takeaways:

  • Bronchiectasis is characterized by irreversible airway dilation and significant sputum production.
  • X-ray findings such as the tram track sign, alongside clinical symptoms, strongly support the diagnosis.

Reference: Harrison's principle of internal Medicine 21st edition page no 2173

questions.text: What is the key distinguishing feature between TTP and HUS?
questions.solution:
TTP is characterized by a deficiency in ADAMTS13 enzyme activity, which leads to the accumulation of ultra-large von Willebrand factor multimers and subsequent microvascular thrombosis.

HUS, on the other hand, typically has normal ADAMTS13 enzyme activity.

The other options are not reliable distinguishing features between TTP and HUS:

A. Schistocytes are present in both conditions.

B. Severity of renal failure can vary in both conditions.

C. Neurological symptoms are more common in TTP, but can also occur in HUS.

KEY TAKEAWAYS- TTP is characterized by a deficiency in ADAMTS13 enzyme activity, which leads to the accumulation of ultra-large von Willebrand factor multimers and subsequent microvascular thrombosis.

Reference: ROBBINS & COTRAN, 10TH EDITION, PAGE NO. 666

choices.text: Reduced diffusion capacity for carbon monoxide

questions.text: Which of the following pattern of pulmonary function test confirms diagnosis of obstructive lung disease?
questions.solution:
• Obstructive Lung Disease: Primarily caused by airway diseases, affecting airflow.
  • Key PFT Indicator:
    • FEV1/FVC <70% is the hallmark for confirming obstructive lung disease.
  • Comparison of Lung Function Tests:
    • FEV1/FVC Ratio:
      • Obstructive: <70% (indicates significant obstruction).
      • Restrictive: >70% (airflow is preserved despite reduced lung volumes).
  • Diffusion Capacity (DLCO):
    • Normal in asthma; may be decreased in COPD due to parenchymal involvement.
  • Total Lung Capacity (TLC):
    • Usually normal in obstructive lung disease, may be decreased in restrictive lung diseases.

Why Not Others:

  • A) Total lung capacity <80%: This criterion does not specifically indicate obstructive disease; it can occur in restrictive lung diseases.
  • C) Reduced diffusion capacity for carbon monoxide: Primarily indicates parenchymal involvement, not solely obstructive disease.
  • D) All of the above: Incorrect, as only the FEV1/FVC ratio is definitive for obstructive lung disease.

Key Takeaways:

  • A FEV1/FVC ratio <70% is essential for diagnosing obstructive lung disease.
  • Understanding the differences between obstructive and restrictive patterns is crucial for accurate diagnosis.
  • The diffusion capacity (DLCO) provides additional information but is not specific to obstruction.

Reference: Harrison's principle of internal Medicine 21st edition page no 2133

choices.text: <1.0 cm2/m2 of body surface area
<1.50 cm2/m2 of body surface area

questions.text: In adults Severe aortic stenosis is defined as aortic valve area of?
questions.solution:
• Severe Aortic Stenosis (AS):
    • Defined by a valve area <1.0 cm².
    • Moderate AS: valve area 1.0-1.5 cm².
    • Mild AS: valve area 1.5-2.0 cm².
  • Aortic Valve Sclerosis:
    • Associated with a jet velocity of <2.5 m/s.
  • Diagnosis:
    • Doppler echocardiography is essential for estimating valve gradient and area.
    • A high transvalvular gradient often indicates severe obstruction.
  • Clinical Findings:
    • Pulsus parvus et tardus:
      • Characterized by a slow-rising carotid pulse with a delayed peak.
    • Auscultation:
      • A systolic ejection murmur: low-pitched, rough, loudest at the second right intercostal space.
      • Murmur often transmitted to the carotids, may confuse with mitral regurgitation (Gallavardin effect).
    • Symptoms of Severe AS:
      • Cardinal Symptoms:
        • Exertional dyspnoea: Difficulty breathing during activity.
        • Angina pectoris: Chest pain due to reduced coronary perfusion.
        • Syncope: Dizziness or fainting from reduced cardiac output.
      • Impairment of Left Ventricular (LV) Function
        • LV dilation and reduced systolic function may occur as AS progresses.
        • Patients may present with a low-flow, low-gradient severe AS even with a normal ejection fraction.

Why Not Others:

  • Option A (<1.5 cm²): This indicates moderate AS; not sufficient for severe classification.
  • Option C (<1.0 cm²/m²): Incorrect as the measurement unit is misapplied; area must be in cm² alone.
  • Option D (<1.50 cm²/m²): Indicates moderate AS, which does not align with the definition of severe AS.

Key Takeaways:

  • Severe aortic stenosis is critically defined by a valve area <1.0 cm².
  • Recognizing the severity is essential for timely intervention, particularly regarding valve replacement, to improve patient outcomes.

Reference: Harrison's principles of medicine 21st edition page no-1972

questions.text: All of the following is seen in Acute Nephritic syndrome except?
questions.solution:
• Acute Nephritic Syndrome is associated with:
    • Haematuria with RBC casts, indicating glomerular damage.
    • Proteinuria: Typically mild (1-2 g/day), reflecting mild glomerular leakage.
    • Hypertension, due to fluid retention and impaired kidney function.
    • Rising serum creatinine, reflecting reduced glomerular filtration rate (GFR).
  • >3.0 grams/day proteinuria is excessive for nephritic syndrome and is a hallmark of nephrotic syndrome. Nephrotic syndrome also features hypoalbuminemia and severe edema.

Why Not Others:

  • Haematuria with RBC casts: Typical in nephritic syndrome due to glomerular inflammation.
  • Rise in serum creatinine: Seen in nephritic syndrome due to decreased GFR.
  • Hypertension: Common in nephritic syndrome due to fluid overload and renal dysfunction.

Key Takeaways:

  • Nephritic Syndrome: Mild proteinuria (<3 g/day), haematuria, hypertension, and rising creatinine.

Nephrotic Syndrome: Marked by >3 g/day proteinuria, hypoalbuminemia, and significant edema.

Reference: Harrison's principle of Textbook 21st Medicine page no 2334

questions.text:
10-year-old boy presents with a 2-week history of Swelling in the right jaw, Weight loss, Fever, Night sweats,

Physical examination reveals:
1. Palpable lymphadenopathy in the neck and axilla
2. Hepatosplenomegaly

Biopsy of the mass reveals: 'Starry sky' appearance.

Which of the following chromosomal translocation is most commonly associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
Clinical presentation and physical examination findings are consistent with Burkitt lymphoma.

  • Biopsy findings of starry sky appearance is characteristic of Burkitt lymphoma.
  • t(8;14) translocation is a hallmark of Burkitt lymphoma.
  • The t(8;14)(q24;q32) translocation involves the MYC oncogene on chromosome 8 and the IGH gene on chromosome 14, leading to overexpression of MYC protein.
  • This translocation is seen in approximately 80% of Burkitt lymphoma cases.

The other options are not specific to Burkitt lymphoma:

B. t(11;14)(q13;q32) is associated with mantle cell lymphoma.

C. t(14;18)(q32;q21) is associated with follicular lymphoma.

D. t(4;11)(q21;q23) is associated with acute lymphoblastic leukemia.

KEY TAKEAWAYS- t(8;14) translocation is a hallmark of Burkitt lymphoma

Reference: ROBBINS AND COTRAN, 10TH EDITION, PAGE NO. 601.

choices.text: The presence of this ring correlates with a specific genetic mutation affecting copper metabolism, which is not observed in conditions involving iron or calcium deposition
This corneal ring is typically associated with a systemic condition characterized by an autoimmune response leading to inflammatory deposits around the corneal margin
The ring is often accompanied by systemic symptoms related to vitamin A deficiency, presenting as both corneal deposits and night blindness
The unique greenish-brown hue of the ring is indicative of a systemic calcium metabolism disorder, commonly found in hyperparathyroidism

questions.text: A 27-year-old patient with recent onset of hepatic dysfunction and psychiatric symptoms presents with a unique corneal finding. On examination, a ring is noted at the corneal margin. Which of the following factors most accurately differentiates this finding from similar corneal deposits seen in other systemic conditions?
questions.solution:
• The image shows KF ring.
  • Kayser-Fleischer ring is associated with Wilson's disease, which is caused by a genetic mutation affecting copper metabolism (ATP7B gene).
  • The greenish-brownhue is characteristic of copper deposition, not calcium.
  • Iron and calcium deposits result from different conditions
  • Autoimmune conditions may cause different types of corneal deposits but are not related to Kayser-Fleischer ring.
  • Vitamin A deficiency causes different corneal issues, such as xerophthalmia and night blindness
  • Calcium metabolism disorders cause different types of corneal deposits, such as band keratopathy

Genetic Basis: Wilson's disease is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern and involves mutations in the ATP7B gene, which encodes a copper-transporting ATPase.

Diagnostic Testing: Diagnostic tests include serum ceruloplasmin levels (typically low in Wilson's disease), 24-hour urinary copper excretion (often elevated), and liver biopsy for copper content.

Treatment: Management involves chelating agents (e.g., D-penicillamine) to promote copper excretion, zinc therapy to reduce copper absorption, and dietary modifications.

Reference: Kanski's Clinical Ophthalmology, 9th Edition, pg: 400.

questions.text: What will be the stage of chronic kidney disease of a patient with eGFR of 40 ml/min and persistent proteinuria of >300 mg/g?
questions.solution:
• Chronic Kidney Disease (CKD) Staging:
    • Stage Classification: CKD is classified based on glomerular filtration rate (GFR) and the degree of proteinuria.
  • eGFR of 40 ml/min:
    • This corresponds to Stage G3b (GFR 30-44 ml/min).
  • Persistent Proteinuria of >300 mg/g:
    • This indicates A3 (high proteinuria >300 mg/g).
  • Combined Staging:
    • Therefore, the stage is G3bA3.

Why Not Others:

  • G3aA3: Incorrect; G3a corresponds to eGFR of 45-59 ml/min.
  • G3aA2: Incorrect; also corresponds to eGFR of 45-59 ml/min.
  • G3bA2: Incorrect; while G3b is correct, A2 indicates lower proteinuria (<300 mg/g).

Key Takeaways:

  • The patient's CKD stage is G3bA3 due to eGFR of 40 ml/min and high proteinuria.
  • Understanding CKD staging is crucial for appropriate management and monitoring of renal function.

Reference: Harrison's principle of Textbook 21st Medicine page no 2309

choices.text: Tattoo or piercing within the last 12 months

questions.text: Which of the following would result in a permanent deferral of a blood donor?
questions.solution:
A history of HIV or HCV infection would result in a permanent deferral of a blood donor, as these viruses can be transmitted through blood transfusion and can cause serious illness.

Incorrect Options-

A: Travel to a malaria-endemic area- This would typically result in a temporary deferral of 12-24 months, depending on the specific travel history and risk assessment.

  • The donor would be eligible to donate again after the deferral period, provided they have no symptoms or history of malaria.

B: Tattoo or piercing within the last 12 months

  • This would typically result in a temporary deferral of 12 months.
  • The donor would be eligible to donate again after the deferral period, provided they have no signs of infection or complications from the tattoo or piercing.

C: History of cancer

  • This would typically result in a temporary deferral or permanent deferral, depending on the type and stage of cancer, as well as the treatment received.
  • Some types of cancer, such as skin cancer or early-stage breast cancer, may result in a temporary deferral, while others, such as leukemia or lymphoma, may result in a permanent deferral.

KEY TAKEAWAYS- A history of HIV or HCV infection would result in a permanent deferral of a blood donor, as these viruses can be transmitted through blood transfusion and can cause serious illness.

Reference: NACO GUIDELINES.

questions.text: Correct sequence for disaster cycle is
questions.solution:
This sequence follows the logical progression of disaster management:

  1. Mitigation: Efforts to reduce the impact of potential disasters.
  2. Preparedness: Planning and preparation for potential disasters.
  3. Response: Immediate actions taken during and after a disaster.
  4. Rehabilitation: Recovery and rebuilding efforts after the disaster.

So, the correct answer is A.

KEY TAKEAWAYS- The sequence for disaster cycle - Mitigation → Preparedness → Response → Rehabilitation

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th Edition,chapter-17,Page no.: 923-928.

questions.text: A 20 year old man steps into an elevator full of people who are coughing and sneezing, all of whom appear to have colds or the flu. The influenza viral particles that he inhales attach to respiratory epithelium, and viral transformation reduces the MHC class I molecules on these epithelial cells. Which of the following cells likely to respond to destroy the infected cells?
questions.solution:
A. Natural killer (NK) cells have the ability to respond with prior sensitization.

  • They carry receptors for MHC class I molecules, which inhibit their lytic function.
  • When expression of class I MHC molecules is reduced on the cell surface, the inhibitory receptors on NK cells do not receive a negative signal, and cell is killed.
  • NK cells are often the first line of the defense against viral infection.

Incorrect Options-

B. Neutrophils provide nonspecific immune response, primarily to bacterial infections and not to intra cellular viral infections.

C. CD4+ cells are helper T cells that assist other cells in immune response.

D. Macrophage can process antigen and can phagocytize necrotic cells.

KEY TAKEAWAYS- When expression of class I MHC molecules is reduced on the cell surface, the inhibitory receptors on NK cells do not receive a negative signal, and cell is killed.

Reference: ROBBINS & COTRAN, 10TH EDITION, PAGE NO. 192

choices.text: Obstructive uropathy secondary to crystallization of calcium phosphate

questions.text: A diagnosed case of multiple myeloma is started on Dexamethasone. 5 days after starting therapy he develops decreased urine output. Evaluation shows hyperkalemia, Hypocalcemia, hyperphosphatemia and hyperuricemia and raised serum urea and creatinine. The ratio of urinary uric acid to urinary creatinine is >1. Serum Creatine phosphokinase is 150 U/L (normal <130 U/L). What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Acute renal failure post chemotherapy with hyperkalemia, hyperphosphatemia and hyperuricemia indicates tumor lysis. The ratio of urinary uric acid to urinary creatinine is >1 in patients with acute hyperuricemic nephropathy and <1 in patients with renal failure due to other causes.

Serum creatine kinase and uric acid levels are often elevated in rhabdomyolysis, while tumor lysis syndrome can be associated with normal or marginally elevated creatine kinase and markedly elevated serum uric acid.

Must Know facts about TSS:

  • Tumor lysis syndrome (TLS) is characterized by hyperuricemia, hyperkalemia, hyperphosphatemia, and hypocalcemia and is caused by the destruction of a large number of rapidly proliferating neoplastic cells. Acute renal failure occurs frequently.
  • TLS is most often associated with the treatment of Burkitt's lymphoma, acute lymphoblastic leukaemia.
  • TLS usually occurs during or shortly (1-5 days) after chemotherapy. The finding of uric acid crystals in the urine is strong evidence for uric acid nephropathy. The ratio of urinary uric acid to urinary creatinine is >1 in patients with acute hyperuricemic nephropathy and <1 in patients with renal failure due to other causes. Other events may lead to renal failure in TLS.
  • Calcium phosphate also precipitates in the interstitium and renal microvasculature, leading to nephrocalcinosis.
  • Hyperkalemia in patients with renal failure may rapidly become life threatening by causing ventricular arrhythmias and sudden death.
  • The likelihood that TLS will occur in patients with Burkitt's lymphoma is related to the tumor burden and renal function. Hyperuricemia and high serum levels of lactate dehydrogenase (LDH >1500 U/L), both of which correlate with total tumor burden, also correlate with the risk of TLS.
  • The standard preventive approach consists of allopurinol and aggressive hydration. Urinary alkalization with sodium bicarbonate is no longer recommended. Febuxostat, a potent nonpurine selective xanthine oxidase inhibitor, is indicated for treatment of hyperuricemia.
  • Rasburicase (recombinant urate oxidase) can be effective in these instances, particularly when renal failure is present. Rasburicase should also be administered to high-risk patients for TLS prophylaxis.

Despite aggressive prophylaxis, TLS and/or oliguric or anuric renal failure may occur. Renal replacement therapy is often necessary and should be considered early in the course. Hemodialysis is preferred. Hemofiltration offers a gradual, continuous method of removing cellular by-products and fluid.

Reference: Harrison's principle of Textbook 21st Medicine page no 573

choices.text: Discard vial, use another new vial
Use vaccine but give double dose
Keep in freezer. Will use tomorrow

questions.text: For giving opv vaccine, worker taken out opv vial from ice lined refrigerator. Suddenly he noticed that colour of inner square of vaccine vial monitor is dark purple. He asked from his senior doctor about this. What could be advise of senior doctor?
questions.solution:
Here's why:

  • The color change in the vaccine vial monitor (VVM), which indicates that the inner square has turned dark purple, suggests that the vaccine has been exposed to inappropriate temperatures (either too high or too low) and may no longer be effective.
  • OPV (Oral Polio Vaccine) is sensitive to temperature changes, and its efficacy can be compromised if it has been stored outside the recommended temperature range. The VVM helps to ensure the vaccine is still potent.
  • Giving vaccine is not appropriate because using a vaccine with a changed VVM color could result in ineffective vaccination.
  • Use vaccine but give double dose is also not recommended as it does not address the issue of potential ineffectiveness due to improper storage.
  • Keep in freezer and use tomorrow is not a solution because the vaccine should not be stored in a freezer, and the color change indicates that the vaccine might already be compromised.

Thus, the safest course of action is to discard the vial and use a new, properly stored vial to ensure the vaccine's efficacy and safety.

Summary of the stages of a Vaccine Vial Monitor (VVM):

Reference: Immunization_Handbook_for_Medical_Officers 2017,MOHFW,GOI, unit no.-04, Page No -19-26.

questions.solution:
