questions.text: On occasion of international millet year 2023, you are preparing a report to present to government of India showing comparison of nutritive value of various millet. which type of graph would best illustrate the data?
questions.solution:
The correct answer is a. Bar chart / component bar chart.

Here's why:

  • A bar chart is ideal for comparing the nutritive values of various millets across different categories (e.g., protein, fiber, vitamins, etc.). It allows for easy visualization of differences between each millet type.
  • A component bar chart would be useful if you need to break down the nutritive value into specific components (e.g., protein, fat, carbohydrates) for each type of millet.
  • Histograms are used to show the distribution of continuous data and wouldn't be appropriate for comparing distinct categories like different types of millets.
  • Pie charts are better suited for illustrating parts of a whole rather than comparing multiple categories.
  • Pictograms use images to represent data, but bar charts are generally clearer for precise nutritional comparisons.

Thus, a bar chart or component bar chart is the best choice to illustrate the comparison of nutritive values of various millets.

Reference: Mahajan's Methods in Biostatistics for Medical Students and Research Workers, Eighth Edition, chapter-02,Page No -25-29 .

questions.text:
A 60-year-old smoker presents with shoulder pain and arm weakness. Chest X-ray shows a mass in the apex of the right lung.

Biopsy reveals:
1. Malignant cells with neuroendocrine features
2. Positive for chromogranin and synaptophysin
3. Invasion of the brachial plexus and ribs

What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Pancoast tumor is a type of lung cancer that arises in the apex of the lung and invades the surrounding structures, including the brachial plexus and ribs.

These tumors form at the superior sulcus of the lung (upper portion) and can invade nearby structures, including ribs, vertebrae, and nerves.

Symptoms (Pancoast Syndrome):

  • Shoulder pain: Radiates to the inner arm, scapula, or hand due to invasion of the brachial plexus.
  • Horner's syndrome: A triad of symptoms, including ptosis (drooping eyelid), miosis (constricted pupil), and anhidrosis (lack of sweating) on the affected side, due to involvement of the sympathetic nerves.
  • Weakness and atrophy of hand muscles: Due to brachial plexus involvement.
  • Chest pain: In advanced cases.

Incorrect Options -

A. Squamous cell carcinoma typically shows keratinization and glandular differentiation.

B. Adenocarcinoma typically shows glandular differentiation without neuroendocrine features.

C. Small cell carcinoma has a high mitotic rate, but lacks invasion of the brachial plexus and ribs.

KEY TAKEAWAYS- Pancoast tumor is a type of lung cancer that arises in the apex of the lung and invades the surrounding structures, including the brachial plexus and ribs.

Reference: ROBBINS & COTRAN, 10TH EDITION, PAGE NO. 7

questions.text: The management technique which is more promising tool for application in health field is:
questions.solution:
• Cost Effective Analysis: A management technique where benefits are expressed in terms of results achieved, e.g., number of lives saved or number of days free from disease
  • It is a more promising tool than cost benefit analysis in the health field
  • Cost Benefit Analysis: A management technique where economic benefits of any programme are compared with cost of that programme.
    • The 'benefits are expressed in monetary terms'
    • Main drawback: All benefits in field of heath cannot be expressed in monetary terms
  • Cost Accounting: A quantitative management technique that provides basic data on cost structure of any programme
  • Input-Output Analysis: An economic technique which enables calculations to be made of the effects of changing the inputs.

KEY TAKEAWAYS- Cost Effective Analysis: A management technique where benefits are expressed in terms of results achieved, e.g., number of lives saved or number of days free from disease

It is a more promising tool than cost benefit analysis in the health field.

REFERENCE: Park's Textbook of preventive and Social Medicine 27th edition, Chapter 23, Page No-998-1000.

questions.text:
A 25-year-old female presents with fever, weight loss, and decreased pulse in the left arm. Imaging studies reveal stenosis of the left subclavian artery.

A biopsy of the affected artery shows:
1. Granulomatous inflammation with giant cells
2. Marked intimal thickening and fibrosis
3. Disruption of the elastic lamina

What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Takayasu arteritis is characterized by granulomatous inflammation with giant cells, intimal thickening, and fibrosis, leading to stenosis of large arteries.

A. Giant cell arteritis typically affects older adults and involves smaller arteries. Most commonly – Superficial temporal artery, presents with temporal headache, increased ESR and polymyalgia rheumatica.

C. Polyarteritis nodosa is characterized by necrotizing inflammation without giant cells.

D. Kawasaki disease is a childhood disease with distinct clinical features.

KEY TAKEAWAYS- Takayasu arteritis is characterized by granulomatous inflammation with giant cells, intimal thickening, and fibrosis, leading to stenosis of large arteries

Reference: ROBBINS & COTRAN, 10TH EDITION, PAGE NO. 512.

questions.text: 10 month old child is brought to PHC with H/O cough and cold. On examination respiratory rate is 45/ min and no chest indrawing seen. Classify as per Integrated Management of Neonatal and Childhood Illness (IMNCI) guidelines:
questions.solution:
Based on the Integrated Management of Neonatal and Childhood Illness (IMNCI) guidelines, the correct classification for a 10-month-old child with a respiratory rate of 45/min and no chest indrawing is:

  1. No pneumonia (Cough or cold)

Reason:

  • For children aged 2 months to 12 months, a respiratory rate of 50 breaths per minute or more is classified as fast breathing and indicates pneumonia.
  • In this case, the respiratory rate is 45 breaths per minute, which is below the threshold for fast breathing, and there are no danger signs (chest indrawing, severe symptoms).

Thus, the child is classified as having "No pneumonia (Cough or cold)".

KEY TAKEAWAYS- No pneumonia is characterized by cough and cold

Reference: INTEGRATED MANAGEMENT OF NEONATAL AND CHILDHOOD ILLNESS (IMNCI),2023, Child Health Division, MOHFW,GOI, Page No - .https://nhm.gov.in/images/pdf/programmes/child-health/guidelines/IMNCI-Module-2023-For-health-worker/IMNCI-Facilitator-Guide-Health-Worker-2023.pdf

choices.text: To detect hepatitis B surface antigen
To detect copper accumulation in Wilson's disease
To detect iron accumulation in hemochromatosis

questions.text: What is the use of rhodanine stain in liver histopathology?
questions.solution:
Copper appears as red to orange deposits within hepatocytes and Kupffer cells, contrasting with the unstained tissue background.

The intensity of the stain correlates with the amount of copper accumulation.

C. Rhodamine stain is used to detect copper accumulation in liver cells, which is characteristic of Wilson's disease.

Incorrect Options-

A. Hepatitis B surface antigen is detected using immunohistochemistry.

B. Alpha-1-antitrypsin deficiency is detected using PAS stain.

D. Iron accumulation in hemochromatosis is detected using Prussian blue stain.

KEY TAKEAWAYS- Rhodanine stain is used to detect copper accumulation in liver cells, which is characteristic of Wilson's disease

Reference: ROBBINS & COTRAN, 10TH EDITION, PAGE NO. 850.

choices.text: Only in cases of ongoing internal bleeding
Within 3 hours of trauma with signs of significant haemorrhage
Only if the patient requires transfusion
In cases of isolated head injury without haemorrhage

questions.text: A 28 year old male is brought to the emergency department after a road traffic accident with significant blood loss. Which of the following is the most appropriate indication for administering tranexamic acid?
questions.solution:
Option B : Within 3 hours of trauma with signs of significant haemorrhage is Correct option. Tranexamic acid is most effective when administered early, ideally within 3 hours of trauma, in patients with significant haemorrhage.

Tranexamic Acid in Trauma:

Indications:

  • Early Administration: Most effective when given within 3 hours of trauma in patients with significant bleeding.
  • Tranexamic acid should be given to all trauma patients suspected to have significant haemorrhage, including those with a systolic blood pressure of <110 mmHg or a pulse of over 110 per minute.
  • It needs to be administered as early as possible and ideally within the first hour from injury; the first dose should not be administered more than 3 hours from injury.

Mechanism of Action:

  • Antifibrinolytic: Inhibits the breakdown of fibrin clots, helping to stabilise formed clots and reduce bleeding.

Clinical Evidence:

  • CRASH2 Trial: Demonstrated a reduction in mortality when tranexamic acid was administered early in trauma patients.

Contraindications:

  • Isolated Head Injury: Not typically recommended unless there is associated haemorrhage.
  • Late Administration: Less effective if given beyond 3 hours after injury.

Complications:

  • Thrombosis: Though rare, there is a theoretical risk of thrombotic complications with antifibrinolytic therapy.


Option A: While tranexamic acid is used to prevent bleeding, its administration is not limited to ongoing internal bleeding.

Option B: Within 3 hours of trauma with signs of significant haemorrhage is Correct option. Tranexamic acid is most effective when administered early, ideally within 3 hours of trauma, in patients with significant haemorrhage.

Option C: Tranexamic acid can be given regardless of whether transfusion is required, especially if there is potential for significant bleeding.

Option D: In cases of isolated head injury without haemorrhage, it's Not indicated as its primary use is to reduce bleeding in trauma with significant haemorrhage, not isolated head injuries without bleeding.

Key Takeaway :

Tranexamic acid indications :

  • Ideally within 1 hour, effective within 3 hours.
  • All Trauma Patients with Significant bleeding.

Tags :

Topic: Tranexamic Acid in Trauma - Indications and Use

Difficulty Level: Must Know

PYQ : NEET 2019, FMGE Dec 2023

References: Bailey and Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Chapter 27, Pages 356

questions.text: Time taken for any project is estimated by:
questions.solution:
It is the graphic plan of all events and activities to be completed in order to reach an end objective.

Two common types of network technique are:

A) Programme Evaluation and Review Technique (PERT): An arrow diagram representing the logical sequence in which events must take place. It aids in planning, scheduling, and monitoring the project; allows better communication between various levels and helps furnish timely, updated progress reports

B) Critical Path Method (CPM): The 'longest path' of the network is called as critical path. If any activity along the critical path is delayed, entire project will be delayed.

KEY TAKEAWAYS- Time taken for any project is estimated by Network Analysis.

REFERENCE: Park's Textbook of preventive and Social Medicine 27th edition, Chapter 23, Page No-1000-1002.

questions.text:
A 55-year-old woman undergoes a mastectomy for a palpable breast mass.

Histopathological examination reveals:
1. Small, uniform cells infiltrating the breast parenchyma
2. Absence of glandular architecture
3. Presence of signet ring cells
4. Loss of E-cadherin

What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A. Invasive lobular carcinoma is characterized by small, uniform cells infiltrating the breast parenchyma, absence of glandular architecture, and presence of signet ring cells.

  • Loss of E-cadherin is also characteristic of lobular carcinoma.

Histopathology:

  • Single-file pattern of invasive tumor cells, lacking the formation of duct-like structures.
  • Cells are usually small and uniform, with loss of E-cadherin expression (a key diagnostic marker differentiating it from invasive ductal carcinoma)

A. Invasive ductal carcinoma typically shows glandular architecture and is often positive for E-cadherin.

C. Ductal carcinoma in situ is a non-invasive lesion and does not show infiltration of the breast parenchyma.

D. Lobular carcinoma in situ is a non-invasive lesion and does not show signet ring cells.

KEY TAKEAWAYS- Invasive lobular carcinoma is characterized by small, uniform cells infiltrating the breast parenchyma, absence of glandular architecture, and presence of signet ring cells.

Reference: ROBBINS & COTRAN, 10TH EDITION, PAGE NO. 1052

questions.text: Following a train accident, emergency response team members reach to the site of accident and they try to segregate patients as per triage guidelines. Dead or moribund patients are included in which color category of triage system
questions.solution:
In the triage system, black is the color code used for patients who are dead or moribund (those who are unlikely to survive due to the severity of their injuries or condition). This category indicates that no further medical intervention is provided, and focus is directed to those with a higher chance of survival.

The color categories of the triage system:

KEY TAKEAWAYS: In the triage system, black is the color code used for patients who are dead or moribund (those who are unlikely to survive due to the severity of their injuries or condition).

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th Edition,chapter-17 ,Page no.:922-928.

questions.text: A 46 years old male with history of bloody diarrhoea for last 6 months presents for evaluation. CRP/ESR is raised. Imaging shows enterovesical fistula Endoscopy shows cobblestone appearance of mucosa. Which of the following antibody can be positive in this patient?
questions.solution:
Cobblestone appearance on endoscopy is characteristic of Crohn's disease. Presence of fistula further confirms the diagnosis as Crohn's disease.

  • Increased titers of anti-Saccharomyces cerevisiae antibody (ASCA) have been associated with CD, whereas increased levels of perinuclear antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibody (p-ANCA) are more commonly seen in patients with UC. However, when evaluated in a meta-analysis of 60 studies, the sensitivity and specificity of an ASCA-positive/p-ANCA-negative pattern for identification of CD were 55 and 93%, respectively.
  • In addition to ASCA, multiple other antibodies to bacterial proteins (Omp-C and I2), flagellin (CBir1), and bacterial carbohydrates have been studied and associated with CD.

Reference: Harrison's principle of Textbook 21st Medicine page no 2478

questions.text: Thrombotic Thrombocytopenic purpura is caused by deficiency of which of the following?
questions.solution:
• TTP is characterized by the pentad of MAHA, thrombocytopenia, neuro- logic symptoms, fever, and renal failure.
  • TTP can be acquired or congenital Acquired TTP accounts for >90% cases. The pathophysiology of TTP involves the accumulation of ultra-large multimers of von Willebrand factor as a result of the absence or markedly decreased activity of the plasma protease ADAMTS13, a disintegrin and metalloproteinase with a thrombospondin type 1 motif, member 13.
  • TTP can be congenital from ADAMTS13 mutation (cTTP) or acquired from autoantibody against ADAMTS13 protein (iTTP).

Reference: Harrison's principle of Textbook 21st Medicine page no 2365

choices.text: Increased efficacy of clopidogrel and hence risk of bleeding

questions.text: A 55 Years old diabetic male is recently diagnosed to have coronary artery disease. He is simultaneously started on clopidogrel, Aspirin and Proton pump inhibitors. Which of the following drug interactions may occur with this combination of drug?
questions.solution:
• Although the evidence is mixed and inconclusive, a small increase in mortality and readmission rate for coronary events was seen in patients receiving a PPI while on clopidogrel in earlier studies. Subsequently, three meta-analyses reported an inverse correlation between clopidogrel and PPI use; therefore, the influence of this drug interaction on mortality is not clearly established.
  • The mechanism involves the competition of the PPI and clopidogrel with the same cytochrome P450 (CYP2C19).
  • there appears to be at least a theoretical advantage of pantoprazole over the other PPIs, but this has not been confirmed. This drug interaction is particularly relevant in light of the common use of aspirin and clopidogrel for prevention of coronary events and the efficacy of PPIs in preventing GI bleeding in these patients.
  • Patients taking clopidogrel with aspirin, especially with other GI risk factors for bleeding, should receive GI protective therapy. Although high-dose H2 blockers have been considered an option, these do not appear to be as effective as PPIs.
  • If PPIs are to be given, some have recommended that there be a 12-h separation between administration of the PPI and clopidogrel to minimize competition of the two agents with the involved cytochrome P450. One option is to give the PPI 30 min before breakfast and the clopidogrel at bedtime.

Reference: Harrison's principle of Textbook 21st Medicine page no 2444

questions.text: Number of live births per 1000 mid-year population of women in reproductive age group is:
questions.solution:
The General Fertility Rate (GFR) is the number of live births per 1,000 women of reproductive age (usually 15-49 years) in a given year.

KEY TAKEAWAYS- The General Fertility Rate (GFR) is the number of live births per 1,000 women of reproductive age (usually 15-49 years) in a given year.

choices.text: A retrosternal goiter is typically removed via a thoracotomy.
All retrosternal goiters require a sternotomy for removal.
Over 95% of retrosternal goitres can be removed transcervically.
Surgery should always be performed in elderly patients, regardless of symptoms.

questions.text: A 65-year-old female presents with progressive dysphagia and mild shortness of breath. Imaging reveals a large retrosternal goiter extending into the superior mediastinum. Which of the following is most accurate regarding the management of retrosternal goitre?
questions.solution:
Retrosternal Goitre

  • A retrosternal goitre is a multinodular thyroid gland that grows into the mediastinum, potentially causing compression of surrounding structures.
  • Symptoms: Most patients are asymptomatic, but larger goiters can cause dysphagia, airway compression, and tracheal deviation.
  • Indications for Surgery:
    • Significant airway compression.
    • Symptomatic patients (dysphagia, dyspnea).
    • Young patients likely to develop symptoms.
  • Surgical Approach:
    • Transcervical Approach: Over 95% of retrosternal goiters can be removed transcervically.
    • Sternotomy: Required in <5% of cases, particularly for large or fixed goitres, or when malignant disease is suspected.
  • Preoperative Imaging: Cross-sectional imaging (CT) is crucial for assessing the extent of the goiter and planning the surgical approach.

Explanation of Options:

Option A) Incorrect. A thoracotomy is not the typical approach for retrosternal goiter removal. Most are removed through a transcervical approach.

Option B) Incorrect. Only a minority of retrosternal goiters require a sternotomy, specifically those with malignant disease or large goiters extending into the posterior mediastinum.

Option C) Correct. Over 95% of retrosternal goiters can be removed using a transcervical approach. Sternotomy is only needed in select cases, such as when the goiter is too large or fixed.

Option D) Incorrect. In elderly patients with incidentally discovered retrosternal goitres and no symptoms, observation is often the preferred approach rather than prophylactic surgery.

Key Points:

Most retrosternal goitres are removed transcervically.

Tags:

Topic: Retrosternal Goitre

Difficulty Level: Good to Know

PYQ: NEET PG 2019,2020

Reference: Bailey and Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Chapter 55, Pages -860

questions.text:
A 39-year-old gardener presents with a chronic, ulcerated lesion on the hand. The patient reports that the lesion initially appeared as a small bump and has progressively developed into an ulcer with multiple satellite lesions. A biopsy was performed, and the microscopic image shows small, cigar-shaped yeast cells with branching hyphae.
Based on the microscopic image, which of the following diagnoses is most consistent with the observed findings?
questions.solution:
• Sporothrix schenckii causes Rose Gardener's disease/sporotrichosis.
  • The lesion begins as a small nodule at the site of thorn prick and progressively develops into multiple, satellite nodules along the lymphatic drainage pathway.
  • Histopathological examination - in the centre there is a round-shaped cigar body-yeast and surrounding it there are projections - Splendore hoeppli (Ag-Ab reaction) and together it is called asteroid body.

Lymphocutaneous spread

Cigar shaped yeast and asteroid bodies

Rosettes of microconidia

  • A) Sporotrichosis: The image shows cigar-shaped yeast cells with branching hyphae, characteristic of Sporothrix schenckii. This fungus causes sporotrichosis, often presenting as a chronic ulcerative skin lesion with a history of plant thorn injury.
  • B) Candidiasis: Typically shows budding yeast cells and pseudohyphae, rather than cigar-shaped yeast cells. Candidiasis is usually found in mucosal or systemic infections, not typically presenting with the described skin lesion.
  • C) Blastomycosis: This fungus causes broad-based budding yeast cells, which are different from the cigar-shaped cells seen in sporotrichosis. Blastomycosis often presents with more systemic symptoms and chronic skin lesions.
  • D) Histoplasmosis: This fungal infection is usually characterized by small intracellular yeast cells within macrophages and does not show cigar-shaped yeast cells. Histoplasmosis commonly presents with respiratory symptoms and disseminated disease.

Key Takeaway: Sporotrichosis is diagnosed by identifying cigar-shaped yeast cells with branching hyphae in tissue samples, reflecting the infection by Sporothrix schenckii.

Reference:

  • CDC Sporotrichosis Overview
  • Dermatology textbooks or infectious disease references for details on the microscopic features of fungal infections.

questions.text: Which of the following contraceptive methods provides the most effective protection against sexually transmitted infections (STIs)?
questions.solution:
OPTION B: Condoms are the only contraceptive method listed that provides significant protection against STIs, including HIV, gonorrhea, chlamydia, and others. They act as a physical barrier, preventing the exchange of bodily fluids during sexual activity.

OPTION A: Oral contraceptive pills are highly effective in preventing pregnancy but do not provide any protection against STIs, as they do not act as a barrier between partners.

OPTION C: Intrauterine devices (IUD) are highly effective in preventing pregnancy, but they do not provide any protection against STIs. In fact, if a person with an IUD contracts an STI, the risk of pelvic inflammatory disease can increase.

OPTION D: Implants are a long-acting reversible contraceptive method that effectively prevents pregnancy but offers no protection against STIs, as they do not prevent the exchange of fluids during sexual intercourse.

Type: Must know

Topic: STI prevention

Reference: Speroff's Gynaecology 9th edition, Page no. 2495

questions.text: A woman with a history of repeated abortions gave birth to a low birth weight baby. The child is having rashes over palm and rhinitis. Most probable diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
OPTION B: Congenital syphilis is characterized by symptoms such as low birth weight, hepatosplenomegaly, rash (especially on palms and soles), rhinitis (snuffles), and bone abnormalities. The history of repeated abortions also suggests syphilis, as it can lead to fetal loss if untreated during pregnancy

OPTION A: Congenital HIV can lead to poor growth, recurrent infections, and developmental delays, but it does not typically present with palm rashes and rhinitis. It is more associated with symptoms like lymphadenopathy, hepatosplenomegaly, and persistent oral thrush.

OPTION C: Congenital rubella presents with cataracts, congenital heart defects, and hearing loss. It may also cause a "blueberry muffin" rash due to extramedullary hematopoiesis but does not usually cause palm rashes and rhinitis.

OPTION D: Congenital toxoplasmosis typically presents with symptoms like chorioretinitis, intracranial calcifications, hydrocephalus, and sometimes a maculopapular rash, but not specifically with palm rashes and rhinitis.

Type: Good to know

Topic: Congenital Infection

Reference: Arias' practical guide to high risk pregnancy & delivery 4th edition, Page no. 74-75

questions.text: Identify the Types of Enzyme Inhibition.
questions.solution:
Reversibly Competitive inhibition is when the inhibitor binds to the substrate-binding Site and competes with the substrate for the active enzyme-binding site. This effect of competitive inhibition can be overcome by increasing the substrate concentration by which maximum velocity can still be achieved. Therefore, Vmax is unaltered in this type of inhibition. However, the concentration of the substrate required to achieve half of the maximum velocity is increased. Therefore, Km is increased in this condition.

Non-competitive inhibition is by binding inhibitors to enzymes in locations other than the active site. Increasing the concentration of the substrate does not overcome non-competitive inhibition Thus, noncompetitive inhibitors decrease the Vmax of the reaction. They do not interfere with the binding of the substrate to the enzyme. Thus, the enzyme shows the same Km in the presence or absence of noncompetitive inhibitors.

Uncompetitive inhibition is a type of enzyme inhibition in which the inhibitor can only bind to the enzyme-substrate complex. As a result, uncompetitive inhibition Vmax decreases but it does not change the affinity of the enzyme for the substrate. the inhibitors typically bind to an allosteric site on the enzyme which changes the shape of the enzyme and makes it more difficult for the substrate to bind.

For example, the drug methotrexate is an uncompetitive inhibitor of dihydrofolate reductase, an enzyme that is involved in the synthesis of DNA.

Suicidal inhibition, also known as irreversible inhibition or mechanism-based inhibition, is a type of enzyme inhibition in which the inhibitor irreversibly binds to the active site of the enzyme, causing permanent inactivation.

Reference: Biochemistry - Lippincott's Illustrated Review, SAE edition, Chapter 10, Page - 142

choices.text: Takayasu arteritis with Anca associated vasculitis

questions.text: A young female presents with sudden onset partial vision loss of left eye. Additionally she also reports claudication in right upper limb. Examination shows right radial and brachial artery pulse to be absent. A carotid bruit is also audible. Rest of the cardiovascular examination is normal. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Takayasu arteritis

  • Takayasu arteritis is an inflammatory and stenotic disease of medium- and large-sized arteries characterized by a strong predilection for the aortic arch and its branches.
  • It is most prevalent in adolescent girls and young women. Although it is more common in Asia, it is neither racially nor geographically restricted.
  • The disease involves medium- and large-sized arteries, with a strong predilection for the aortic arch and its branches; the pulmonary artery may also be involved. The involvement of the major branches of the aorta is much more marked at their origin than distally. Narrowing of the lumen occurs with or without thrombosis. demonstrated, but their pathogenic significance is unclear.
  • CLINICAL AND LABORATORY MANIFESTATIONS Takayasu arteritis is a systemic disease with generalized as well as vascular symptoms. The generalized symptoms include malaise, fever, night sweats, arthralgias, anorexia, and weight loss, which may occur months before vessel involvement is apparent. These symptoms may merge into those related to vascular compromise and organ ischemia. Pulses are commonly absent in the involved vessels, particularly the subclavian artery. Hypertension occurs in 32-93% of patients and contributes to renal, cardiac, and cerebral injury.
  • Vision loss is most common ocular manifestation in Takayasu arteritis and sudden onset vision loss can be due to embolization in retinal artery.

Ref: Harrison's principle of Textbook 21st Medicine page no 2770

questions.text: A 30 year old woman presents with recurrent urinary tract infections and flank pain. Imaging shows a cystic dilation at the distal end of the ureter inside the bladder. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ureterocele

  • Ureterocele:
    • Cystic dilation of the distal ureter, often at the ureterovesical junction. It can cause obstruction, leading to hydronephrosis and recurrent infections.
  • Types:
    • Simple (orthotopic) and ectopic.
    • Ectopic ureteroceles are more common in duplex systems and are associated with significant clinical symptoms.
  • Symptoms:
    • Recurrent UTIs, flank pain, hematuria, or asymptomatic and found incidentally on imaging.
  • Diagnosis:
    • Ultrasound or cystoscopy; may show a ballooning of the distal ureter within the bladder.
    • When large, they can obstruct the bladder neck or even the contralateral ureteric orifice. The classic feature of a ureterocele on an intravenous urogram (IVU) is the 'cobra head'

  • Management:
    • The treatment of simple ureteroceles is surgical excision with reimplantation of the ureter.
    • Endoscopic incision of a ureterocele is the preferred treatment method for simple ureteroceles in infants and small children, but may result in subsequent ureteric reflux.
    • A non-functioning kidney may need nephrectomy.

Option A: Vesicoureteral reflux is Incorrect. This condition involves the backward flow of urine from the bladder into the ureters, but it does not present as a cystic dilation within the bladder.

Option B: Ureterocele is Correct. Ureterocele is a cystic dilation of the distal ureter, often visible within the bladder and associated with obstructive symptoms.

Option C: Urethral diverticulum is Incorrect. This condition involves the urethra and typically presents with dysuria, post void dribbling, or recurrent UTIs.

Option D: Bladder cystitis is Incorrect. Cystitis is inflammation of the bladder lining, not characterised by cystic dilation within the ureter.

Key Takeaway:

  • Ureterocele often presents with recurrent UTIs and may cause hydronephrosis.
  • Diagnosis is typically made with imaging studies.

Tags :

Topic: Ureterocele

Difficulty Level: Good to Know

Tags : FMGE Aug 2020, FMGE Dec 2020

References: Bailey and Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Chapter 82, Pages 1467

questions.text: A 53-year-old man was brought to the medicine department for evaluation of his hypertension. He has a history of having chronic kidney disease related to IgA nephropathy. Blood pressure is 170/96 mmHg on serial measurements. Serum creatinine is 3.2 mg/dl and potassium is 6.7 meEq/L. Which of the following drugs is most appropriate for the treatment of this man's hypertension?
questions.solution:
This patient has hypertension in the setting of chronic kidney disease and hyperkalemia. Amlodipine is the safest drug in this regard from above options.

Amlodipine is a dihydropyridine calcium channel blocker. It has no major adverse effects on renal function or potassium.

The major side effect is lower extremity edema.

Advantages of CCBs as an Anti-hypertensive agent are:

Do not compromise haemodynamics

No sedation or other CNS effects

Not contraindicated in asthma, angina (especially variant) and PVD patients

Are particularly effective in elderly patients, black races and low renin hypertensives.

Do not affect male sexual function.

No deleterious effect on plasma lipid profile, uric acid level and electrolyte balance.

Shown to have no/minimal effect on quality of life.

No adverse foetal effects; can be used during pregnancy

The long-acting DHPs are next to ACE inhibitors in reducing albuminuria and slowing disease progression in hypertensive/diabetic nephropathy

Option A : Valsartan is an angiotensin receptor blocker. It reduces the glomerular filtration rate (GFR) through vasodilation of the efferent arteriole. These drugs are generally avoided in advanced renal failure for this reason.

It may also increase potassium levels through inhibition of aldosterone release from the adrenal glands.

Option B : Hydrochlorothiazide is a thiazide diuretic. This drug will reduce the effective circulating volume and lower GFR thereby worsening renal function.

Option D : Spironolactone is a potassium sparing diuretic. Spironolactone also raises serum potassium which could be life-threatening in this man who already has hyperkalemia.

Key takeaway

The long-acting DHPs are next to ACE inhibitors in reducing albuminuria and slowing disease progression in hypertensive/diabetic nephropathy

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi 8th edition, page no. 609

questions.text: A 19 year old woman has a history of asthma for 10 years. She was brought to the medicine department with complaints of an acute onset of wheezing. Which of the following drugs would be the best for treatment of an acute attack of asthma?
questions.solution:
Inhaled albuterol would provide the fastest acting and most localized therapy for an acute attack.

Bronchodilators are the only drugs useful in terminating acute attack of bronchial asthma.

  • Adrenergic drugs (β2 agonists) act by:
    • Stimulating GPCRs - Activation of adenylyl cyclase - Increase in cAMP
      • smooth muscle relaxation(bronchodilation)
      • Decreases the mediator release from mast cells.
      • Inhibit microvascular leakage
      • Increase mucociliary transport by increasing ciliary activity.
    • By inhalation route, these are the fastest acting drugs.
    • Salbutamol (albuterol), metaproterenol, and terbutaline are fast acting drugs by inhalation route.They are used for aborting an attack of acute asthma.
    • Not suitable for prophylaxis because of the shorter duration of action.

Option B, C & D: All of them are orally active drugs which will take some time to act. So they are not preferred for acute emergency conditions.

Key Takeaway :

Inhaled albuterol would provide the fastest acting and most localized therapy for an acute attack.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi 8th edition, page no. 242

questions.text: A 55 year old male presents with a 3 cm staghorn calculus in the renal pelvis causing recurrent urinary tract infections. What is the best surgical approach for this stone?
questions.solution:
Percutaneous Nephrolithotomy (PCNL)

  • A minimally invasive surgical procedure where a nephroscope is inserted through a small incision in the back to access the kidney. Stones are removed or fragmented using ultrasonic or laser lithotripsy.
  • Indications:
    • Large stones (>2 cm),
    • staghorn calculi,
    • complex renal anatomy
    • failed less invasive treatments.
  • Contraindications to percutaneous nephrolithotomy
    • Pregnancy.
    • Untreated UTI.
    • Bleeding diathesis.
    • Current anticoagulation.
  • Advantages: High success rate, shorter recovery time compared to open surgery.
  • Complications: Bleeding, infection, injury to adjacent organs, and residual stone fragments.

Option A: ESWL is less effective for large stones (>2 cm) and staghorn calculi.

Option B: RIRS is suited for smaller stones and not typically used for large staghorn calculi.

Option C: Percutaneous nephrolithotomy (PCNL) is Correct. PCNL is the procedure of choice for large or complex stones like staghorn calculi, allowing direct access to remove or fragment the stone.

Option D: Open nephrolithotomy is rarely indicated today except in cases where minimally invasive techniques fail or are contraindicated.

Key Takeaway:

  • PCNL is the preferred method for large renal stones and staghorn calculi.
  • It is more effective and has fewer complications than open surgery.

Tags :

Topic: Percutaneous Nephrolithotomy (PCNL)

Difficulty Level: Must Know

PYQ : FMGE Jan 2023 , FMGE Aug 2020

References: Bailey and Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Chapter 82, Pages 1476

questions.text: A 18-month-old child presented to paediatric OPD with ambiguous genitalia, on investigation his BP is 110/70 mm Hg, Serum potassium is 6.5 mEq/L, serum sodium is 115 mEq/L. He was later started on intravenous fluids. What is the most specific therapy will you add to this patient immediately?
questions.solution:
• Normal serum K+ level is 3.5-5.0 mEq/L . Normal Na+ level is 136-152 mEq/L. So, the patient in the question has hyperkalemia and hyponatremia.
  • This together with ambiguous genitalia suggests the diagnosis of CAH (Congenital adrenal hyperplasia).
  • In CAH, there is deficiency of glucocorticoids and mineralocorticoids
  • Hydrocortisone is the glucocorticoid with maximum mineralocorticoid activity, so it is the preferred drug for treatment of this patient.
  • Congenital adrenal hyperplasia (Adrenogenital syndrome)
    • It is a familial disorder due to genetic deficiency of steroidogenic enzymes, mostly 21-hydroxylase.
    • As a result the synthesis of hydrocortisone and aldosterone suffers.
    • There is compensatory increase in ACTH secretion causing adrenocortical hypertrophy.
    • Enzyme deficiency being only partial in most cases, normal amounts of gluco- and mineralocorticoids are produced along with excessive amounts of weak androgens which produce virilisation and/or precocious sexual development.
    • Treatment is to give hydrocortisone in divided doses round the clock to maintain feedback suppression of pituitary.
    • If salt wasting persists-fludrocortisone 50-200 μg/day may be added.

Option B, C & D: All agents given here are not used in Congenital adrenal hyperplasia

Key Takeaway

Hydrocortisone is the glucocorticoid with maximum mineralocorticoid activity, hence preferred in cases with Congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH) where there is deficiency of glucocorticoids and mineralocorticoids

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi 8th edition, page no. 314

questions.text: A 45 year old female is found unconscious after a motor vehicle accident. To open her airway, what is the most appropriate manoeuvre to use if there is no suspicion of a cervical spine injury?
questions.solution:
Option C : Head tilt, chin lift is Correct as The first line manoeuvre for opening the airway in an unconscious patient without a suspected cervical spine injury.


Head Tilt, Chin Lift Maneuver:

Purpose:

  • Head Tilt, Chin Lift: A technique used to open the airway in an unconscious patient by preventing the tongue from obstructing the airway.

Indications:

  • Unconscious Patients: Particularly those without a suspected cervical spine injury.
  • Airway Obstruction: Due to the tongue falling back against the pharynx, common in unconscious patients.

Technique:

  • Head Tilt: Place one hand on the patient's forehead and gently tilt the head back.
  • Chin Lift: Use the fingertips of your other hand to lift the chin upwards and forwards.

Contraindications:

  • Suspected Cervical Spine Injury: In such cases, the jaw thrust manoeuvre should be used instead, as it does not involve movement of the cervical spine.

Complications:

  • Exacerbation of Cervical Spine Injury
  • Inadequate Airway Opening

Option A: Jaw Thrust manoeuvre is Used when cervical spine injury is suspected to open the airway without moving the neck.

Option B: Nasopharyngeal airway insertion is An adjunct airway device but not the initial manoeuvre for opening the airway.

Option C: Head tilt, chin lift is Correct as The first line manoeuvre for opening the airway in an unconscious patient without a suspected cervical spine injury.

Option D: Oropharyngeal airway insertion: A useful airway adjunct but not the initial manoeuvre for airway opening.

Key Takeaway :

  • The head tilt, chin lift manoeuvre is the preferred method for opening the airway in unconscious patients without suspected cervical spine injuries.
  • In trauma patients with potential cervical spine injuries, the jaw thrust manoeuvre should be used instead.

Tags :

Topic: Head Tilt, Chin Lift

Difficulty Level: Must Know (Easy)

PYQ : NEET 2021, FMGE Aug 2021

References: Bailey and Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Chapter 27, Pages 355

questions.text: Hypertriglyceridemia is considered a risk factor for acute pancreatitis. At what serum levels of serum triglycerides it usually causes acute pancreatitis?
questions.solution:
• Hypertriglyceridemia is the cause of acute pancreatitis in 1-4% of cases; serum triglyceride levels are usually >1000 mg/dL. Most patients with hypertriglyceridemia pancreatitis have undiagnosed or uncontrolled diabetes mellitus.
  • Any factor (e.g., alcohol or medications, such as oral contraceptives) that causes an abrupt increase in serum triglycerides can potentially precipitate a bout of acute pancreatitis.
  • Common causes of acute pancreatitis Include:
    • Gallstones (including microlithiasis)
    • Alcohol (acute or chronic)
    • Hypertriglyceridemia
    • Post ERCP
    • Idiopathic

Reference: Harrison's principle of Textbook 21st Medicine page no 2658

questions.text: A 50 year old male is brought to the emergency department after a motorcycle accident. He is hypotensive, bradycardic, and has warm extremities. His physical exam reveals flaccid paralysis below the level of T6. What type of shock is most likely present?
questions.solution:
Option D : Neurogenic shock is Correct as it Results from the loss of sympathetic tone due to spinal cord injury above T6, leading to hypotension, bradycardia, and warm extremities.

Spinal Shock vs. Neurogenic Shock:

Spinal Shock:

  • Definition: Temporary loss of all neurological activity below the level of injury, including motor, sensory, and reflex functions.
  • Duration: Can last hours to weeks.
  • Clinical Features: Flaccid paralysis, areflexia, and absence of sensation below the level of the lesion.
  • Resolution: Gradual return of reflexes, often marked by the return of the bulbocavernosus reflex.

Neurogenic Shock:

  • Definition: A type of distributive shock resulting from the loss of sympathetic tone due to spinal cord injury, typically above T6.
  • Clinical Features: Hypotension, bradycardia, and warm, dry skin due to vasodilation and unopposed parasympathetic activity.
  • Management: Stabilisation of the cervical spine, administration of fluids, vasopressors, and atropine for bradycardia.

Option A: Hypovolemic shock Typically presents with hypotension, tachycardia, and cool, clammy skin due to blood loss, not associated with bradycardia or warm extremities.

Option B: Cardiogenic shock Usually characterised by hypotension, tachycardia, and signs of heart failure (e.g., pulmonary edema) but not flaccid paralysis or bradycardia.

Option C: Spinal shock Refers to the temporary loss of all neurological function (motor, sensory, and reflex) below the level of the injury, not directly involving hypotension or bradycardia.

Option D: Neurogenic shock is Correct as it Results from the loss of sympathetic tone due to spinal cord injury above T6, leading to hypotension, bradycardia, and warm extremities.

Key takeaway :

  • Spinal Shock: Focuses on the temporary loss of neurological function.
  • Neurogenic Shock: Involves hemodynamic instability due to autonomic disruption.

Tags :

Topic: Spinal Shock vs. Neurogenic Shock - Differences

Difficulty Level: Must Know

PYQ : NEET 2022, FMGE Jan 2023

References: Bailey and Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Chapter 30, Pages 402

questions.text:
A patient presents with a skin lesion that has a black eschar. The Gram stain image shows large, Gram-positive rods with square ends and a characteristic "boxcar" appearance.

Which bacterial species is most likely associated with these findings?
questions.solution:
Gram-positive rods with a "boxcar" appearance and large size, associated with cutaneous anthrax and a black eschar.

  1. Bacillus anthracis: Gram-positive rods with a "boxcar" appearance and large size, associated with cutaneous anthrax and a black eschar.
  2. Bacillus cereus: Gram-positive rods but not with the characteristic "boxcar" appearance.
  3. Clostridium botulinum: Gram-positive rods but typically associated with botulism, not the "boxcar" appearance.
  4. Clostridium perfringens: Gram-positive rods but typically associated with gas gangrene, not the "boxcar" appearance.

Key Takeaway: Bacillus anthracis is characterized by large, Gram-positive rods with a "boxcar" appearance, often associated with cutaneous anthrax.

Reference: CDC Bacillus anthracis

questions.text: Which of the following is a feature of compensated cirrhosis of liver?
questions.solution:
Patients who have cirrhosis have varying degrees of liver function, and clinicians need to differentiate between those who have stable, compensated cirrhosis and those who have decompensated cirrhosis. Patients who have developed ascites, hepatic encephalopathy, or variceal bleeding are classified as decompensated. They should be considered for liver transplantation, particularly if the decompensations are poorly controlled. Many of the complications of cirrhosis will require specific therapy. Portal hypertension is a significant complicating feature of decompensated cirrhosis and is responsible for the development of ascites and bleeding from esophagogastric varices, two complications that signify decompensated cirrhosis. Loss of hepatocellular function results in jaundice, coagulation disorders, and hypoalbuminemia and contributes to the causes of portosystemic encephalopathy.

Reference: Harrison's principle of Textbook 21st Medicine page no 2624

choices.text: Plasmids do not influence bacterial virulence and only carry genes for replication
Plasmids can encode toxins and virulence factors that enhance the pathogenicity of bacteria
Plasmids are exclusively responsible for bacterial growth and replication but do not affect virulence
Plasmids act as structural components of the bacterial cell wal

questions.text: What role do plasmids play in bacterial virulence?
questions.solution:
Plasmids are small, circular, double-stranded DNA molecules found in bacteria and some eukaryotes, separate from chromosomal DNA.

They replicate independently of the host's chromosomal DNA

Role of plasmids in bacterial virulence:

  • Option A: Incorrect. Plasmids can carry virulence factors in addition to genes necessary for their replication.
  • Option B: Correct. Plasmids can encode toxins and other proteins that increase bacterial virulence, enhancing pathogenicity.
  • Option C: Incorrect. While plasmids are involved in replication, they also significantly impact bacterial virulence by carrying genes for toxins.
  • Option D: Incorrect. Plasmids are not structural components of the bacterial cell wall; they are independent DNA molecules.

Key Takeaway: Plasmids play a crucial role in bacterial virulence by encoding toxins and other factors that increase pathogenicity, in addition to carrying genes for their own replication.

Reference: Smith, J. (2024). Classification of microorganisms. In R. Brown & L. Green (Eds.), MIMS' Medical Microbiology and Immunology (6th ed., 2- CHAPTER The bacteria pp: 15).

questions.text: What is the primary vector responsible for transmitting dengue virus to humans?
questions.solution:
A) Anopheles mosquito: Incorrect. The Anopheles mosquito is primarily responsible for transmitting malaria, not dengue. Sits at an angle to surface.

B) Aedes mosquito: Correct. The Aedes mosquito, specifically Aedes aegypti and Aedes albopictus, is the primary vector responsible for transmitting the dengue virus to humans.

C) Culex mosquito: Incorrect. Culex mosquitoes are vectors for other diseases such as West Nile virus and filariasis, but not dengue.

D) Tsetse fly: Incorrect. The tsetse fly is the vector for trypanosomiasis (sleeping sickness), not dengue fever.

Key Takeaway: The Aedes mosquito is the primary vector for dengue fever transmission. Understanding these properties helps in devising control measures and public health interventions to mitigate the spread of diseases transmitted by Aedes mosquitoes.

Reference: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC). Dengue Transmission. CDC Dengue Transmission

questions.text:
40-year-old male presents with hematuria and proteinuria. Urine microscopy reveals:

Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Figure 1 shows dysmorphic RBCs.
  • Figure 2 shows Red cell cast.

Dysmorphic red blood cells and red blood cell casts are indicative of glomerular damage, which is consistent with glomerulonephritis.

  • Glomerulonephritis is a group of diseases characterized by inflammation of the glomeruli, leading to hematuria, proteinuria, and kidney dysfunction.

Incorrect Options-

A: IgA nephropathy (also called Berger's disease) is a kidney disorder caused by the buildup of IgA antibodies in the glomeruli (filtering units) of the kidneys, leading to inflammation and damage.Caused due to Abnormal deposits of IgA antibodies in the kidneys.

B: Alport syndrome is a genetic disorder affecting the kidneys, eyes, and ears, primarily caused by mutations in genes that produce type IV collagen, an essential part of the kidney's glomerular basement membrane.

C: Thin Basement Membrane Disease (TBMD), also known as benign familial hematuria, is a genetic condition characterized by a thinning of the glomerular basement membrane in the kidneys.

KEY TAKEAWAYS- Glomerulonephritis is a group of diseases characterized by inflammation of the glomeruli, leading to hematuria, proteinuria, and kidney dysfunction.

Reference: ESSENTIALS OF CLINICAL PATHOLOGY, 2ND EDITION, PAGE NO. 38.

questions.text: Estimation of which of the following in stool is useful for diagnosis of pancreatic insufficiency in a patient presenting with steatorrhea?
questions.solution:
• To diagnose steatorrhea, a spot stool can be submitted for Sudan III staining, which is specific for fecal fat. This is a useful qualitative but not quantitative test. Stool for elastase is helpful for diagnosing pancreatic insufficiency.
  • A 24-h assessment of stool volume/weight may be useful to establish the presence of clinically significant absorptive or secretory diarrhea vs diarrhea from other causes such as proctitis, which causes frequent, small, low-volume stools.
  • The gold standard for documenting steatorrhea is the 72-h fecal fat collection, which is performed in concert with the patient's consumption of a 100-g fat diet. This test is highly accurate but difficult to obtain due to patient reluctance to collect stool.
  • Finally, the calculation of the stool osmotic gap is a very useful and easy way to diagnose an osmotic diarrhea.

Reference: Harrison's principle of Textbook 21st Medicine page no 2467

choices.text: Thick ascending loop of Henle in the kidney
Pulmonary epithelial cells in the lungs

questions.text: ENaC channel is not found in
questions.solution:
• ENaCs (epithelial sodium channels) are sodium transport channels which help in reabsorption of sodium in various systems of the body.
  • In the salty and sour sensation signal transduction mechanism include the passage through ENaC ion channels.
  • At birth, there is a shift from Cl- secretin to Na+ absorption by pulmonary epithelial cells via the epithelial Na+ channels (ENaC), and fluid is absorbed with the Na+.
    • Prolonged immaturity of the ENaC contributes to the pulmonary abnormalities in IRDS.
  • The aldosterone (adrenocortical mineralocorticoid) have two effects in the collecting duct for Na+ reabsorption.
    • Rapid effect to increase activity of ENaC channels by inserting the channels into the membrane.
    • Slower effect to increase the synthesis of ENaCs.
  • In thick ascending limb of loop of Henle Na-K-Cl cotransporter and Na/H exchanger. ENaC are not found in it.

Reference: Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology, 26th Edition, Table 37-5, Page no. 435,812,1441,1559

questions.text: Rate of involution of uterus is:
questions.solution:
The average rate of uterine involution is approximately 1.25 cm per day.

Rate of Uterine Involution

  • Immediately after delivery: Uterus is at the level of the umbilicus.
  • Day 1 postpartum: Fundus is approximately 1.25 cm below the umbilicus.
  • Daily reduction: The fundus descends about 1.25 cm per day.
  • End of 1 week: Fundus is typically midway between the umbilicus and the pubic symphysis.
  • End of 2 weeks: Uterus is no longer palpable abdominally.
  • By 6 weeks: Uterus returns to its non-pregnant size (around 60-80 grams).

This steady descent continues until the uterus reaches its normal size and position by about 6 weeks postpartum. Factors like breastfeeding (which increases oxytocin release), parity, and presence of complications can influence this rate.

Type: Must know

Topic: Involution of uterus

Reference: Dutta's Obstetrics 9th edition, Page no. 169-170

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy was taken to the pediatrician for routine checkup. Pediatrician evaluated him and found that he has autoimmune disorder causing damage to the small intestine. What could be the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Option C) Celiac disease is an autoimmune disorder triggered by the ingestion of gluten (a protein found in wheat, barley, and rye). It damages the small intestine lining by intestinal T cells, leading to malabsorption of nutrients.
  • The disease recovers if the gluten containing diet is removed from diet.
  • Option B) Hartnup disease is caused by a congenital defect in the mechanism that transports neutral amino acids in the intestine and renal tubules. It causes cystinuria.
  • Option A) Lactose intolerance occurs due to absence of lactase enzyme. It is congenital defect. Due to inability to digest the lactose, it produces diarrhea, bloating and pain in the abdomen. Simplest treatment is to avoid dairy products.
  • Option D) Cystinuria is caused due to congenital defect in transport of basic amino acid.

Reference: Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology, 26th Edition, page no. 1100, 1105, 1110.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman is considering starting a hormonal contraceptive but is concerned about its effect on her bone density. Which of the following is the most likely hormonal method to affect bone density?
questions.solution:
OPTION C: Depot medroxyprogesterone acetate (DMPA) is a progestin-only injectable contraceptive, is associated with a decrease in bone mineral density, especially with long-term use (more than two years). This effect is reversible after discontinuation, but it is the most likely hormonal method to affect bone density adversely among the listed options.

OPTION A: Combined oral contraceptive pills contain both estrogen and progestin, which generally do not have a negative impact on bone density. In some cases, they may even have a protective effect on bone health.

OPTION B: Contraceptive patch delivers both estrogen and progestin through the skin. It does not negatively affect bone density and may help maintain or improve bone health due to the presence of estrogen.

OPTION D: Contraceptive implants which release a small amount of progestin over time, have not been shown to significantly affect bone density in most users, unlike DMPA.

Type: Must know

Topic: DMPA & its adverse effects

Reference: Speroff's Gyanecology 9th edition, Page no. 2417

questions.text: A patient has been suffering from Acute Diarrhea since 03 days. Identify the correct Acid Base Imbalance from the above diagram the patient is suffering from.
questions.solution:
• Above diagram explains changes occurs in pH and HCO3 values in different conditions leading to Acid Base Imbalance.
  • In chronic Diarrhea, there is direct loss of fluid rich in bicarbonate from the Gastrointestinal tract. To maintain electric Neutrality of the blood, chloride is reabsorbed back and Anion Gap remains normal and H+ ion concentration increases leading to Metabolic acidosis.
  • In this condition pH less than 7.35 and HCO3 - ion < 22 mmol/L which is seen in option C and marked in image as III. Compensation by Respiratory system and Hyperventilation.

Option B) Metabolic Alkalosis: (Marked as II in image)

Primary disturbance: Increase in HCO3-

  • pH: Increased (> 7.45)
  • HCO3-: Increased (> 26 mEq/L)
  • Compensation: Respiratory system compensates by hypo ventilating to retain CO2 (PaCO2 increases)

Option A) Respiratory Acidosis: Marked as (I)

  • Primary disturbance: Increased PaCO2 (due to hypoventilation or respiratory failure)
  • pH: Decreased (< 7.35)
  • HCO3-: Initially normal, but may increase if renal compensation occurs (to buffer excess acid)
  • Compensation: Kidneys retain HCO3- to neutralize the excess CO2 (slow process)

Option D) Respiratory Alkalosis: Marked as IV

  • Primary disturbance: Decreased PaCO2 (due to hyperventilation)
  • pH: Increased (> 7.45)
  • HCO3-: Initially normal, but may decrease if renal compensation occurs (kidneys excrete more HCO3-)
  • Compensation: Kidneys excrete HCO3- to reduce pH (slow process)

Reference: Biochemistry - Lippincott's Illustrated Review SAE, Chapter 4, Page 40-41

questions.text: A 34 year old male presents to the emergency department with sudden chest pain and severe shortness of breath after being involved in a road traffic accident. On examination, he has tracheal deviation to the left, hyperresonance on the right side, and absent breath sounds on the right. What is the next most appropriate step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Tension Pneumothorax:

Pathophysiology:

  • Mechanism: Air enters the pleural space during inspiration but cannot escape during expiration, leading to increased intrathoracic pressure.
  • Complications: This pressure shift compresses the lung and mediastinal structures, leading to decreased venous return, reduced cardiac output, and potential cardiovascular collapse.

Clinical Features:

  • Symptoms: Sudden onset of chest pain and severe dyspnea.
  • Signs: Tracheal deviation away from the affected side, hyperresonance to percussion, absent breath sounds on the affected side, and distended neck veins.

Diagnosis:

  • Clinical Diagnosis: Based on physical examination findings; should not delay treatment.
  • Imaging: While a chest X-ray can confirm the diagnosis, it is not required before initiating emergency treatment.

Management:

  • Immediate Needle Decompression: Insert a large bore needle (14-16 gauge) into the fifth intercostal space at the midclavicular line of the affected side to relieve pressure.
  • Chest Tube Insertion: Following needle decompression, a chest tube should be placed to allow continuous evacuation of air and reexpansion of the lung.

Explanation of Options :

Option A : Tension pneumothorax is a medical emergency, and immediate needle decompression is necessary to relieve the pressure.

Option B : Although a chest Xray can confirm the diagnosis, it is not the first step in a life threatening emergency.

Option C : Oxygen therapy can help in improving low saturation but will not resolve the underlying tension pneumothorax.

Option D : Antibiotics are not indicated in the immediate management of tension pneumothorax.

Key Takeaways:

  • Tension pneumothorax is a life threatening emergency requiring immediate needle decompression to prevent cardiovascular collapse.
  • Rapid recognition and intervention are critical, with chest tube placement following initial decompression.

Tags :

Topic: Tension Pneumothorax - Diagnosis and Emergency Treatment

Difficulty Level: Must Know

PYQ : NEET 2019, 2020 , 2021 , 2023 | Inicet Nov 2020 | FMGE Aug 2020, FMGE Dec 2020 , FMGE June 2021

References:

Bailey and Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Chapter -29 , page no -374

questions.text: A -30 years old Male presented with above cutaneous manifestation on sun exposed areas along with increase in urine uroporphyrin levels, what should be your probable Diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Cutaneous manifestation seen in above image over the sun exposed area is skin eruption due to accumulation of porphyrin mainly seen in most common type of Porphyria - Chronic Hepatic Porphyria - also known as Porphyria Cutanea Tarda.
  • The disease is associated with Deficiency of Uroporphyrinogen decarboxylase. It is mainly Autosomal Dominant Disorder. Clinical Manifestation depends on hepatic iron overload, exposure to sunlight, alcohol ingestion, oestrogen therapy and seen in fourth / fifth decades of life.
  • Conversion of Uroporphyrinogen III to coproporphyrinogen III is deficient leading to increase in Uroporphyrin levels also appears in urine.

Reference: Biochemistry - Lippincott's Illustrated Review, Chapter 26, Page 419-420

questions.text: A 40 year old male is brought to the emergency department after being stabbed in the chest. He is hypotensive, tachycardic, and has distended neck veins. Muffled heart sounds are noted on auscultation. What is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Cardiac Tamponade

Pathophysiology:

  • Mechanism: Accumulation of fluid in the pericardial sac leads to increased intrapericardial pressure, which compresses the heart and restricts its ability to fill during diastole.
  • Complications: If untreated, cardiac tamponade can lead to obstructive shock and death due to inadequate cardiac output.

Clinical Features:

  • Beck's Triad: Hypotension, distended neck veins, and muffled heart sounds.
  • Other Signs: Pulsus paradoxus (a drop in systolic blood pressure >10 mmHg during inspiration), tachycardia, and signs of shock.

Diagnosis:

  • Clinical Diagnosis: Based on physical examination findings.
  • Echocardiogram: The gold standard for diagnosing cardiac tamponade, as it can visualise fluid in the pericardial sac and assess its impact on cardiac function.

Management:

  • Pericardiocentesis: Immediate needle aspiration of the pericardial fluid to relieve pressure on the heart.
  • Surgical Management: In cases of myocardial trauma, thoracotomy may be needed if pericardiocentesis is ineffective or if there is ongoing bleeding.

Option A : While a chest Xray can show an enlarged cardiac silhouette, it is not the first step in an emergency situation.

Option B : Pericardiocentesis is the lifesaving procedure to relieve pressure on the heart in cases of cardiac tamponade.

Option C : Thoracotomy may be required in certain situations but is not the first line treatment for cardiac tamponade.

Option D : While IV fluids can temporarily support blood pressure, they do not address the underlying issue of tamponade.

Key Takeaways:

  • Cardiac tamponade is a life threatening condition requiring urgent pericardiocentesis to prevent cardiovascular collapse.
  • Recognition of Beck's Triad of Muffled Heart Sound, Distended Neck veins & Hypotension and rapid intervention are critical for patient survival.
  • Pericardiocentesis is Contraindicated in penetrating trauma.

Tags :

Topic: Cardiac Tamponade - Diagnosis and Management

Difficulty Level: Good to Know

PYQ : NEET 2022 | FMGE Aug 2020 FMGE Dec 2021

Reference: Bailey and Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Chapter 29 , pages - 374.

questions.text: A 60 year old male presents with abdominal pain, weight loss, and hepatomegaly. Imaging studies reveal a large, heterogeneous liver mass. Biopsy confirms Hepatic Angiosarcoma. All of the following exposures are associated with this except?
questions.solution:
Hepatic angiosarcoma is a rare and aggressive primary malignant tumor of the liver that originates from endothelial cells lining blood vessels.

Several environmental and chemical exposures have been associated with an increased risk:

  1. Thorium dioxide (Thorotrast): Historically used as a contrast agent in radiology, it has been linked to a high incidence of hepatic angiosarcoma.
  2. Vinyl chloride: A chemical used in the production of plastics has been strongly associated with hepatic angiosarcoma.
  3. Arsenic: Chronic exposure to arsenic has been implicated in the development of hepatic angiosarcoma.
  4. Anabolic steroids: Long-term use of anabolic steroids may increase the risk.
  5. Hemochromatosis: Some reports suggest an association between hepatic angiosarcoma and hereditary hemochromatosis, a condition characterized by excess iron storage in the liver.

KEY TAKEAWAYS - Hepatic Angiosarcoma is a rare, aggressive liver cancer often associated with variety of carcinogenic exposures including Arsenic(A), Thorotrast(B) and poly vinyl chloride(D).

Iron does not have any role in causing hepatic angiosarcoma.

Reference: Robbins & Cotran, 10th edition, Page no. 522.

choices.text: It increases the risk of renal cell carcinoma.
It causes frequent urinary tract infections.
It typically results in renal failure by the age of 50.

questions.text: A 45 year old male is incidentally diagnosed with a horseshoe kidney during an abdominal ultrasound for unrelated reasons. Which statement is true regarding this condition?
questions.solution:
Horseshoe Kidney

  • Horseshoe Kidney: A congenital condition where the lower poles of the kidneys are fused, typically located lower in the abdomen.
  • The isthmus lies at the level of the fourth to fifth lumbar vertebrae (fused lower poles). This causes failure to ascend and rotate so that the renal pelvis faces anteriorly and vertically with the malrotated calyces pointing posteromedially.
  • Prevalence:
    • Occurs in about 1 in 400 individuals, more common in males.
  • Complications:
    • Increased risk of UTIs, kidney stones, and hydronephrosis due to altered renal drainage and urinary stasis.
    • Associated with Turner syndrome
  • Management:
    • Often conservative, focusing on managing UTIs and monitoring kidney function.
    • Surgical intervention is rare.

Option A : It increases the risk of renal cell carcinoma is Incorrect. Horseshoe kidney has a slight increase in the risk of certain tumours(wilm's tumor), but renal cell carcinoma is not significantly higher.

Option B : It is associated with hypertension is Incorrect. While renal anomalies can affect blood pressure, horseshoe kidney is not strongly associated with hypertension.

Option C : It causes frequent urinary tract infections is Correct. Horseshoe kidneys are prone to urinary stasis and reflux, leading to a higher incidence of UTIs.

Option D : It typically results in renal failure by the age of 50 is Incorrect. Most individuals with a horseshoe kidney have normal renal function unless complicated by other conditions.

Key Takeaway:

  • Horseshoe kidney increases the risk of urinary tract infections.
  • Most individuals maintain normal renal function throughout life.

Tags :

Topic: Horseshoe Kidney

Difficulty Level: Good to Know

PYQ : FMGE Jan 2023

Reference: Bailey and Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Chapter 82, Pages 1467

choices.text: To allow damaged cells to repair DNA
To permit cells to enter quiescence
To regulate cell growth and division

questions.text: What is the primary function of the G1 checkpoint in the cell cycle?
questions.solution:
The G1 checkpoint ensures that a cell is ready to enter the S phase of the cell cycle by checking:

  1. Cell Size: Ensures the cell has grown enough to divide.
  2. DNA Integrity: Detects and repairs DNA damage or triggers apoptosis if the damage is irreparable.
  3. Nutrient Availability: Confirms sufficient nutrients and energy are present.
  4. Growth Signals: Responds to external growth factors needed for division.
  5. Quiescence Decision: Determines whether to proceed or enter a resting state (G0).

Key regulators include p53 (DNA damage response), Cyclins/CDKs, and Retinoblastoma (Rb). If conditions are favorable, the cell moves into the S phase for DNA replication.

Explanation:

  1. The G1 checkpoint ensures that cells are ready to enter the S phase and undergo DNA replication by checking for proper cell growth and division.
  2. G2 checkpoint allows damaged cells to repair DNA.
  3. Chromosome segregation occurs during mitosis.
  4. Quiescence is a state of dormancy that can occur outside of the cell cycle.

KEY TAKEAWAYS - The G1 checkpoint ensures that cells are ready to enter the S phase and undergo DNA replication by checking for proper cell growth and division.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran, 10th edition, Page no. 2

questions.text: All of the following arteries form circle of Willis except
questions.solution:
Circle of Willis (Circulus Arteriosus): It is six sided polygonal of arteries formed at base of brain by branches of basilar and internal carotid arteries.

It is formed around the interpeduncular fossa and lies in the interpeduncular cistern.

Formation of circle of Willis:

  • Anteriorly: By anterior cerebral and anterior communicating arteries
  • Posteriorly: By the basilar artery dividing into two posterior cerebral arteries
  • Laterally on each side: By posterior communicating artery connecting internal carotid artery with the posterior cerebral artery.

Option wise explanation:

Option A, C and D: arteries form circle of Willis.

Option B: Middle cerebral artery: does not form circle of Willis

Reference: Textbook of Clinical Neuroanatomy, Vishram Singh, 5th Edition, Page no. 192.

questions.text: A 40 year old male presents with right flank pain and recurrent urinary tract infections. Imaging following appearance of the proximal right ureter. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Retrocaval Ureter:
    • A congenital anomaly where the ureter passes posterior to the inferior vena cava, leading to a characteristic "fish hook" appearance.
  • Symptoms:
    • Flank pain, hematuria, recurrent UTIs due to partial ureteral obstruction.
  • Diagnosis:
    • Imaging studies such as intravenous urography or CT scan showing the path of the ureter behind the IVC.
  • Management:
    • Surgical correction to reposition the ureter anterior to the IVC to relieve obstruction.

Option A: Horseshoe kidney is Incorrect. This congenital condition results in the fusion of the kidneys but does not cause a "fish hook" appearance of the ureter.

Option B: Ureterocele is Incorrect. Ureterocele appears as a cystic dilation at the distal ureter rather than a retrocaval positioning.

Option C: Retrocaval ureter is Correct. This anomaly results in the ureter looping behind the inferior vena cava, creating a "fishhook" or "reverse J" appearance on imaging.

Option D: UPJ obstruction is Incorrect. UPJ obstruction typically presents with hydronephrosis, but not the specific retrocaval positioning seen in this case.

Key Takeaway:

  • Retrocaval ureter presents with a characteristic "fishhook" appearance on imaging.
  • Surgical repositioning is often required to relieve symptoms and prevent complications.

Tags :

Topic: Retrocaval Ureter

Difficulty Level: May Know

References: Bailey and Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Chapter 82, Pages 1468

questions.text: A 25 year old male presents with sudden, severe loin pain relieved by urination. He has a history of intermittent episodes of similar pain. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Dietl's Crisis and Ureteropelvic Junction Obstruction (PUJO)

Dietl's crisis is a severe episode of flank pain associated with ureteropelvic junction obstruction (PUJO). PUJO is a common congenital condition where the ureter is narrowed at the point where it joins the renal pelvis, leading to obstruction of urine flow.

Congenital PUJO

  • Incidence: Approximately 1 in 500 live births.
  • Causes: Intrinsic obstruction due to muscular hypoplasia, high insertion of the ureter, or crossing aberrant vessels.
  • Prevalence: More common in males and on the left side.

Presentation

  • Infants and children: Often presents with a palpable flank mass.
  • Adults: May present with back or flank pain, recurrent pyelonephritis, or Dietl's crisis.
  • Dietl's crisis: Severe flank pain following excessive fluid intake, often relieved by passing a large amount of urine.

Diagnosis

  • Isotope diuretic renography: The preferred imaging test. A rising curve following furosemide administration, a T1/2max of greater than 20 minutes, and a differential function of less than 40% on the affected side suggest significant obstruction.

Management

  • Surgical intervention: Indicated for persistent pain, hypertension, hematuria, secondary renal calculi, or recurrent UTIs.
  • Anderson-Hynes dismembered pyeloplasty: The preferred surgical procedure, involving a wide funnelled,dependent anastomosis and excision of the redundant pelvis.

Option A: Renal colic is Incorrect. While renal colic presents with severe pain, it is usually not relieved by positional changes and is caused by the passage of a stone.

Option B: Appendicitis is Incorrect. Appendicitis pain typically begins around the umbilicus and then localises to the right lower quadrant, with no relief from positional change.

Option C: Dietl's crisis is Correct. Dietl's crisis involves sudden severe pain in the loin, often associated with hydronephrosis, and is relieved by urination.

Option D: Acute cholecystitis is Incorrect. This condition causes right upper quadrant pain that does not change with movement and often radiates to the back or shoulder.

Key Takeaway:

  • Dietl's crisis is associated with urination that relieves the pain.
  • It often involves intermittent UPJ obstruction or nephroptosis.

Tags:

Topic: Congenital PUJ Crisis; Dietl's Crisis

Difficulty Level: Good to Know

PYQ: FMGE Aug 2020

References: Bailey and Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Chapter 82, Pages 1469

questions.solution:
• Alteplase is a tissue plasminogen activator drug.
  • It is potent fibrinolytic and a potent tissue plasminogen activator.
  • It acts via following mechanism
  • Heparin is a naturally occurring anticoagulant that facilitates the action of antithrombin III.
  • Chelating agents bind with the calcium and prevents clotting mechanism (dicumarol)

Reference: Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology, 26th Edition, page no. 1287, 1288

questions.text: A middle aged male undergoes spirometry for his respiratory symptoms. FEV1/FVC is 94%. Which of the following diseases should not be considered in the differential diagnosis?
questions.solution:
FEV1/FVC<80% indicates airway disease

Since the ratio is more than 80% therefore restrictive diseases should be considered in the differential diagnosis.
