choices.text: Stone Fragments in a renal stone
Multiple stone fragments in the ureter

questions.text: A 35 year old male with a history of recent extracorporeal shock wave lithotripsy (ESWL) presents with flank pain and fever. What does this indicate?
questions.solution:
Steinstrasse (Stone Street)

  • Steinstrasse refers to the alignment of multiple stone fragments in the ureter, a common complication postESWL. It can cause ureteral obstruction, leading to pain, infection, and hydronephrosis.
  • Symptoms: Flank pain, fever, and signs of urinary obstruction following ESWL.
  • Diagnosis: Imaging, typically noncontrast CT or X Ray, showing a chain of stone fragments within the ureter.
  • Management: Observation if asymptomatic, medical expulsive therapy, or intervention (ureteroscopy or additional ESWL) if symptomatic or obstructing.

Option A: Stone Fragments in Kidney is an incorrect Option. It Refers to Ureter.

Option B: Stone formation in the urethra is Incorrect. Steinstrasse refers to the ureter, not the urethra.

Option C: Multiple stone fragments in the ureter are Correct. "Steinstrasse," meaning "stone street," refers to a condition where multiple stone fragments align in the ureter following ESWL, potentially causing obstruction and symptoms.

Option D: Bilateral hydronephrosis is Incorrect. Steinstrasse is a unilateral condition affecting the ureter and does not cause bilateral hydronephrosis.

Key Takeaway:

  • Steinstrasse is a post ESWL complication characterised by stone fragments lining up in the ureter.
  • It may cause pain and obstruction, requiring medical or surgical intervention.

Tags:

Topic: Steinstrasse

Difficulty Level: Good to Know

PYQ: FMGE Jan 2023

References: Bailey and Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Chapter 82, Pages 1476

questions.text: A 45 year old female with a 1.5 cm renal stone in the lower pole of the kidney is planned for minimally invasive stone removal. What procedure is most appropriate?
questions.solution:
Retrograde Intrarenal Surgery (RIRS)

  • A minimally invasive procedure using a flexible ureteroscope inserted through the urethra to access the kidney. Stones are fragmented using laser lithotripsy.
  • Indications:
    • Stones up to 2 cm, especially in the lower pole where ESWL is less effective.
    • patients with bleeding disorders or obese patients where PCNL may be risky.
    • kyphoscoliosis
  • Advantages: Less invasive, shorter recovery time, and high success rates for lower pole stones.
  • Complications: Infection, bleeding, ureteral injury, and residual fragments.

Option A: Percutaneous nephrolithotomy (PCNL) is Incorrect. PCNL is more invasive and typically reserved for larger or complex renal stones (>2 cm).

Option B: Extracorporeal shock wave lithotripsy (ESWL) is Incorrect. ESWL is less effective for lower pole stones due to poor clearance rates.

Option C: Retrograde intrarenal surgery (RIRS) is Correct. RIRS is minimally invasive, using a flexible ureteroscope and laser lithotripsy to treat stones up to 2 cm, especially in the lower pole.

Option D: Open nephrolithotomy is Incorrect. This is an invasive procedure, reserved for cases where other methods have failed or are contraindicated.

Key Takeaway:

  • RIRS is suitable for treating renal stones up to 2 cm, particularly in the lower pole.
  • It is less invasive than PCNL and has a high success rate for stone clearance.

Tags:

Topic: Retrograde Intrarenal Surgery (RIRS)

Difficulty Level: Good to Know

PYQ: FMGE Jan 2023

References: Bailey and Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Chapter 82, Pages 1477

questions.text: A 51-year-old female visited the primary care physician clinic due to breathing problems. Doctor examined her and did spirometry. The values are tidal volume - 260 ml, vital capacity - 2600 ml, FEV1/FVC - 80%. The probable diagnosis in this patient is
questions.solution:
• There are two principle category of respiratory disorders
    1. obstructive lung disorders
    2. restrictive lung disorders
  • Here the values in the spirometry shows that this patient has reduced lung volume and capacity.
  • Tuberculosis shows the restrictive pattern in lung disorder due to fibrosis.
    • Reduced lung volumes with a normal or increased FEV1/FVC ratio
    • Especially tidal volume and vital capacity are less.
  • Other options are-type of obstructive lung disorder in which
    • FEV1/FVC ratio is usually less than 70%
    • Tidal volume and vital capacity does not reduce usually.
  • Option A) Emphysema is a form of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) characterized by damage to the alveoli (air sacs) in the lungs.
  • Option C) Chronic bronchitis is a form of COPD characterized by chronic inflammation of the bronchi, leading to mucus production, airway narrowing, and airflow obstruction.
  • Option D) cystic fibrosis (CF) is a genetic disorder that affects the exocrine glands, leading to the production of thick mucus that can obstruct the airways and lead to recurrent infections, inflammation, and lung damage.

Reference: Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology, 26th Edition, page 1436

questions.text: Tram track sign and signet ring sign is seen in which of the following clinical condition?
questions.solution:
Bronchiectasis is irreversible dilation of airways. It can be cylindrical, tubular (most common), Varicose vein or cystic.

Depending on distribution it can be focal or diffuse.

Typical radiological signs of bronchiectasis include:

  1. Tram track sign-can be seen on chest X-ray PA view but CT is more specific
  2. "signet-ring sign"-only seen on CT scan of chest and defined as a cross-sectional area of the airway with a diameter at least 1.5 times that of the adjacent vessel)
  3. Lack of bronchial tapering (including the presence of tubular structures within 1 cm from the pleural surface),
  4. Bronchial wall thickening in dilated airways, inspissated secretions (e.g., the "tree-in-bud" pattern), or cysts emanating from the bronchial wall (especially pronounced in cystic bronchiectasis)

Reference: Harrison's principle of Textbook 21st Medicine page no 2174

questions.text: Most common cardiac lesion seen in pregnancy:
questions.solution:
OPTION B: Mitral stenosis is the most common cardiac lesion in pregnancy, often due to rheumatic heart disease. Pregnancy increases blood volume and cardiac output, which can worsen symptoms of mitral stenosis, such as pulmonary congestion and atrial fibrillation, posing risks to both the mother and fetus.

OPTION A: Mitral regurgitation is relatively common in pregnancy due to increased blood volume and cardiac output, which can exacerbate existing valve insufficiency. However, it is not the most common cardiac lesion; it usually presents as a functional or physiological regurgitation without significant hemodynamic compromise.

OPTION C: Aortic stenosis is less common in pregnancy compared to mitral valve lesions. Severe cases can pose significant risks due to fixed cardiac output that cannot meet the increased demands of pregnancy, but it is not the most prevalent condition.

OPTION D: Pulmonary regurgitation is typically mild and often clinically insignificant in pregnancy. It is generally well tolerated due to the low-pressure nature of the right side of the heart, and it is far less common as a primary cardiac lesion compared to mitral stenosis.

Therefore, mitral stenosis is the most common cardiac lesion seen in pregnancy, particularly in regions where rheumatic heart disease is prevalent.

Type: Must know

Topic: Mitral stenosis

Reference: Arias' practical guide to high risk pregnancy & delivery 4th edition, Page no. 276

questions.text: The image below shows a microscopic view of a blood smear or a tissue sample showing filarial parasites. Based on the appearance and specific characteristics in the image, which parasite is depicted?
questions.solution:
It is identified by the presence of sheathed microfilariae with an undulating motion and no nuclei at the tip.


A) Correct: Wuchereria bancrofti is characterized by its sheathed microfilariae with an undulating motion, typically observed in blood samples. The sheathed structure and specific movement patterns are key identifiers.

B) Incorrect: Brugia malayi also causes lymphatic filariasis and has sheathed microfilariae, but differs in some morphologic details compared to Wuchereria bancrofti.-It has 2 nuclei at it's tip.


C) Incorrect: Onchocerca volvulus microfilariae are unsheathed and typically do not show the sheathed structure seen in Wuchereria bancrofti.

D) Incorrect: Loa loa microfilariae are larger and unsheathed, exhibiting a cork-screw motion, which is different from the sheathed microfilariae of Wuchereria bancrofti.



Key Takeaway: Wuchereria bancrofti is identified by its sheathed microfilariae and undulating motion in blood samples, which is crucial for distinguishing it from other filarial species.

Reference: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC). Filariasis. CDC Filariasis

questions.text: A 50 year old woman presents with a groin mass below the inguinal ligament that becomes more prominent with standing. You suspect a femoral hernia. Which structure forms the medial boundary of the femoral canal?
questions.solution:
Femoral Canal

  • Location: The femoral canal lies medial to the femoral vein within the femoral sheath.
  • Contents: The canal contains lymphatic vessels, a lymph node (Cloquet's node), and loose connective tissue.
  • Function: It allows the femoral vein to expand and provides a pathway for lymphatic drainage from the lower limb.
  • Boundaries:
    • Anterior: Inguinal ligament
    • Posterior: Pectineal ligament
    • Medial: Lacunar ligament
    • Lateral: Femoral vein

Explanation of Options:

Option A. Femoral vein: Incorrect. The femoral vein is located lateral to the femoral canal.

Option B. Inguinal ligament: Incorrect. The inguinal ligament forms the superior boundary of the femoral canal.

Option C. Lacunar ligament: Correct. The lacunar ligament forms the medial boundary of the femoral canal.

Option D. Pectineal ligament: Incorrect. The pectineal ligament forms the posterior boundary of the femoral canal.

Key points :

The femoral canal is the site of femoral hernias, more common in women and prone to incarceration due to its narrow structure.

Topic: Femoral Canal Anatomy

Difficulty Level: Moderate; Must know

choices.text: External cephalic version and trial of vaginal delivery
External cephalic version followed by Caesarean section

questions.text: Ideal management of 37 weeks uncomplicated breech pregnancy is:
questions.solution:
a) External cephalic version and trial of vaginal delivery

  • External cephalic version (ECV) is a procedure performed at or after 37 weeks of gestation to turn the fetus from a breech position to a cephalic (head-down) position. The goal of ECV is to enable a vaginal delivery, reducing the need for a Caesarean section. If the ECV is successful and there are no contraindications, a trial of vaginal delivery can be offered. This option is ideal as it aims to promote a vaginal birth, which has fewer risks of complications associated with surgery. However, the success rate of ECV is variable, and it requires careful monitoring.

b) External cephalic version followed by Caesarean section

  • This option is less commonly recommended because if the ECV is successful, the primary goal is to proceed with a vaginal delivery. Planning a Caesarean section after a successful ECV is contradictory, as the intent of ECV is to avoid a surgical delivery. Caesarean section would be reserved if the ECV fails or if other complications arise that necessitate surgery.

c) Spontaneous vaginal delivery

  • While some breech presentations can be delivered vaginally, it requires careful selection of cases and an experienced team. Most guidelines recommend against spontaneous vaginal breech delivery in uncomplicated cases at term because of the increased risks for both mother and fetus, such as cord prolapse, head entrapment, and traumatic injury.

d) Caesarean section straightaway

  • This option is generally preferred in term breech pregnancies to avoid the complications associated with breech vaginal deliveries. While Caesarean section provides a controlled environment to reduce risks, it is not the ideal initial management if ECV is available and there are no contraindications to attempting a vaginal delivery.

Key takeaway: The ideal management for a 37-week uncomplicated breech pregnancy would be to attempt an External Cephalic Version (ECV) followed by a trial of vaginal delivery if successful. This approach provides an opportunity to avoid surgery and promotes natural birth, assuming the ECV is successful and there are no other contraindications for vaginal delivery.

Type: Must know

Topic: Singleton Breech Delivery

Reference: Williams Obstetrics 26th edition, Page no. 1353

questions.text: A 58 year old female presents with a swelling located at the semilunar line just below the level of the umbilicus. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Spigelian Hernia

  • A rare abdominal wall hernia occurring along the Spigelian fascia, between the lateral edge of the rectus abdominis muscle and the semilunar line.
  • Location: Typically occurs in the lower abdomen below the umbilicus, lateral to the rectus sheath.
  • Epidemiology: More common in middle-aged and elderly individuals; slight female predominance.
  • Diagnosis: Clinical examination may be difficult due to the deep location; Ultrasound or CT scan is the imaging modality of choice for confirmation.
  • Complications: Incarceration and strangulation are common, due to the narrow neck of the hernia sac.
  • Treatment: Surgical repair

Explanation of Options:

Option A. Inguinal hernia: Incorrect. Inguinal hernias are located in the groin, not at the semilunar line.

Option B. Umbilical hernia: Incorrect. Umbilical hernias are located at the umbilicus, not below it.

Option C. Spigelian hernia: Correct. A Spigelian hernia occurs along the semilunar line, typically at or below the umbilicus.

Option D. Femoral hernia: Incorrect. Femoral hernias occur below the inguinal ligament.

Key points :

  • Occurs along the semilunar line, commonly below the level of the umbilicus.
  • Difficult to diagnose on clinical examination and often requires imaging.

Tags:

Topic: Spigelian Hernia

Difficulty Level: Moderate; Must know

Reference: Bailey and Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Chapter- 64 , PAGE NO. -1075

questions.text: Identify the type of pelvis shown in the image:
questions.solution:
OPTION A: Robert's pelvis is characterized by the presence of two pubic bones with both sides alae of sacrum being absent.



OPTION B: Scoliotic pelvis results from a spinal curvature condition known as scoliosis, leading to asymmetry of the pelvis but not specifically involving the sacral ala. The pelvis is often tilted or distorted due to the abnormal spinal curvature, but the sacral anatomy, such as the alae, is typically intact.

OPTION C: Rachitic pelvis is caused by rickets, a disease resulting from vitamin D deficiency, leading to softening and weakening of the bones, including pelvic bones. The pelvis is deformed with a flattened appearance, but there is no characteristic absence of one sacral ala as seen in Naegele's pelvis.

OPTION D: Naegele's pelvis is a type of oblique pelvis where one ala (wing) of the sacrum is absent or underdeveloped. This leads to asymmetry in the pelvis, which can cause difficulty during childbirth due to the altered shape of the pelvic inlet. This deformity specifically matches the description of the condition where one ala of the sacrum is absent.

Type: Must know

Topic: Abnormal pelvis

Reference: www.researchgate.com

choices.text: Stimulation of O2 sensitive K+ channels
Stimulation of ATP sensitive K+ channels
Inhibition of ligand gated calcium channels

questions.text: In response to hypoxia in systemic arteries there is vasodilatation. Which of the following channels primarily are responsible for vasodilation?
questions.solution:
• Option B - ATP-sensitive potassium channels are crucial in the vasodilatory response to hypoxia.
  • When oxygen levels are low, the decrease in ATP production leads to the opening of these channels. The opening of K+ATP channels allows potassium to efflux, causing hyper-polarization of the smooth muscle cell membrane. This hyper-polarization reduces the activity of voltage-gated calcium channels, leading to a decrease in intracellular calcium levels, which causes smooth muscle relaxation and vasodilation.
  • Option A - O2-sensitive potassium channels are found in certain tissues like the carotid body, where they play a role in sensing oxygen levels.
  • In hypoxic conditions, This reduces the K+ efflux, depolarizing the cell and causing Ca2+ influx, primarily via L-type voltage-gated Ca2+ channels. It causes vasoconstriction in pulmonary vessels.
  • Option C - Ligand-gated calcium channels are typically involved in responses triggered by specific ligands (such as neurotransmitters) binding to their receptors. It may cause vasodilatation but the primary mechanism is K+ channels.
  • Option D - The Na+ K+ ATPase pump is crucial for maintaining the electrochemical gradient across cell membranes by pumping sodium out of the cell and potassium into the cell using ATP.

Reference: Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology, 26th Edition, page no.1509

questions.text: Bartholin's gland in females is homologous to which of the following in males:
questions.solution:
The table below mentions all the homologous structures of male and female reproductive system and their origin.



OPTION A: Glands of Littre are mucus-secreting glands located along the male urethra. They are not directly related to the female reproductive system and have no homologous structure with Bartholin's gland.

OPTION B: Cowper's glands, also known as bulbourethral glands in males, are the homologous structures to Bartholin's glands in females. Both glands are responsible for secreting mucus that lubricates the respective areas: Cowper's glands secrete into the urethra, while Bartholin's glands secrete into the vaginal orifice.

OPTION C: Skene's glands also known as the paraurethral glands, are located near the female urethra and are homologous to the prostate gland in males, not to the Bartholin's glands.

OPTION D: Prostate is a male accessory sex gland that contributes to semen production. The homologous structure in females would be Skene's glands, not Bartholin's glands.

Type: Must know

Topic: Anatomy of female genital tract

Reference: Shaw's Gynaecology 17th edition, Page no. 15

questions.text: Examine the image below showing a blood smear. What is the most likely parasite shown in the image?
questions.solution:
Plasmodium vivax is one of the five species of malaria parasites that infect humans. It is responsible for vivax malaria, which is generally less severe than Plasmodium falciparum malaria but can still lead to significant morbidity due to its relapsing nature.

Life Cycle:

  • After a mosquito bite, sporozoites enter the bloodstream and infect liver cells, where they develop into hypnozoites(dormant forms) or continue as merozoites that invade red blood cells.
  • Hypnozoites can remain dormant in the liver for months or years and reactivate to cause relapses of malaria.

Clinical Features:

  • Causes tertian malaria, where fevers recur every 48 hours.
  • Symptoms include fever, chills, sweating, headache, nausea, and fatigue.
  • Can lead to severe anemia due to the parasite's invasion of red blood cells.
  • Relapses are common due to reactivation of hypnozoites from the liver.

Gametocytes:

  • Unlike P. falciparum, Plasmodium vivax gametocytes are round in shape, not banana-shaped.

A) Babesia microti: This parasite causes babesiosis and can be identified by the presence of ring forms, but often lacks the specific multi-ring forms or schizonts seen in the image.


B) Trypanosoma brucei: Causes African sleeping sickness and is usually found in blood as trypomastigotes, not ring forms inside red blood cells.

C) Plasmodium vivax: The image shows schizonts, which are characteristic of Plasmodium vivax, a common cause of malaria.

D) Leishmania braziliensis: Typically found in tissue samples or bone marrow smears, not in blood smears.


Key Takeaway: Plasmodium vivax is identified by ring forms and schizonts within red blood cells, which are specific to malaria diagnosis.

Reference: For further details on Plasmodium vivax and its blood smear identification, see the CDC's malaria resources: CDC - Malaria.

questions.text: Which of the following structures is not attached to the cornua of uterus?
questions.solution:
OPTION B: Infundibulopelvic ligament, also known as the suspensory ligament of the ovary, connects the ovary to the lateral pelvic wall and carries the ovarian vessels. It does not attach to the cornua of the uterus but rather to the ovary and lateral pelvic wall, which is why it is the correct answer

OPTION A: Round ligament attaches to the cornua (horn) of the uterus and extends to the labia majora through the inguinal canal. It helps in maintaining the anteverted position of the uterus.

OPTION C: Fallopian tubes are directly attached to the cornua of the uterus. They extend laterally from the cornua to the ovaries, allowing for the transport of eggs from the ovaries to the uterus.

OPTION D: Ovarian ligament attaches the ovary to the cornua of the uterus. It extends from the uterus just below the point of attachment of the fallopian tubes to the ovary



Fig: Structure attached to cornua of uterus

Key takeaway: Mnemonic to remember the structures attached to the cornua of the uterus from anterior to posterior aspect using "RTO":

RTO:

  • R - Round ligament
  • T - Tube (Fallopian tube)
  • O - Ovarian ligament

Type: Must know

Topic: Attachments to the uterus

Reference: Shaw's Gynaecology 17th edition, Page no. 21

questions.text: Examine the image of the electron microscope view provided. Which virus is depicted in the image?
questions.solution:
Shape:

  • Typically spherical or oval, with a diameter of about 80-120 nm.
  • Some strains can be pleomorphic, meaning they may vary in shape, occasionally forming filamentous structures.

Envelope:

  • The virus is enveloped, meaning it has a lipid membrane derived from the host cell.
  • Embedded in the envelope are two key surface proteins:
    • Hemagglutinin (HA): Responsible for binding to host cell receptors.
    • Neuraminidase (NA): Helps the virus to release from the host cell after replication.

Core:

  • Inside the envelope is the viral genome, made up of 8 segments of single-stranded RNA, which are associated with nucleoproteins and packaged in a helical configuration.

Surface:

  • The surface of the virus is studded with the HA and NA spikes, which give the virus its characteristic appearance and are crucial for its infectivity.

A) HIV: HIV particles are spherical but have a more irregular shape and are covered with a dense layer of glycoprotein spikes, which is different from the spiked structure seen in the image.


B) Influenza Virus: Influenza virus particles are spherical with a lipid envelope and characteristic spikes (hemagglutinin and neuraminidase), fitting the description of the image.

C) HBV: Hepatitis B virus is more spherical with a less pronounced spiked appearance and has a more complex surface structure.


D) HSV: Herpes Simplex Virus is known for its icosahedral capsid structure and does not typically exhibit the spiked envelope seen in the image.

Key Takeaway: The Influenza Virus is characterized by its spherical shape with a spiked envelope. Identifying these spikes helps in distinguishing it from other viruses.

Reference: For more information on the Influenza Virus, refer to the CDC: CDC - Influenza (Flu).

questions.text: Peg cells are found in
questions.solution:
Peg cells are a component of the epithelial lining of the fallopian tubes, where they play a crucial role in reproductive physiology. They are specialized secretory cells that produce a fluid that nourishes and supports the egg and sperm during their journey through the fallopian tube. This fluid also helps in the transport of the egg and facilitates fertilization.



Fig: Histology of Fallopian tube

Type: Must know

Topic: Fallopian tube histology

questions.text: A 45 year old male patient with a history of food poisoning presented to the emergency department with multiple episodes of vomiting, mild diarrhoea and weakness. He was given an intravenous drug to control the severity of vomiting and later he developed abnormal posture as given in the image below. Which of the following drugs can be used to treat this condition?
questions.solution:
Acute muscular dystonia :

  • Bizarre muscle spasms, mostly involving linguo-facial muscles -grimacing, tongue thrusting, torticollis, locked jaw; occurs within a few hours of a single dose or at the most during treatment with Dopaminergic antagonist therapy.
  • Here mostly Metoclopramide is given as an anti-emetic drug and as it is dopaminergic antagonist it has created acute dystonia as side effect.
  • One of the central anticholinergics, promethazine or hydroxyzine injected i.m. clears the reaction within 10-15 min.

Central anticholinergics :

  • The central anticholinergics act by reducing the unbalanced cholinergic activity in the striatum of parkinsonian patients.
  • Anticholinergics are the only drugs effective in drug (phenothiazines, other D2 antagonists) induced parkinsonism.

Option A : Levodopa, Prodrug of Dopamine is not Effective in Muscular Dystonia.

Option C : Ondansetron, 5HT3 Antagonist antiemetic is not effective in Muscular Dystonia.

Option D : Selegiline , MAO Inhibitor reduces metabolism of Monoamines but is not effective in acute muscular dystonia.

Key Takeaway :

Anticholinergics are the only drugs effective in drug induced parkinsonism.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi 8th edition, page no. 460.

questions.text: Most common site for adenocarcinoma of cervix is:
questions.solution:
OPTION C: Adenocarcinoma of the cervix commonly arises from the glandular cells of the endocervix, which produce mucus. The endocervix contains columnar epithelium, making it the primary site for adenocarcinoma

OPTION A: Transformation zone is the most common site for squamous cell carcinoma of the cervix, not adenocarcinoma. Squamous cell carcinoma arises from the squamous epithelium that undergoes metaplasia in this zone.

OPTION B: Ectocervix is covered by squamous epithelium and is not the common site for adenocarcinoma, which arises from glandular cells.

OPTION D: Equal incidence at all these sites: This option is incorrect because adenocarcinoma predominantly arises from the glandular cells of the endocervix and not equally from all areas of the cervix.

questions.text: Look at the image of the virus particle. What virus is shown?
questions.solution:
Adenovirus has an icosahedral shape, which means it is a symmetrical, 20-sided structure. The virus is non-enveloped and its capsid is made up of 252 protein subunits called capsomeres, arranged in an icosahedron.

Each vertex of the icosahedron has a fiber-like projection, called a penton, which helps the virus attach to and infect host cells.

A) HSV: Herpes Simplex Virus has an enveloped structure with an icosahedral capsid inside, but it is enveloped, not naked like the virus shown.

B) Papillomavirus: Papillomavirus is also icosahedral but is smaller and lacks the complex protein shell seen here.

C) Adenovirus: Adenovirus has a distinctive icosahedral capsid with a complex protein structure and lacks an envelope, matching the image description.

D) HPV: Human Papillomavirus (HPV) is similar to Papillomavirus, with a simpler structure compared to the image shown.

Key Takeaway: Adenovirus is characterized by its icosahedral shape with a complex protein shell, which is crucial for identifying it.

Reference: For more information on Adenovirus, refer to the CDC: CDC - Adenovirus.

choices.text: Change & Increase in in NAD / NADH ratio
Enzyme involved in Alcohol Metabolism is Metalloenzyme and Zn is required
Decrease in S. Lactate level will lead to Increase in Uric Acid Stone
Excess Intake of Alcohol Promotes Fatty Acid Oxidation

questions.text: A Chronic Alcoholic Patient presented with Grade I Fatty liver & High Triglyceride levels in blood. Metabolic derangement in this patient include
questions.solution:
Ethanol metabolism ↑ NADH/ NAD+ ratio in liver, causing:

  1. Lactic acidosis - ↑ pyruvate conversion to lactate
  2. Fasting hypoglycemia - ↓ gluconeogenesis due to ↑ conversion of OAA to malate
  3. Ketoacidosis - diversion of acetyl-CoA into ketogenesis rather than TCA cycle
  4. Hepatosteatosis - ↑ conversion of DHAP to glycerol-3-P
    • 4A ; acetyl-CoA diverges into fatty acid synthesis
    • 4B , which combines with glycerol-3-P to synthesize triglycerides

Option: B) Alcohol Metabolism in our body requires enzyme Alcohol Dehydrogenase which is Metalloenzymes and Zn is an essential component of Enzyme. Examples of other Metalloenzymes includes Carboxypeptidase A, Carbonic Anhydrase inhibitor, Adenosine Deaminase, Alkaline Phosphatase, Phospholipase C, Leucine Aminopeptidase, The Cytosolic Form of Superoxide Dismutase.

Option A) Oxidation of Ethanol by Alcohol Dehydrogenase leading to increase production of NADH which will increase NADH/NAD+ ratio & production of Acetaldehyde. Acetaldehyde is a toxic metabolite which needs to be converted into non toxic substance with Aldehyde Dehydrogenase enzyme.

Option: C) Increased (NADH)/(NAD+) ratio causes increased (lactate)/(pyruvate), resulting in hyper lactic acidemia, which decreases excretion of uric acid, aggravating gout. (S. Lactate levels are increased).

Option D) Alteration of NADH / NAD ratio, will leads to inhibition of Fatty Acid Oxidation and esterification of Fatty acid to Triacyl glyceride.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 32nd Edition, Chapter 25, Page no. 252

choices.text: Roundworm (Ascaris lumbricoides): Characterized by its large, cylindrical shape and smooth surface
Hookworm (Ancylostoma duodenale or Necator americanus): Identified by its hook-like anterior end and the presence of cutting plates or teeth
Strongyloides (Strongyloides stercoralis): Known for its small size and the presence of rhabditiform larvae with a short buccal cavity
Whipworm (Trichuris trichiura): Recognizable by its thin, whip-like anterior end and thicker posterior end

questions.text:
Identify the Parasite from the Image
The image below displays a microscopic view of a parasitic worm. Based on the visible features, which of the following correctly identifies the parasite shown?
questions.solution:
A) Incorrect: Ascaris lumbricoides (Roundworm) is large, cylindrical, and smooth, which does not match the hook-like appearance shown in the image.


B) Correct: Ancylostoma duodenale (Hookworm) features a hook-like anterior end and may have cutting plates or teeth. It has segmented eggs with blastomeres.


C) Incorrect: Strongyloides stercoralis (Strongyloides) is smaller and characterized by rhabditiform larvae with a short buccal cavity, unlike the hook-like structure.


D) Incorrect: Trichuris trichiura (Whipworm) has a thin, whip-like anterior end and thicker posterior end and barrel shaped eggs with mucus plugs.


Key Takeaway: Ancylostoma duodenale or Necator americanus (Hookworms) can be identified by their segmented appearance with blastomeres. This distinguishes them from other parasitic worms based on morphological features.

Tag Line: Hard

Reference: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC). Hookworm. CDC Hookworm

questions.text: A 28 year old man is brought to the emergency room after being found unconscious. He opens his eyes to pain, makes incomprehensible sounds, and withdraws from pain. What is his Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score?
questions.solution:
Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS):

  • Eye Opening (E):
    • E4: Spontaneous
    • E3: To speech
    • E2: To pain
    • E1: None
  • Verbal Response (V):
    • V5: Oriented
    • V4: Confused
    • V3: Inappropriate words
    • V2: Incomprehensible sounds
    • V1: None
  • Motor Response (M):
    • M6: Obeys commands
    • M5: Localizes pain
    • M4: Withdraws from pain
    • M3: Flexion (decorticate posture)
    • M2: Extension (decerebrate posture)
    • M1: None

Option A : 8: The GCS score is calculated as follows: Eye Opening (E2), Verbal Response (V2), and Motor Response (M4).

Option B : Score 9 This would require a higher verbal or motor response.

Option C : Score 10 A GCS of 10 suggests better responsiveness.

Option D : Score 11 Requires an even higher level of response.

Key Takeaways:

  • GCS 8 indicates severe brain injury, often requiring immediate medical intervention.
  • GCS is essential for assessing consciousness and determining the need for further neurological evaluation.

Tags :

Topic: Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS)

Difficulty Level: Must Know

PYQ : NEET 2023, FMGE June 2021

choices.text: Type I Mirizzi's syndrome; laparoscopic cholecystectomy
Type II Mirizzi's syndrome; ERCP with stent placement
Type III Mirizzi's syndrome; open cholecystectomy with common bile duct exploration
Type IV Mirizzi's syndrome; liver resection

questions.text: A 65 year old patient presents with jaundice, right upper quadrant pain, and fever. Imaging reveals a large gallstone impacted in the cystic duct, common bile duct with large fistula formation. Which classification and treatment option are most appropriate?
questions.solution:
Mirizzi's Syndrome - Classification and Treatment

  • Gallstone impaction in the cystic duct or gallbladder neck, causing common hepatic duct compression.
  • Classification:
    • Type I: External compression without fistula.
    • Type II: Small cholecystobiliary fistula.
    • Type III: Large cholecystobiliary fistula (>2 cm).
    • Type IV: Complete destruction of the common bile duct wall.
  • Clinical Presentation:
    • Jaundice, right upper quadrant pain, fever.
    • May present with cholangitis.
  • Diagnosis:
    • Imaging: Ultrasound, MRCP, or ERCP shows gallstone and ductal compression.
    • ERCP: Confirms fistula presence and location.
  • Management:
    • Type I: Laparoscopic cholecystectomy.
    • Type II-IV: Open cholecystectomy, bile duct exploration, and repair. May require biliary drainage procedures.

Explanation of Options:

Option A. Type I Mirizzi's syndrome; laparoscopic cholecystectomy: Incorrect. Type I involves external compression without fistula formation, managed laparoscopically, but this case involves a fistula.

Option B. Type II Mirizzi's syndrome; ERCP with stent placement: Incorrect. ERCP may aid diagnosis, but surgery is often needed for fistulas.

Option C. Type III Mirizzi's syndrome; open cholecystectomy with common bile duct exploration: Correct. Type III involves a large fistula and partial cholecystobiliary fistula, requiring open surgery for safe management.

Option D. Type IV Mirizzi's syndrome; liver resection: Incorrect. Liver resection is not a standard treatment for Mirizzi's syndrome.

Key Points:

  • Mirizzi's syndrome involves cystic duct gallstones compressing the common hepatic duct.

Tags:

Topic: Mirizzi's Syndrome - Classification and Treatment

Difficulty Level: May Know

PYQ: FMGE DEC 2020

References: Sabiston textbook of surgery 21th edition, Chapter 55, Page no. -1502

questions.text: A 40 year old male visited to hospital with complaint of difficulty in lifting his left arm above head. He had lifted a heavy table a few days ago. On examination, his left scapular border became prominent, when asked to push against the wall. Which of the following nerve is most likely to damage?

Long thoracic nerve: That supply serratus anterior muscle. It cause over head abduction and protraction of scapula. So damage to long thoracic nerve lead to paralysis of serratus anterior muscle. The condition is called winging of scapula.

Option C: Ulnar nerve: supply flexor carpi ulnaris and hand muscle. so not related to lifting arm above head.

Option D: Thoracodorsal nerve: supply latissimus dorsi muscle that adduct and medial rotate the upper limb and extension.

questions.text: A 5 year old child presents with jaundice, right upper quadrant pain, and a palpable abdominal mass. Imaging reveals a cystic dilation of the common bile duct. What is the most appropriate classification and treatment?
questions.solution:
Choledochal Cyst : Todani Classification and Treatment

  1. Type I:
    • Fusiform dilation of the CBD.
    • Most common type.
    • Treatment: Excision and hepaticojejunostomy.
  2. Type II:
    • CBD diverticulum.
    • Treatment: Excision of the diverticulum.
  3. Type III:
    • Choledochocele, dilation at the duodenum.
    • Treatment: Endoscopic sphincterotomy.
  4. Type IV:
    • Multiple cysts, both intrahepatic and extrahepatic.
    • Treatment: Cyst excision and biliary reconstruction.
  5. Type V:
    • Caroli's disease (intrahepatic cysts).
    • Treatment: Varies, may include liver transplant in severe cases.

Key Points:

  • Choledochal cysts present with jaundice, pain, and mass.

questions.text: A 55 year old male presents with right upper quadrant pain, jaundice, and fever with chills. Physical examination shows hypotension and confusion. What do these findings suggest?
questions.solution:
Charcot's Triad and Reynold's Pentad

  1. Charcot's Triad:
    • Right upper quadrant pain, fever with chills, jaundice.
    • Classic sign of acute cholangitis.
  2. Reynold's Pentad:
    • Charcot's triad plus hypotension and altered mental status.
    • Indicates severe cholangitis with systemic sepsis.
  3. Clinical Significance:
    • Suggests biliary tract infection, often due to bile duct obstruction.Can lead to septic shock if untreated.

Explanation of Options:

Option A. Acute pancreatitis: Incorrect. Acute pancreatitis presents with severe epigastric pain radiating to the back but does not typically cause jaundice or fever.

Option B. Biliary colic: Incorrect. Biliary colic involves intermittent pain without systemic signs like fever or hypotension.

Option C. Acute cholangitis with sepsis: Correct. Charcot's triad (fever, jaundice, right upper quadrant pain) plus hypotension and confusion (Reynold's pentad) indicate acute cholangitis with sepsis.

Option D. Gallstone ileus: Incorrect. This condition causes intestinal obstruction, not jaundice and fever.

Key Points:

Charcot's triad indicates acute cholangitis; Reynold's pentad suggests severe sepsis.

questions.text: You are seeing a 2-year-old boy with hemoglobin SS disease for routine health care in your primary care practice. His mother is 7 months pregnant with the couple's second child. They know that there is a risk that the newborn will also have sickle cell disease, but they declined prenatal diagnostic procedures because of the risk to the fetus. They ask how soon after birth the diagnosis of sickle cell disease can be made. Of the following, the MOST appropriate answer to their question is
questions.solution:
• Newborns have a predominance of hemoglobin F (fetal hemoglobin, α2γ2) at birth and a minor expression of hemoglobin A (adult hemoglobin, α2β2).
  • Abnormal hemoglobin can be detected from a neonatal blood spot; thus, sickle cell disease can be diagnosed in the newborn.
  • Newborn screening results are reported as FA for newborns with normal hemoglobin, FS for newborns with hemoglobin SS disease, and FAS for newborns with sickle cell trait.

questions.text: A 5-day-old, full-term male infant was severely cyanotic at birth. Prostaglandin E was administered initially and later ballooned atrial septostomy was done which showed improvement in oxygenation. The most likely diagnosis of this infant is
questions.solution:
• Cyanosis at birth, PGE infusion and atrial septostomy to improve oxygen are typical of TGA.
  • In complete transposition of great vessels, there are independent systemic and pulmonary circulation with communication only through ductus arteriosus. Hence, patency of ductus arteriosus is to be maintained to ensure mixing of blood. Due to deoxygenated blood flowing in the systemic circulation, moderate to severe cyanosis is present at birth.
  • As a part of rescue therapy initially, atrial septostomy to ensure mixing of blood.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents with cyclical mastalgia that has been worsening over the past few months, especially just before her periods. She has no palpable lumps on breast examination and her imaging studies are normal. What is the first-line treatment for this condition?
questions.solution:
Mastalgia

  • Cyclical Mastalgia:
    • Pain related to the menstrual cycle, generally starting mid-cycle and increasing in severity until menstruation. Both breasts are usually involved.
    • Hormonal sensitivity, possibly due to estrogen.
  • Non-Cyclical Mastalgia:
    • Unrelated to the menstrual cycle, localized to a specific region of the breast. Causes include duct ectasia, trauma, and musculoskeletal pain.
    • causes:Trauma, infections, musculoskeletal causes (e.g., Tietze's syndrome), and occasionally malignancy
  • Management:
    • First-line: Reassurance, lifestyle modifications, supportive bras, and reducing caffeine intake.
    • Medical Treatment: Tamoxifen 10 mg or Danazol 50-300 mg for severe cases.
    • Topical NSAIDs: For localized breast pain, topical diclofenac or piroxicam may be used.

Option A) Oral contraceptives - Incorrect. Oral contraceptives are not the first-line treatment for mastalgia, particularly cyclical mastalgia.

Option B) Tamoxifen 10 mg daily - Incorrect. Tamoxifen is used for severe cases of mastalgia but not as the first-line treatment.

Option C) Reassurance and lifestyle modification - Correct. Most cases of cyclical mastalgia are benign, and reassurance along with lifestyle changes such as reducing caffeine and using supportive bras is recommended.

Option D) Immediate biopsy - Incorrect. Mastalgia without concerning features on examination or imaging does not require a biopsy.

Key Points:

  • Cyclical mastalgia responds well to reassurance and lifestyle modifications. Severe cases may require treatment with tamoxifen or danazol.

questions.text: A healthy term baby girl is born via elective cesarean delivery due to breech presentation. On physical exam, when abducting and rotating the infant's legs you hear a "clunk" on the left hip. What is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
• Developmental dysplasia of the hip (DDH) is a condition at birth in which the femoral head and the acetabulum are misaligned or grow abnormally.
  • If not detected early, the hip joint will grow abnormally resulting in degenerative joint disease, impaired walking, chronic pain, or permanent disability.
  • Currently, the guidelines for screening are serial physical examinations up to one year of age using the Barlow and Ortolani maneuvers and ultrasonography.
  • The Barlow exam is done by adducting a flexed hip, and the Ortolani is performed by abducting a flexed hip. Both exams are done to identify a dislocatable hip.
  • A positive Ortolani or Barlow indicates the need for further investigation with ultrasonography.
  • Treatment of DDH varies depending on the age of discovery and severity.
  • The Pavlik method is a common nonsurgical method that positions the baby’s hip in a way that the joints align and the baby can grow normally.
  • Surgical interventions are reserved for more severe cases, late diagnosis, or failed nonsurgical treatment.

Reference: Avery’s diseases of the newborn, 1st SA ed., pg. 1438

questions.text: A 32-year-old pregnant woman presents with severe lower abdominal pain and fever. She is diagnosed with red degeneration of a fibroid. What is the most likely pathophysiological process involved?
questions.solution:
Red degeneration is due to necrosis of the fibroid tissue caused by compromised blood supply, leading to hemorrhagic infarction.

OPTION a) Infection of the fibroid: Infection of a fibroid, while it can occur, is not typically associated with red degeneration. Red degeneration is more related to the changes in the fibroid's blood supply rather than an infection.

OPTION b) Necrosis due to compromised blood supply: Red degeneration, also known as caseous degeneration, occurs when a fibroid undergoes necrosis due to reduced or compromised blood supply. During pregnancy, fibroids can grow rapidly and outstrip their blood supply, leading to hemorrhage and necrosis, which results in the characteristic pain and fever.There is leukocytosis and raised ESR.(Differentiated from torsion of fibroid where WBC count and ESR is normal).

OPTION c) Malignant transformation: While fibroids can sometimes undergo malignant transformation, this is rare and not typically associated with red degeneration. Red degeneration is related to changes in blood supply rather than malignancy.

OPTION d) Calcification of the fibroid: Calcification of fibroids usually occurs over a longer period and is not associated with acute symptoms like severe pain and fever. It is a late change rather than an acute one.

Note: The most common degeneration in fibroid is hyaline degeneration whereas the least common is malignancy.

Type: Must know

Topic: Secondary changes in fibroid

Reference: Shaw’s Gynaecology 17th edition, Page no. 159

choices.text: No further action required if asymptomatic

questions.text: A 55-year-old female undergoes a mammogram as part of her routine screening. The report indicates a BI-RADS 4b category lesion. What is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Option A) Routine annual screening - Incorrect. BI-RADS 4 lesions suggest suspicion for malignancy, and follow-up with just annual screening would not be appropriate.

Option B) Biopsy - Correct. BI-RADS 4 lesions indicate a moderate to high suspicion of malignancy, particularly 4b (10-50% malignancy risk), necessitating biopsy to confirm the diagnosis.

Option C) Follow-up imaging in 6 months - Incorrect. This option is appropriate for BI-RADS 3, which indicates "probably benign" findings.

Option D) No further action required if asymptomatic - Incorrect. Action must be taken based on radiological findings, not just the presence or absence of symptoms.

BI-RADS Score

Key Points:

  • BI-RADS 3: Short-term follow-up.
  • BI-RADS 4-6: Requires biopsy for definitive diagnosis.

questions.text: Below diagram shows the potential occurring in the pacemaker of the heart. The marked phase is depolarization phase in the potential. It occurs due to which type of channels from the following?
questions.solution:
The potential generated by the pacemakers in the heart (SA node, primarily) is known as pacemaker potential.

Occurs in the SA and AV nodes:

  • Phase 0 = upstroke-opening of voltage-gated L type Ca2+
  • Phases 1 and 2 are absent in pacemaker potential.
  • Phase 3 = repolarization-inactivation of the Ca2+ channels and ↑ activation of K+ channels ↑↑ K+ efflux
  • Phase 4 = slow spontaneous diastolic depolarization due to If ("funny current") and T type ca2+ If (funny current) channels responsible for a slow, mixed Na+ inward/K+ outward current.
  • The slope of phase 4 in the SA node determines HR (heart rate)
    1. ACh/adenosine ↓ the rate of diastolic depolarization and ↓ HR,
    2. catecholamines ↑ depolarization and ↑ HR

Image of Pacemaker potential:

  • Option a & option d: The Na+ and K+ channels activated following hyperpolarization. They are leaky channels and referred to as "If" channels. Because of this funny activation these channels are known as "f" channels.
  • Option c: The Ca2+ current (ICa) due to opening of T channels completes the prepotential.
  • Option b: The Ca2+ current (ICa) due to opening of L channels causes the depolarization.

References: Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology, 26th Edition, fig 29-2, page no. 1183

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common cause of abnormal uterine bleeding in a reproductive-aged woman?
questions.solution:
Uterine fibroids are the most common cause of abnormal uterine bleeding in women of reproductive age, especially those with heavy menstrual bleeding.

Fig: FIGO classification of AUB.

OPTION a) Endometrial cancer: While endometrial cancer can cause abnormal uterine bleeding, it is relatively rare compared to other causes, especially in premenopausal women.

OPTION b) Polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS): PCOS is a common cause of abnormal uterine bleeding in reproductive-aged women due to hormonal imbalances that can lead to irregular or absent menstrual periods. However, it is less common than uterine fibroids.

OPTION c) Uterine fibroids: Uterine fibroids, or leiomyomas, are the most common cause of abnormal uterine bleeding in reproductive-aged women. They can cause heavy menstrual bleeding, prolonged periods, or bleeding between periods.

OPTION d) Endometritis: Endometritis, an infection or inflammation of the endometrium, can cause abnormal bleeding, but it is less common compared to uterine fibroids in reproductive-aged women.

Type: Must know

Topic: Abnormal Uterine Bleeding

Reference: Shaw’s Gynaecology 17th edition, Page no. 129, 132

questions.text: HMG (Human Menopausal Gonadotropin) is a combination of:
questions.solution:
OPTION A: FSH + LH: HMG is a medication that contains a combination of Follicle-Stimulating Hormone (FSH) and Luteinizing Hormone (LH). These hormones are derived from the urine of postmenopausal women and are used to stimulate ovarian follicle development and maturation in fertility treatments.

OPTION B: FSH + HCG: Human Chorionic Gonadotropin (HCG) is often used in combination with FSH for ovulation induction, but it is not part of the HMG formulation. HCG is used to trigger ovulation after follicle development has been stimulated by FSH.

OPTION C: LH + HCG: HMG does not contain HCG. HCG is used separately, typically after follicle stimulation with FSH and LH.

OPTION D: FSH + GnRH: Gonadotropin-Releasing Hormone (GnRH) is a different type of hormone that stimulates the release of FSH and LH from the pituitary gland. It is not included in the composition of HMG.

Type: Good to know

Topic: Ovulation induction

Reference: Speroff’s Gynaecology 9th edition, Page no. 2806-2807

questions.text: What is the primary mechanism the body uses to reduce core temperature when it becomes too high?
questions.solution:
• Option A - Sweating is the body's primary mechanism for reducing core temperature. When sweat evaporates from the skin, it removes heat from the body, effectively cooling it down.
  • Option B - Vasoconstriction helps conserve heat by reducing blood flow to the skin.
  • Option C - Shivering generates heat by causing muscle contractions, which is a response to cold temperatures,
  • Option D - Increased metabolic rate would generate more heat, not reduce it.

questions.text: A 1-year-old male infant from a family with a known history of Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia Type 2B (MEN 2B) has tested positive for a specific RET mutation associated with the syndrome. There is no evidence of medullary thyroid carcinoma (MTC) on imaging, and his calcitonin levels are mildly elevated. What is the recommended next step in managing this infant?
questions.solution:
MEN Type 2A and 2B

  • MEN 2A: Associated with medullary thyroid carcinoma (MTC), pheochromocytoma, and hyperparathyroidism.
  • MEN 2B: Associated with MTC, pheochromocytoma, and mucosal neuromas, but no parathyroid disease.

RET Mutation: A genetic mutation in the RET proto-oncogene leads to the development of MEN 2 syndromes.

Surgery in MEN 2B:

  • Timing: Prophylactic thyroidectomy should be performed as soon as possible within the first year of life to prevent the development of MTC.
  • Screening: Calcitonin levels are monitored to detect early C-cell hyperplasia, but surgery is recommended before any cancer is detectable.

Surgery in MEN 2A:

  • Prophylactic thyroidectomy is recommended before 5 years of age depending on the specific RET mutation. Genetic testing and family history are crucial in determining the timing.

Explanation Of Options:

  1. Annual calcitonin screening alone is not sufficient for MEN 2B patients.
  2. In MEN 2B patients, prophylactic thyroidectomy is recommended within the first year of life due to the high risk of early-onset MTC.
  3. Waiting until 5 years old increases the risk of MTC development in MEN 2B patients, making early surgery crucial.
  4. Chemotherapy is not indicated for prophylaxis in MEN 2B; surgery is the preventive measure for medullary thyroid carcinoma.

Key Points:

MEN 2B patients should undergo prophylactic thyroidectomy within the first year of life to prevent medullary thyroid carcinoma.

Tags:

Topic: MEN Types 2A and 2B

Difficulty Level: May Know

questions.text: Most dreaded adverse effect of clomiphene citrate when used for ovulation induction?
questions.solution:
Clomiphene citrate, a SERM, predisposes to growth of multiple follicles and hence increases risk of a dreaded complication known as: Ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome(OHSS).Hence, Letrozole(Aromatase inhibitor),is currently the new drug for choice for ovulation induction as it predisposes to monofollicular development.

OPTION a. Hot flushes: This is a common but generally mild side effect of clomiphene citrate. It occurs due to the drug's effect on the hypothalamic-pituitary-ovarian axis and is not considered a severe or life-threatening complication.

OPTION b. Visual disturbances: While visual disturbances can occur due to clomiphene citrate, they are usually transient and not the most severe outcome. The drug can affect the visual field temporarily, but these disturbances are not considered the most dreaded adverse effect.

OPTION c. OHSS (Ovarian Hyperstimulation Syndrome): This is the most severe and dreaded adverse effect associated with clomiphene citrate. OHSS is characterized by enlarged ovaries, abdominal pain, ascites, and in severe cases, can lead to potentially life-threatening complications such as thromboembolism and respiratory distress. It results from excessive ovarian stimulation, making it the most significant risk associated with the medication.

Most important mediator of OHSS is VEGF.

Most important trigger for OHSS is Injection HCG.

OPTION d. Birth defects: While clomiphene citrate is generally considered safe, concerns about birth defects are not as significant compared to the risk of OHSS. Birth defects are not the most immediate or severe risk associated with this drug.

Type: Must know

Topic: Ovulation induction

Reference: Speroff's Gynaecology 9th edition, Page no. 2806-2807

questions.text: Which among the following is an example of ligand gated channel?
questions.solution:
• Option A - The Ryanodine receptor (RyR) is an example of a ligand-gated channel. It is primarily found in the sarcoplasmic reticulum of muscle cells, where it plays a crucial role in calcium release during muscle contraction.
    • The RyR is activated by calcium induced calcium release (CICR) allowing calcium ions to flow out of the sarcoplasmic reticulum into the cytoplasm.
  • Option B - The Dihydropyridine receptor (DHPR) is a voltage-gated calcium channel located in the T-tubules of skeletal and cardiac muscle cells.
  • Option c - Pressure receptor channels, such as those involved in mechano-transduction, are typically mechanosensitive channels.
    • These channels open in response to mechanical forces such as pressure, stretch, or deformation of the cell membrane.

Reference: Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology, 26th Edition, page no. 260

questions.text: Which of the following tests is most specific for diagnosing prolactinoma?
questions.solution:
OPTION C: MRI of the pituitary: It is the most specific test for diagnosing prolactinoma as it provides high-resolution images of the pituitary gland, allowing for precise identification and characterization of pituitary tumors, including their size and extent. MRI is the gold standard imaging modality for prolactinoma diagnosis.

OPTION A: Serum prolactin levels: While elevated serum prolactin levels are suggestive of prolactinoma, they are not specific. Hyperprolactinemia can also result from other conditions such as hypothyroidism, medications (e.g., antipsychotics), and pituitary stalk compression. Thus, while useful for initial screening, it does not confirm the diagnosis.

OPTION B: CT scan of the brain: CT scans can detect large pituitary tumors, but they lack the sensitivity and specificity of MRI. CT is less effective in visualizing the small microadenomas typical of prolactinomas and provides less detail of the pituitary gland and surrounding structures.

OPTION D: Serum TRH levels are not relevant to the diagnosis of prolactinoma. TRH testing is more related to the assessment of the thyroid axis and is not used in the context of prolactinoma.

Key takeaway: MRI of the pituitary is the most specific and gold standard investigation for diagnosis of Prolactinoma because it directly visualizes the tumor, confirming its presence and distinguishing it from other potential causes of elevated prolactin levels.

Type: Must know

Topic: Hyperprolactinemia

Reference: Speroff's Gynaecology 9th edition, Page no. 902

questions.text: A 19-year-old male presents with delayed puberty, anosmia, and low testosterone levels. Physical examination reveals a lack of secondary sexual characteristics. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
OPTION A: Klinefelter Syndrome is characterized by hypogonadism, small testes, gynecomastia, and tall stature. Patients usually have normal sense of smell and may show mild to moderate learning difficulties. It is associated with high FSH and LH levels and low testosterone but does not present with anosmia.

OPTION B: Kallmann Syndrome is a genetic condition characterized by hypogonadotropic hypogonadism (low levels of gonadotropins like FSH and LH) and anosmia (loss of sense of smell). It is due to a failure of GnRH neurons to migrate properly, leading to delayed or absent puberty and low testosterone levels in males, along with lack of secondary sexual characteristics. Anosmia is a distinguishing feature of this condition.

OPTION C: Turner Syndrome affects females and is characterized by short stature, ovarian dysgenesis, and a lack of sexual development. It is not associated with anosmia or low testosterone levels in males.

OPTION D: Androgen Insensitivity Syndrome (AIS) is a condition where individuals with a 46, XY karyotype are resistant to androgens. It presents with normal levels of testosterone, but due to resistance, individuals may have female external genitalia, lack male secondary sexual characteristics, and have undescended testes. Anosmia is not a feature of AIS.

Type: Must know

Topic: Disorders of pubertal development

Reference: Speroff's Gynaecology 9th edition, Page no. 782

This condition is characterized by

questions.text: Most common cause of bilateral cornual block on HSG:
questions.solution:
OPTION C: Physiological spasm of the uterotubal junction during the procedure is the most common cause of bilateral cornual block on HSG. This spasm is transient and can be relieved with antispasmodic agents, showing normal tube patency on repeat HSG.

OPTION A: Gonococcal infection can cause pelvic inflammatory disease (PID) leading to scarring and blockage of the fallopian tubes. However, it usually causes a more irregular, dilated tubal appearance rather than a cornual block on HSG.

OPTION B: Tuberculosis of the genital tract can cause bilateral tubal blockage, often with beading or clubbing of the tubes. While TB can cause cornual block, it is not the most common cause and usually presents with additional findings such as endometrial calcifications.

OPTION D: Asherman's syndrome involves intrauterine adhesions, which can lead to blockage, but it typically affects the uterine cavity rather than causing a cornual block of the fallopian tubes specifically.


Type: Must know

Topic: Interpretation of HSG

questions.text: A child Presented with multiple fragile bone also known as Brittle Bone Disease. On Examination, Child has thin transparent sclera which appears blue. He had mutation in COLIA1 gene. Identify the most common inheritance of disorder from which a child is suffering.
questions.solution:
Child is suffering from Collagen vascular Disease - Osteogenesis Imperfecta.

Characteristic Symptoms and signs of disease includes

  • Multiple Fragile bones,
  • Joint Hypermobility and
  • Blue sclera

COLIA1 or COLIA2 Gene mutation. Most commonly it is autosomal dominant.

  • Types I to IV are caused by mutations in the COL1A1 or COL1A2 genes or both.
  • Type I is mild, but type II is severe and infants born with the condition usually not survive,
  • Types III and IV are progressive and/or deforming.
  • Mutation results into replacement of Glycine affecting formation of Tripple Helix, decreased expression of Collagen, structurally abnormal, weakening of Bone, enzymatic Degradation called as Procollagen Suicide.

Collagen Vascular Diseases having Autosomal Dominant inheritance includes

  • Osteogenesis Imperfecta,
  • Marfan's Syndrome,
  • Ehler Danlos Syndrome.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 32nd Edition, Chapter 50, Page no. 614
