questions.text: Most common site of ureteric injury during hysterectomy:
questions.solution:
OPTION B: The ureter is most commonly injured at the point where it crosses under the uterine artery, which is often referred to as the "water under the bridge" location. This is because the ureter lies just beneath the uterine artery at the level of the cardinal ligament, making it vulnerable during dissection, clamping, or suturing in this area.

OPTION A: At the pelvic brim: The ureter can be vulnerable at the pelvic brim where it crosses the common iliac vessels. However, this is not the most common site for injury during hysterectomy.

OPTION C: At the level of the uterosacral ligament: While the ureter runs close to the uterosacral ligament, injury at this site is less common compared to near the uterine artery.

OPTION D: Vesicoureteric junction is not commonly injured during hysterectomy, as it is located lower in the pelvis and away from the surgical field unless bladder dissection is performed.

Key takeaway: Ureteral injury can also occur near other pelvic structures, but the crossing of the uterine artery is the most frequent site due to its close anatomical proximity to surgical maneuvers performed during hysterectomy.

Above figure shows the various points of constriction of the ureter and the probable points of injury.

Various points at which ureter is prone to injury in gynaecological surgery:

  1. At the pelvic brim, while clamping the ovarian vessels
  2. In the broad ligament while clamping the uterine vessels
  3. In the ureteric tunnel in cardinal ligament
  4. At the vault of the vagina before it enters the bladder

Type: Must know

Topic: Ureteric injury in Gynaecological surgeries

Reference: Williams Gynaecology 3rd edition, Page no. 868-869

questions.text: A 24 year old woman presents with a fluctuant non-tender swelling at the introitus. The attending Gynaecologist makes the diagnosis of a Bartholin's cyst. Which of the following is the most appropriate management?
questions.solution:
OPTION A: Marsupialization is the preferred treatment for a Bartholin's cyst, especially if it's recurrent or symptomatic. This procedure involves creating a permanent opening to facilitate continuous drainage, reducing the risk of recurrence.

OPTION B Incision & Drainage is generally used for acutely infected Bartholin's abscess rather than a cyst. This method may provide temporary relief but has a high recurrence rate and is not ideal for cyst management.

OPTION C: Aspiration is rarely used for Bartholin's cyst as it often results in recurrence due to incomplete drainage and closure of the cyst's duct. It is not a definitive treatment.

OPTION D: Surgical Resection of the Bartholin gland is a more invasive option and is typically reserved for cases where other treatments have failed or if there is suspicion of malignancy. It is not the first-line treatment due to its associated risks and complications.

Key takeaway: Marsupialization offers a balance between effective, less invasive management and a lower recurrence rate, making it the best choice for symptomatic Bartholin's cyst.

Type: Must know

Topic: Bartholin's cyst

Reference: Shaw's Gynaecology 17th edition, Page no. 320

choices.text: Referral to an ENT specialist for a throat biopsy
Administration of oral corticosteroids for inflammation

questions.text: A 7-year-old child is brought to the emergency department with a history of sore throat, fever, and a grayish membrane observed on the back of the throat. The child has also been experiencing difficulty swallowing and breathing. The parents report that the child's immunizations are not up-to-date. Based on the clinical presentation and CDC guidelines, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Diphtheria is a potentially life-threatening bacterial infection caused by Corynebacterium diphtheriae, affecting the respiratory tract and sometimes the skin.


Pharyngeal or Tonsillar Diphtheria (Most Common Form):

  • Pseudomembrane:
    • Grayish-white or dirty-gray membrane forms on the tonsils, pharynx, or nasal passages.
    • Firmly adherent, and attempts to remove it may cause bleeding.
    • It can extend to the larynx, trachea, or bronchi, leading to airway obstruction.
    • Bull neck appearance: Severe cases may show lymphadenopathy and swelling of the neck due to regional inflammation.
    • Hoarseness and stridor: May develop as the disease progresses, indicating laryngeal involvement.
    • Dysphagia: Difficulty swallowing due to throat and neck swelling.
  • Cutaneous Diphtheria:
    • Chronic non-healing ulcers:
      • Infected wounds or skin lesions develop ulcers covered with a grayish membrane.
      • Most commonly seen in tropical regions or in people with poor hygiene.
    • Typically, less severe than respiratory diphtheria but still contagious.
  • Systemic Complications (Due to Toxin Spread):
    • Cardiac Complications:
      • Myocarditis: Can occur in the second or third week of illness.
        • Symptoms include arrhythmias, heart block, and heart failure.
        • Can lead to sudden death in severe cases.
  • Neurological Complications:
    • Cranial nerve palsies: Usually affects the soft palate, causing dysphonia(difficulty speaking) or dysphagia (difficulty swallowing).
    • Peripheral neuropathy: Occurs several weeks after the onset of diphtheria.
      • Involves motor weaknessor paralysis starting in the lower extremities, progressing in a pattern similar to Guillain-Barré syndrome.

Treatment:

The antitoxin is administered intravenously or intramuscularly as soon as the disease is suspected, without waiting for laboratory confirmation.

  • Perform a skin test before administration to rule out hypersensitivity to the antitoxin.

Dose: Depends on the severity and duration of the disease, ranging from 20,000 to 100,000 units.

First-line antibiotics:

  • Erythromycin: 40-50 mg/kg/day (maximum 2 g/day) for 14 days, orally or intravenously.
  • Penicillin G: 250,000 to 500,000 units intramuscularly every 6 hours for 14 days (alternatively, penicillin V can be used orally).

A) Immediate initiation of broad-spectrum antibiotics: Incorrect. While antibiotics such as penicillin or erythromycin are important for treating diphtheria, the immediate and critical step in the management of diphtheria, especially with the presentation of a grayish membrane, is the administration of diphtheria antitoxin to neutralize the toxin. Antibiotics are then used to eradicate the bacteria.

B) Immediate administration of diphtheria antitoxin: Correct. The administration of diphtheria antitoxin is essential to neutralize the diphtheria toxin and prevent severe complications. This should be done as soon as diphtheria is suspected, according to CDC guidelines. Antibiotic therapy should also be started concurrently.

C) Referral to an ENT specialist for a throat biopsy: Incorrect. While a throat biopsy might be necessary in some cases to confirm the diagnosis, the immediate management of suspected diphtheria should focus on the administration of diphtheria antitoxin and antibiotics. Delays in treatment can lead to serious complications.

D) Administration of oral corticosteroids for inflammation: Incorrect. Corticosteroids are not indicated for the treatment of diphtheria. The primary treatment includes diphtheria antitoxin and antibiotics to address the bacterial infection and neutralize the toxin.

Key Takeaway: The immediate administration of diphtheria antitoxin is crucial in the management of diphtheria to neutralize the diphtheria toxin. Antibiotic therapy should follow to treat the bacterial infection.

Reference: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC). Diphtheria Treatment Guidelines. CDC Diphtheria Treatment

questions.text: A 7-year-old girl is taken for a health check-up as her parents feel she is too short. Her height is less than the 3rd centile and she has nonpitting edema of both lower limbs. Her blood pressure is 130/92mmHg in both upper limbs and a radio-femoral delay is noted on simultaneous palpation of pulses. What additional finding do you expect on general examination of this girl?
questions.solution:
• The patient in the scenario has short stature, hypertension, and findings consistent with bicuspid aortic valves and coarctation of the aorta.
  • Both bicuspid aortic valves and coarctation of the aorta are common among individuals with Turner syndrome.
  • Bicuspid aortic valves occur in up to 50% of patients with Turner syndrome while coarctation of aorta occurs in up to 20% of cases.
  • Physical findings in patients with Turner syndrome include nonpitting edema of the lower extremities, down slanting eyes, wide spaced nipples, and webbing of neck.

Reference: Nelson textbook of pediatrics, 21st ed., pg. 3002

questions.text: Mishika had her first birthday party recently. During her party she was able to commando crawl with ease and could stand independently. She picked up all the gems from her cake. She could speak monosyllables. She waved goodbye to her guests. Which domain of Mishika's development is delayed?
questions.solution:
MILESTONE at 1 YEAR

  • Gross Motor: Creeping, walks but falls, stands without support
  • Fine motor: Mature pincer grasp
  • Social: Comes when called, plays simple ball game
  • Language: 1-2 words with meaning; (Monosyllables are achieved at 6 months)

Reference: Essential Pediatrics, O.P Ghai, 8th edition, pg-50

choices.text: The cholera toxin is a protease that degrades mucosal proteins, leading to fluid loss
The cholera toxin causes prolonged activation of adenylate cyclase, increasing intracellular cAMP levels and resulting in electrolyte and water secretion
The cholera toxin inhibits the sodium-potassium ATPase pump, resulting in decreased absorption of fluids
The cholera toxin disrupts the tight junctions between intestinal epithelial cells, leading to leakage of plasma into the intestinal lumen

questions.text: In the context of cholera, which of the following statements accurately describes the role of the cholera toxin in the pathogenesis of the disease?
questions.solution:
1. Binding: The B subunit of cholera toxin binds to GM1 ganglioside receptors on intestinal epithelial cells.
  2. Entry: The toxin is internalized into the cell and transported to the endoplasmic reticulum.
  3. Activation: The A subunit is cleaved, and the A1 fragment enters the cytoplasm, acting as an enzyme.
  4. ADP-Ribosylation: A1 modifies the Gsα protein, leading to constant activation of adenylate cyclase.
  5. Increased cAMP: Adenylate cyclase converts ATP to cyclic AMP (cAMP), increasing intracellular cAMP levels.
  6. Chloride Secretion: cAMP activates CFTR chloride channels, causing secretion of chloride ions into the intestinal lumen.
  7. Water Loss: Sodium and water follow chloride into the lumen, resulting in massive fluid loss and watery diarrhea.

  • A) The cholera toxin is a protease that degrades mucosal proteins, leading to fluid loss.
    • The cholera toxin is not a protease and does not directly degrade mucosal proteins. Its mechanism involves the activation of cellular signaling pathways.
  • B) The cholera toxin causes prolonged activation of adenylate cyclase, increasing intracellular cAMP levels and resulting in electrolyte and water secretion.
    • The cholera toxin binds to the Gs protein, leading to the persistent activation of adenylate cyclase. This results in elevated intracellular cAMP levels, which subsequently cause the intestinal epithelial cells to secrete excessive amounts of electrolytes and water into the lumen, leading to diarrhea.
  • C) The cholera toxin inhibits the sodium-potassium ATPase pump, resulting in decreased absorption of fluids.
    • The cholera toxin does not inhibit the sodium-potassium ATPase pump. Instead, it affects fluid secretion by increasing cAMP levels.
  • D) The cholera toxin disrupts the tight junctions between intestinal epithelial cells, leading to leakage of plasma into the intestinal lumen.
    • The cholera toxin does not primarily affect tight junctions. It acts through the adenylate cyclase pathway to induce fluid secretion, rather than causing structural changes to tight junctions.

Key Takeaway: The cholera toxin causes cholera by increasing intracellular cAMP levels through prolonged activation of adenylate cyclase, which leads to excessive secretion of electrolytes and water into the intestinal lumen, resulting in severe diarrhea.

TIPS AND TRICKS - Bacteria that act by Camp - CALP

C-Cholera toxin

A-Anthrax

L-heat Labile toxin of ETEC

P- Pertussis

Reference: World Health Organization (WHO) Guidelines on Cholera: WHO Cholera Guidelines

choices.text: Intravenous antibiotics and possible surgical intervention

questions.text: A 10-year-old patient presents with acute onset of eyelid swelling, redness, and pain around the eye, along with fever and limited eye movement. A CT scan reveals orbital swelling and possible involvement of the ethmoid sinus. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial management for this condition?
questions.solution:
Orbital cellulitis is an acute infection of the tissues surrounding the eye, including the eyelids, orbital fat, and muscles. It is a serious condition that requires prompt medical attention.

  • Etiology:
    • Typically caused by bacterial infections, most commonly by Staphylococcus aureus and Streptococcus species.
    • Can also be a complication of sinus infections, especially from the ethmoid or maxillary sinuses.
  • Symptoms:
    • Rapidly progressive swelling of the eyelids and surrounding tissues.
    • Redness and warmth in the affected area.
    • Painful eye movements and possible reduced vision.
    • Fever and systemic symptoms may also be present.
  • Diagnosis:
    • Clinical evaluation and history.
    • Imaging studies, such as CT scan or MRI, to assess the extent of infection and rule out other conditions.
    • Laboratory tests to identify the causative organism and determine antibiotic sensitivity.
  • Treatment:
    • Prompt administration of intravenous antibiotics to cover common pathogens.
    • Surgical intervention may be necessary to drain abscesses or remove any infected tissue if there is no improvement with antibiotics alone.
  • Complications:
    • Can lead to serious complications like vision loss, orbital abscess, or even meningitis if not treated promptly.

Options A and B are inadequate for the severity of this condition and do not address the potential need for surgical intervention.

Option D is inappropriate as orbital cellulitis requires immediate treatment to prevent serious complications.

Reference: Parson's Diseases of the Eye, 22nd Edition, Section IV, Chapter 19, The Orbit and Ocular Adnexa, p: 214.

choices.text: Most commonly seen in Bipolar 1 Mood Disorder
Cataplexy is one of the classical features seen in this condition
Benzodiazepines are the first line management for this condition
This condition has been discussed separately in DSM-5

questions.text: A case of 28 years old male brought to casualty with complaints of mutism, repeating same words after examiner's question and with abnormal posture. All complaints started since last 10 days. All of them are true regarding the clinical presentation except?
questions.solution:
Above clinical presentation is suggestive of Catatonia.

Catatonia- Catatonia is a clinical syndrome characterized by striking behavioral abnormalities that may include motoric immobility or excitement, profound negativism, or echolalia (mimicry of speech) or echopraxia (mimicry of movement).

DSM-5 criteria for catatonia

Criteria A: three or more of the following symptoms

  • Stupor, no psychomotor activity; not actively relating to environment
  • Catalepsy: passive induction of posture against gravity
  • Waxy Flexibility: slight, even resistance to positioning by examiner
  • Mutism: no or very little verbal response to instructions or external stimuli
  • Negativism: opposition or no response to instructions or external stimuli
  • Posturing: spontaneous and active maintenance of posturing against gravity
  • Mannerism: odd circumstantial caricature of normal actions
  • Stereotype: repetitive, abnormally frequent, non-goal directed movements
  • Agitation, not influenced by external stimuli
  • Grimacing
  • Echolalia: mimicking another’s speech
  • Echopraxia: mimicking another’s movement

Catatonia is condition mostly seen in advanced primary mood or psychotic illnesses. Among inpatients with catatonia, 25 to 50 percent are related to mood disorders (e.g., major depressive episode, recurrent, with catatonic features), and approximately 10 percent are associated with schizophrenia.

Management

  • Benzodiazepine
  • Electroconvulsive Therapy
  • Anti-Psychotic/ Anti-Depressants
  • Treat the causative factor.

KEY TAKEAWAYS- Catatonia- Catatonia is a clinical syndrome characterized by striking behavioral abnormalities that may include motoric immobility or excitement, profound negativism, or echolalia (mimicry of speech) or echopraxia (mimicry of movement)

Reference: Kaplan and Saddocks Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th Edition, Page No:746-748

choices.text: Referral to a specialist for biopsy

questions.text: A 32-year-old male patient presents with a single, painless ulcer on his genitalia that appeared about three weeks ago. The ulcer has a clean base and raised edges. He also reports swollen lymph nodes in the groin. The patient has no significant medical history and denies any recent sexual activity, although he admits to occasional unprotected sex. Based on the clinical presentation and the CDC guidelines, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Primary syphilis typically presents with:

  • A single, painless ulcer on genitalia
  • Clean base, raised edges
  • Swollen shotty lymph nodes
  • Spontaneously heals in 3-6 weeks.
  • Diagnosis- Dark-field microscopy, serological tests (RPR, VDRL, FTA-ABS)

A) Immediate initiation of oral azithromycin: Incorrect. While azithromycin is used in the treatment of syphilis, it is not the first-line treatment recommended by the CDC. Additionally, initiating treatment before confirming the diagnosis can lead to mismanagement and potentially complicate the diagnosis.

B) Serological testing for syphilis: Correct. The patient's presentation of a painless ulcer (chancre) and regional lymphadenopathy is suggestive of primary syphilis. According to CDC guidelines, the appropriate next step is to perform serological testing for syphilis to confirm the diagnosis. Testing includes non-treponemal tests (e.g., RPR or VDRL) followed by treponemal tests (e.g., FTA-ABS) for confirmation.

C) Immediate initiation of intravenous penicillin: Incorrect. Although intravenous penicillin is an effective treatment for syphilis, it is reserved for more advanced stages or neurosyphilis. Initial management should include confirmation of the diagnosis through appropriate serological tests.

D) Referral to a specialist for biopsy: Incorrect. A biopsy is not typically the first step in diagnosing syphilis. Diagnosis is usually made based on clinical presentation and serological tests rather than biopsy.

Key Takeaway: A hard chancre is a hallmark of primary syphilis, and early diagnosis and treatment are essential to prevent the disease's progression.

Serological testing for syphilis is essential to confirm the diagnosis before initiating treatment. The CDC guidelines recommend starting with diagnostic tests to confirm syphilis rather than starting treatment immediately.

Reference: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC). Syphilis Treatment Guidelines. CDC Syphilis Guidelines

choices.text: Thomas splint for applying skeletal traction
Bohler-Brown splint for applying skin traction
Bohler-Brown splint for applying skeletal traction
Cramer wire splint for splinting and transportation

questions.text: Identify the splint and choose correct option according to its indication:
questions.solution:
The image shown is of Bohler-Brown splint.

Bohler-Braun splint: It has a number of pulleys (1-3) over which the traction cord passes while giving skeletal traction for different fractures. It is more convenient than Thomas splint since it has no ring. The ring of a Thomas splint is a common cause of discomfort, especially in elderly people. A Bohler-Braun splint has no inbuilt system of countertraction, hence it is not suitable for transportation.

Fig: Bohler Braun Splint

Option A -: It is one of the commonest splints used in orthopaedic practice. It was devised by H.O. Thomas, initially for immobilisation for tuberculosis of the knee. It is now commonly used for the immobilisation and transportation of hip and thigh injuries.

Fig. Thomas splint

Option D - Cramer-wire splint: This splint is used for temporary splintage of fractures during transportation. It is made up of two thick parallel wires with interlacing wires. It can be bent into different shapes in order to immobilise different parts of the body.

Fig. Cramer splint

Reference: J. Maheshwari’s 5th Edition of Essential Orthopaedics page no. 26.

questions.text: Which of the following types of staphyloma commonly associated with high myopia?
questions.solution:
Types of staphyloma:

  1. Posterior Staphyloma
    • Location: Posterior pole of the eye
    • Associated Conditions: High myopia, degenerative conditions
    • Description: Localized protrusion at the back of the eye, often linked to high myopia and scleral thinning.
  2. Equatorial Staphyloma
    • Location: Equator of the eye
    • Associated Conditions: Myopia, scleral degeneration
    • Description: Outpouching around the equatorial region, characterized by scleral thinning and bulging.
  3. Anterior Staphyloma
    • Location: Anterior part of the eye
    • Associated Conditions: Corneal ectasia, thinning
    • Description: Protrusion at the front of the eye, associated with corneal thinning or ectasia.
  4. Intermediate Staphyloma
    • Location: Between anterior and posterior poles
    • Associated Conditions: Rare conditions
    • Description: A less common type occurring between the anterior and posterior poles, often with less specific characteristics.

Reference: Kanski's Clinical Ophthalmology, 9th Edition, Section 5, Chapter 18, pg: 467

questions.text: A woman gave birth to twins. The father who believed that they did not belong to him requested DNA testing. After testing, it was found that one child did not belong to him. This case would be best described as?
questions.solution:
• Superfecundation refers to the fertilization of two or more ova from different acts of sexual intercourse, in the same cycle, resulting in the conception of multiple embryos with different genetic fathers. In the given scenario, the woman gave birth to twins, but DNA testing revealed that one child did not belong to the father.
  • This indicates that two separate acts of sexual intercourse with different partners occurred, leading to the fertilization of two different ova by two different spermatozoa. As a result, the twins have different genetic fathers, confirming the occurrence of superfecundation.

Incorrect Options:

  • Option A - Superfetation: Superfetation refers to the occurrence of a second pregnancy during an ongoing pregnancy, where a woman conceives another fetus while already pregnant. This is not applicable in the given scenario as there is no indication of a second pregnancy occurring during an ongoing pregnancy.
  • Option C - Suppositious child: A suppositious child refers to a child who is falsely or fraudulently claimed or substituted as one's own. In the given scenario, there is no indication of false claims or substitution of the child, as the DNA testing revealed that one child did not belong to the father. Therefore, suppositious child is not the appropriate term for this case.
  • Option D - Atavism: Atavism refers to the reappearance of a characteristic or trait in an organism that is not present in its immediate ancestors but was present in previous generations. It is not applicable in the given scenario, as the issue at hand is related to the genetic paternity of the twins, rather than the reappearance of ancestral traits.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Superfecundation refers to the fertilization of two or more ova from different acts of sexual intercourse, in the same cycle, resulting in the conception of multiple embryos with different genetic fathers. In the given scenario, the woman gave birth to twins, but DNA testing revealed that one child did not belong to the father.

REFERENCE: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, 33rd edition, Page no: 396.

questions.text:
A patient met with RTA and developed knee pain with hemarthrosis. An MRI of the knee joint was done after 1 week which showed injury to posterior cruciate ligament and postero-lateral corner of the knee joint. Which clinical tests will be positive in this patient ?
1. DIAL test
2. Lachman test
3. Posterior drawer test
4. McMurray's test
questions.solution:
Dial Test

  • Purpose:
    • Diagnose posterolateral knee injury.
    • Differentiate between:
      • Isolated Posterolateral Corner (PLC) injury.
      • Combination of PLC and Posterior Cruciate Ligament (PCL) injury.
  • Tibial External Rotation (Dial) Test:
    • Procedure:
      • Assess external rotation of the tibia on the femur at both 30 and 90 degrees of knee flexion.
      • The test can be performed with the patient either supine or prone.
    • Findings:
      • Isolated PLC Injury:
        • More than a 10-degree increase in external rotation compared to the contralateral side at 30 degrees of knee flexion, but not at 90 degrees.
      • PLC and PCL Injury:
        • Pathologic external rotation at 30 degrees of knee flexion.
        • Increased external rotation when the knee is flexed to 90 degrees.
  • For Isolated PCL Tear:
    • The posterior drawer test or sag test are more relevant.

(Option A and C) In this case both PCL and PLC are injured, hence both posterior drawer and DIAL test will be positive.

(Option B) – Lachman’s test is most sensitive test for ACL injury.

(Option D) – McMurray’s test is user for clinical examination in meniscus injuries.

Reference: Campbell’s Operative Orthopaedics 14th edition page no. 2238.

questions.text: Identify the fingerprint pattern shown in the image:
questions.solution:
• An arch fingerprint pattern is the simplest and least common type.
  • It appears as a continuous wave-like pattern without any deltas or cores. In an arch pattern, the ridges enter from one side of the fingerprint and exit from the opposite side, forming a slight upward or downward curve.

Incorrect Options:

  • Option A- Whorl: A whorl fingerprint pattern consists of two deltas and a circular core, which is not seen in the given image.
  • Option B - Composite: Composite patterns are combinations of different types of fingerprints and are more complex, which is not applicable here.
  • Option C - Loop: Loop patterns have one delta and a core, with ridges looping around, which is also not seen in the given image.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Arch appears as a continuous wave-like pattern without any deltas or cores. In an arch pattern, the ridges enter from one side of the fingerprint and exit from the opposite side, forming a slight upward or downward curve.

REFERENCE: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, 33rd edition, Page no: 85.

questions.text: It is widely considered in orthopaedic practice that Ilizarov's ring fixator is the final resort to many failed as well as complex primary fractures. All of the following are indications of Illizarov's ring fixator except:
questions.solution:
(Option C) Pelvic external fixators are used for complex pelvic injuries and not Illizarov’s ring fixator.

Ilizarov Technique

Applications:

  1. Limb Lengthening: (Option D)
    • Useful for lengthening limbs, especially when shortening is accompanied by deformity.
    • The fixator assembly is designed to correct deformity and produce lengthening simultaneously.
    • Capable of massive limb lengthening (up to 18 inches).
    • Provides a stable biological environment for new bone formation at the lengthening site.
  2. Non-Union:
    • Effective for non-unions resistant to conventional treatments or those associated with deformity or shortening.
    • Can address non-unions requiring skin cover and bone grafting without staged surgeries.
  3. Deformity Correction:
    • Suitable for correcting both congenital and acquired deformities. (Option B)
  4. Osteomyelitis Treatment:
    • Allows for liberal excision of necrotic bone.
    • The resulting gap can be filled by transporting a segment of bone from either end.
  5. Arthrodesis: (Option A)
    • Achieved by “crushing” the articular surfaces together to stimulate union between opposing bones.

Reference: J. Maheshwari’s 5th Edition of Essential Orthopaedics page no. 34.

questions.text: Winking owl sign is seen in which condition?
questions.solution:
Bone to bone metastasis in vertebra presents as winking owl sign on Xray(1 pedicle is not visible).

Introduction to Spinal Tumors

  • Spine as a Site of Metastasis:
    • The spine frequently hosts metastases.
    • Certain tumors have a particular tendency to affect the spine, showing unique manifestations in the vertebrae.
  • Tumors of the Vertebral Body:
    • Histiocytosis X
    • Giant Cell Tumor
    • Chordoma
    • Osteosarcoma
    • Hemangioma
    • Metastatic Disease
    • Marrow Cell Tumors
  • Tumors of the Posterior Elements:
    • Aneurysmal Bone Cysts
    • Osteoblastoma
    • Osteoid Osteoma
  • Imaging Studies in Spinal Tumors
  • Radiographic Changes:
    • Most tumors are osteolytic and may not be visible on plain films until more than 30% of the vertebral body is destroyed.
    • Absence of a Pedicle: Identified as the “winking owl sign” on anteroposterior radiographs. (Options B)
    • Cortical Erosion or Expansion
    • Vertebral Collapse
  • Bone Scans:
    • Useful for detecting protracted back pain or night pain.
  • MRI:
    • Diagnostic Modality of Choice.
  • CT Scan:
    • Provides information on bony involvement and mechanical stability.
  • CT-Guided Needle Biopsy:
    • Often possible when the primary tumour is unknown.
    • May avoid the need for surgical open biopsy.

Option A - Characteristic x-ray sign in spondylolisthesis is ‘beheaded Scottish dog sign’.

Option C - Characteristic x-ray findings in osteoporosis are ‘biconcave / fish-mouth vertebrae’

Reference: Miler’s 8th Edition of Review of Orthopaedics, page no. 1745

questions.text: A 30-year-old patient presents with decreased vision and photophobia in both eyes, several months after undergoing surgical repair for a penetrating injury in the right eye. On examination, bilateral anterior uveitis with signs of vitritis and choroiditis are observed. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Sympathetic ophthalmia

  • bilateral, granulomatous uveitis that occurs after trauma or surgery to one eye, leading to inflammation in the uninjured, or "sympathetic," eye.
  • It is an autoimmune response where the immune system attacks the uveal tissue of the unaffected eye following trauma to the other eye.

Etiology: Typically occurs after ocular trauma (e.g., penetrating injury) or ocular surgery. The exact mechanism is unclear but is believed to involve a hypersensitivity reaction to uveal antigens that are released from the injured eye and then recognized as foreign by the immune system.

Clinical Features:

  • Onset: Can occur weeks to months after the initial trauma or surgery.
  • Symptoms in Affected Eye:
    • Decreased vision
    • Redness
    • Pain
    • Photophobia
    • Floaters
  • Signs:
    • Bilateral uveitis (both anterior and posterior segments may be involved)
    • Vitritis (inflammation of the vitreous body)
    • Choroiditis (inflammation of the choroid)
    • Retinal edema
    • Possible optic nerve involvement

Diagnosis:

  • Clinical Examination: Comprehensive eye examination showing bilateral uveitis with characteristic findings of sympathetic ophthalmia.
  • Imaging: OCT (Optical Coherence Tomography) and fundus photography may be used to assess retinal and choroidal involvement.
  • Exclusion of Other Causes: Important to rule out other causes of bilateral uveitis and intraocular inflammation.

Management:

  • Immediate Treatment: High-dose systemic corticosteroids are typically used to reduce inflammation and prevent further damage.
  • Additional Immunosuppressive Therapy: May be necessary for cases resistant to corticosteroids or to reduce the steroid dose.
  • Supportive Care: Includes managing symptoms and monitoring for complications.

Prognosis: With prompt and aggressive treatment, vision can often be preserved. However, if untreated, sympathetic ophthalmia can lead to significant visual impairment or blindness.


Complications: Include chronic uveitis, retinal detachment, and vision loss.

  • Option B) Sympathetic Ophthalmia: This condition is characterized by bilateral granulomatous uveitis occurring after trauma or surgery to one eye. The patient's history of ocular trauma followed by bilateral uveitis and vitritis aligns with this diagnosis.
  • Option A) Acute Anterior Uveitis: Typically unilateral and more associated with a specific etiology rather than a delayed onset after ocular trauma.
  • Option C) Herpes Simplex Keratitis: Generally presents with dendritic ulcers on the cornea and is not typically associated with bilateral uveitis after trauma.
  • Option D) Behçet's Disease: A systemic vasculitis that can cause bilateral uveitis, but is usually accompanied by other systemic symptoms such as oral and genital ulcers

Reference: Parson's Diseases of the Eye, 22nd Edition, Section VI, Chapter 15, pg: 349.

questions.text: What is the ratio of breaths to chest compressions when performing cardiopulmonary resuscitation alone in an adult?
questions.solution:
Whether there are one or two rescuers, the ratio of chest compressions to rescue breath for all persons is 30:2, i.e. 30 chest compressions for 2 breathing pauses, if no advanced airway is placed.


Reference: Adult Cardiac Arrest Algorithm, American Heart Association (AHA) 2020 guidelines

questions.text: Which of the following anaesthetic medications should not be used in chronic renal failure?
questions.solution:
• Pethidine (also known as meperidine) is an opioid analgesic commonly used for pain management.
  • In patients with chronic renal failure, pethidine should be avoided due to its active metabolite, normeperidine, which can accumulate and cause neurotoxicity.
  • Normeperidine can lead to central nervous system excitation, seizures, and other adverse effects, particularly in patients with impaired renal function.
  • Alternative opioids with shorter or no active metabolites, such as fentanyl or sufentanil, are preferred in patients with chronic renal failure.

Reference: Miller’s Anaesthesia, 9th edition, Page no. 727

questions.text: First carpal bone to ossify:
questions.solution:
Capitate is the first carpal bone and pisiform is the last carpal bone to ossify.

Age of ossification centres of carpal bones:


KEY TAKEAWAYS:Capitate is the first bone to ossify.

REFERENCE: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, 33rd edition, Page no: 78

questions.text: What anaesthetic gas is in the blue conduit in OT?
questions.solution:
Blue pipeline in OT delivers Nitrous Oxide

Reference: Equipment in Anaesthesia and Critical care, 2014 edition, Page no 6, 10.

questions.text: Identify the image shown in the image below?
questions.solution:
T1-weighted imaging (T1WI) is a fundamental type of MRI sequence that provides information about tissue properties.

  1. Appearance:
    • Fat: Appears bright (high signal intensity) because fat has a short T1 relaxation time.
    • Water and fluid (e.g., cerebrospinal fluid, cysts): Appears dark (low signal intensity) due to a longer T1 relaxation time.
    • Muscle, soft tissue, and gray matter: Intermediate signal intensity.
    • White matter: Slightly brighter than gray matter due to its fat content.
  2. Purpose:
    • Used for anatomical detail and structural imaging because it provides high contrast between different tissues.
    • Particularly useful for visualizing fat-containing tissues, detecting hemorrhage, and assessing the integrity of brain structures.
  3. Clinical Applications:
    • Brain MRI: Good for detecting anatomical abnormalities, brain structure, and some tumors (especially those with fat content).
    • Spine MRI: Helpful for assessing spinal anatomy and detecting changes in spinal cord structure.
    • Musculoskeletal MRI: Used to differentiate fat from other tissues and evaluate bone marrow, muscles, and tendons.
  4. Contrast Enhancement:
    • When gadolinium-based contrast agents are used, T1-weighted imaging is excellent for detecting areas of enhancement, which often correspond to regions of increased blood flow, inflammation, or breakdown of the blood-brain barrier (e.g., tumors, infections, active demyelinating lesions).

KEY TAKEAWAYS: T1-weighted MRI is a fundamental imaging technique, often used in conjunction with other MRI sequences, like T2-weighted or FLAIR, to give a comprehensive view of both normal anatomy and pathological changes.

Reference: MRI made easy, second edition, page no 14

questions.text: Black foot disease with peripheral neuropathy is seen in which metal poisoning?
questions.solution:
• Black foot disease, also known as Blackfoot or arsenicosis, is a condition associated with chronic arsenic poisoning.
  • It is a severe form of peripheral vascular disease in which blood vessels of the lower limb are severely damaged, eventually resulting in gangrene.
  • Prolonged exposure to high levels of arsenic, typically through contaminated drinking water or food, can lead to peripheral neuropathy and other health issues.

Incorrect Options:

  • Option B: Lead: Lead poisoning can lead to developmental delays, learning difficulties, behavior problems, and impaired growth. In adults, it can cause neurological symptoms, such as headaches, memory loss, and concentration problems, as well as abdominal pain and reproductive It is not associated with black foot disease.
  • Option C: Mercury: The symptoms and effects of mercury poisoning depend on the form of mercury involved:
    • Methylmercury, a form of organic mercury found in contaminated fish and seafood, primarily affects the nervous system and can cause developmental issues in children, as well as neurological and cardiovascularproblems in adults.
    • It is not associated with black foot disease.
  • Option D: Cadmium: Cadmium poisoning primarily affects the kidneys and can cause kidney damage, causes Itai Itai disease.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Black foot disease, also known as Blackfoot or arsenicosis, is a condition associated with chronic arsenic poisoning.

REFERENCE: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, 33rd edition, Page no: 538.

questions.text: Which of the following MRI sequences best depicts the edematous changes in the brain parenchyma?
questions.solution:
FLAIR (Fluid-Attenuated Inversion Recovery) is a specialized MRI sequence designed to suppress the signals from fluids, such as cerebrospinal fluid (CSF), making it particularly useful in brain imaging. It is a type of T2-weighted imaging with modifications that “null” or remove the bright signal from free fluid, making abnormal areas stand out more clearly.

Appearance:

  • CSF and free fluids: Appears dark (signal is suppressed).
  • Abnormal fluid or pathology (e.g., edema, inflammation) Appears bright, helping to identify lesions near or within fluid-filled spaces.
  • Gray and white matter: Intermediate signal intensities similar to T2-weighted images.
  • Lesions: Pathological tissues like tumors, infections, and demyelinating lesions typically appear bright against a darker background.

Purpose:

  • FLAIR is particularly useful for detecting lesions that are near or adjacent to CSF-filled areas, such as those in the brain parenchyma.
  • It is excellent for evaluating white matter diseases, such as multiple sclerosis (MS) or areas of edema, ischemia, or gliosis

Clinical Applications:

  • Brain MRI: FLAIR is commonly used to identify abnormalities that are hard to detect with conventional T2-weighted images because of interference from bright CSF. It is especially useful for:
  • Detecting subtle white matter lesions (e.g., in MS).
  • Identifying infarcts and stroke regions.
  • Evaluating brain tumors and the associated edema or infiltration
  • Detecting subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH) after the acute phase
  • Spinal Cord MRI: FLAIR can also be used to detect inflammatory or demyelinating lesions within the spinal cord, though its use is more limited in the spine.

Fig: FLAIR MRI sequence showing cerebral edema

KEY TAKEAWAYS: FLAIR (Fluid-Attenuated Inversion Recovery) is a specialized MRI sequence designed to suppress the signals from fluids, such as cerebrospinal fluid (CSF), making it particularly useful in brain imaging. It is a type of T2-weighted imaging with modifications that “null” or remove the bright signal from free fluid, making abnormal areas stand out more clearly.

Reference: MRI made easy, second edition, page no 44

questions.text: Which of the following is not a side effect of iodinated contrast medium?
questions.solution:
CT contrast agents (specifically iodinated contrast agents) are generally safe but can have side effects, which range from mild to severe. These side effects are typically related to the body’s response to the iodine in the contrast material.

Option D: Nephrogenic systemic fibrosis is a reaction seen with gadolinium contrast agents.

Reference: Christensen’s Physics of Diagnostic Radiology, fourth edition, page no 327

questions.text: Which of the following agent is used as contrast in CT scan?
questions.solution:
Iodinated contrast agents are commonly used in CT (Computed Tomography) scans to enhance the visibility of certain tissues and blood vessels. These contrast agents contain iodine, which is highly radiopaque, meaning it absorbs X-rays effectively. This makes structures with the contrast agent appear brighter on the CT images, improving differentiation between normal and abnormal tissues.

Types:

  • Non-ionic contrast (commonly used due to fewer side effects).
  • Ionic contrast (less commonly used, can have more side effects).

Option B,C and D are incorrect.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Iodinated contrast agents are commonly used in CT (Computed Tomography) scans to enhance the visibility of certain tissues and blood vessels.

Reference: Christensen’s Physics of Diagnostic Radiology, fourth edition, page no 323

questions.text: Which of the following features on ultrasound help in identifying the gall bladder calculi?
questions.solution:
Posterior acoustic shadowing (or simply acoustic shadowing) is an ultrasound artifact that occurs when sound waves encounter a structure that strongly attenuates or blocks the transmission of sound. This typically happens with dense structures such as bone, calcifications, or stones (e.g., gallstones or kidney stones).

Because the sound waves are either absorbed or reflected by these structures, very little or no sound energy reaches deeper tissues, resulting in a dark or hypoechoic shadow on the ultrasound image behind (posterior to) the attenuating structure.

This shadowing effect is useful in diagnostic imaging, as it can help identify and characterize solid, dense objects, such as stones, calcifications, or foreign bodies.

Option A: Posterior acoustic enhancement (also known as through transmission) is an ultrasound phenomenon that occurs when sound waves pass through a structure with low attenuation, such as fluid-filled areas (e.g., cysts, the urinary bladder, or gallbladder). As the sound waves travel through these structures, they lose very little energy.

On the ultrasound image, this results in an area of increased brightness or echogenicity immediately posterior (deeper) to the low-attenuating structure. This phenomenon helps differentiate fluid-filled structures from solid masses, as solid masses tend to attenuate sound waves more and would not exhibit posterior enhancement.

Option B: Reverberation is an ultrasound artifact that occurs when sound waves bounce back and forth between two strong reflectors, producing multiple equally spaced echoes on the image. This creates the appearance of repeated structures that are not actually present, often seen in fluid-filled areas like the bladder or cysts.

Option D: Ring Down artifact in radiology, particularly in ultrasound imaging, refers to a type of reverberation artifact caused by trapped gas bubbles. It produces a continuous, solid streak or band of echoes extending down from the source of the bubbles.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Posterior acoustic shadowing (or simply acoustic shadowing) is an ultrasound artifact that occurs when sound waves encounter a structure that strongly attenuates or blocks the transmission of sound. This typically happens with dense structures such as bone, calcifications, or stones (e.g., gallstones or kidney stones).

Reference: Diagnostic Ultrasound, sixth edition, page no 27

questions.text: Police brought a person from the railway track with features of dry dilated pupil, dry skin, slurring of speech, altered sensorium. The poisoning is?
questions.solution:
• Datura is a plant known for its anticholinergic properties. It can cause symptoms of anticholinergic toxicity, which include dry skin, dilated pupils (mydriasis), slurred speech, and altered sensorium. This is consistent with the clinical presentation described.

Incorrect Options:

  • Option A: Morphine: Morphine is an opioid and typically causes miosis (constricted pupils), not mydriasis. It can lead to respiratory depression and altered sensorium, but the dry skin and dilated pupils are not characteristic of morphine poisoning.
  • Option B: Cannabis: Cannabis can cause altered sensorium and slurred speech but is not associated with dry skin or dilated pupils. Cannabis effects are typically less severe and do not match the full clinical picture described.
  • Option D: Alcohol: Alcohol can cause altered sensorium and slurred speech, but it is not associated with dry skin or dilated pupils. Alcohol typically causes miosis and does not have the anticholinergic effects seen with Datura.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Datura poisoning causes anticholinergic symptoms, including dry skin, dilated pupils, slurred speech, and altered sensorium.

REFERENCE: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, 33rd edition, Page no: 598.

questions.text: All of the following changes occur in chronic starvation except?
questions.solution:
• Hyperthermia refers to elevated body temperature. In chronic starvation, the body's metabolic rate decreases, and thermoregulation mechanisms work to conserve heat rather than generate excess heat. Therefore, hyperthermia is not a characteristic change seen in chronic starvation.

Chronic Starvation causes the development of the following changes in the order mentioned below:

  • Loss of well-being, hunger, and hunger pains.
  • Mental and physical lethargy and easy fatigue.
  • Progressive loss of weight which is rapid in the first six months.
  • Polyuria
  • Increasing wasting, the body weight is reduced by about 40% of the normal.
  • Pigmentation and anemia.
  • Hypothermia and not Hyperthermia; peripheral vascular stasis in cold and hypotension.

Incorrect Options:

  • Option B: Exhaustion: Chronic starvation leads to the depletion of energy reserves in the body, resulting in fatigue, weakness, and exhaustion.
  • Option C: Heart atrophy: In chronic starvation, the body conserves energy by reducing its metabolic rate. This can result in muscle wasting, including the heart muscle, leading to heart atrophy.
  • Option D: Hypotension: Hypotension refers to low blood pressure. In chronic starvation, the body tries to conserve fluids and maintain blood volume, which can result in decreased blood pressure.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: In chronic starvation, the body's metabolic rate decreases, and thermoregulation mechanisms work to conserve heat rather than generate excess heat. Therefore, hyperthermia is not a characteristic change seen in chronic starvation.

REFERENCE: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, 33rd edition, Page no: 335, 336.

questions.text: 45-year-old male brought to casualty after he met with a Road Traffic Accident followed by Minor bruises over temporal region and maxillary bone. On detailed evaluation, you found that he was driving in intoxicated state with last intake 12 hours back. In the ER, he gets fits(seizure) for first time. He was restless and had perspiration all over his body. NCCT suggestive of no significant abnormality. What can be the reason for seizure in this patient?
questions.solution:
45-year-old maleà met with an accident, under intoxicated state with Last intake of Alcohol being 12 hours back à Bruises over Temporal region and Maxillary region with NCCT is suggestive of no significant Abnormality àRuling out Head Injury.

Alcohol intoxication manifest as slurring of speech, motor in coordination, judgement impairment, nystagmus, coma and death and not present with seizures.

Alcohol Withdrawal Seizure- history suggestive of Alcohol intake and RTA under intoxication without significant head injury & last intake being 12 hours back à Alcohol withdrawal usually starts after 6 hoursàmore the withdrawal duration, more the complicated withdrawalà withdrawal seizures.

Hierarchical presentation of Alcohol withdrawal.

KEY TAKEAWAYS-Delirium Tremens (agitation, clouding of consciousness, disorientation, delusions, hallucinations, etc.), manifests within the first 24 to 48 hours but can be manifested even after 72 hours to 1 week of Alcohol cessation. Resolve on its own in 10 days

Reference: Kaplan and Saddoxks Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th Edition.

questions.text:
A 30-year-old drowsy male was brought to the casualty. His pulse was 130/min, respiratory rate 30/min. His lab reports are given below. He showed improvement on nasogastric aspiration and administration of sodium bicarbonate, calcium gluconate, and 4-methyl pyrazole. What substance did he most likely consume?
ABG - Metabolic acidosis
1. Total serum calcium - 6.8 mg/dL
2. Blood Urea - 100 mg/dL
3. Creatinine - 3.4 mg/dL
4. Urine analysis - Calcium oxalate crystals
questions.solution:
Ethylene glycol is converted to glyoxyaldehyde by alcohol dehydrogenase. Glyoxyaldehyde causes kidney damage.

Methanol is converted to formaldehyde by alcohol dehydrogenase. Formaldehyde causes retinal damage like blurring of vision/loss of vision.

The principles of treatment for both these conditions are the same. It predominantly involves using fomepizole or ethanol to inhibit the metabolic conversion of these relatively non-toxic alcohols to their toxic metabolites.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Ethylene glycol is converted to glyoxyaldehyde by alcohol dehydrogenase. Glyoxyaldehyde causes kidney damage.

REFERENCE: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, 33rd edition, Page no: 583.

questions.text: Inhaling the cloth soaked in drug is:
questions.solution:
• Huffing refers to the act of inhaling volatile substances or drugs by saturating a cloth or other material and then inhaling the fumes.
  • Huffing is a form of inhalant abuse, and it can have harmful effects on the body, including intoxication and potential damage to the respiratory system.

Incorrect Options:

  • Option A - Bagging: Bagging refers to a method of inhaling substances by placing them inside a bag and then inhaling or breathing in the vapors. The bag is typically held over the nose and mouth, allowing the person to inhale the substance contained within the bag.
  • Option B - Spraying: Spraying typically involves the dispersal of liquid substances in a fine mist or spray form.
  • Option D - Sniffing: Sniffing refers to the act of inhaling substances directly through the nose.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Huffing refers to the act of inhaling volatile substances or drugs by saturating a cloth or other material and then inhaling the fumes

REFERENCE: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, 33rd edition, Page no: 608

questions.text: A 34 year male patient presented with silvery white scaling over elbow and knees. There was history of winter aggravation in skin lesions. All of the following nail changes can be seen in this patient, except:
questions.solution:
Mees' Lines are a change that occurs in the colour of the nail with no palpable ridges, typically described as white bands traversing the nail bed, running parallel to the lunula across the entire nail bed of the individual. This finding is indicative of arsenic, thallium or other heavy metal poisonings.

Aldrich mees line (transverse white bands)

Clinical signs of nail bed involvement

  • Oil-drop sign and salmon patch (Pathognomic of nail psoriasis) - Choice D
  • Onycholysis - typically with a pink zone proximally
  • Subungual hyperkeratosis - Choice A
  • Splinter haemorrhages under the distal third of the nail plate

Clinical signs of nail matrix involvement

  • Coarse Pitting (Most Common manifestation) - Choice B
  • Leukonychia
  • Red spots in lunule
  • Onychorrhexis (longitudinal nail ridge, split, or fissure)
  • Beau lines (transverse lines and ridges)
  • Nail crumbling

Nail Psoriasis Severity Index (NAPSI) is a scoring tool for nail psoriasis.

Source: Nail Psoriasis

Reference: Rook’s textbook of dermatology, 9 th edition, Pg no 35.14

questions.text: A 35 year old male patient has a known case of leprosy with multiple, bilaterally symmetrical Plaques and nodules over face, ears, trunk. Glove & stocking anesthesia is present. Which of the following is not treatment of lepra reaction seen in this given type of leprosy?
questions.solution:
Based on given clinical presentation, diagnosis is lepromatous leprosy with Type 2 Lepra reaction.

  • Cessation of anti leprosy treatment is not the treament of type 2 lepra reaction. Antileprosy treatment should be continued.

Thalidomide is of no value in Type I reaction It is used in management of type II reaction

It is teratogenic hence contraindicated in women

Option A- Clofazimine

For Severe ENL (neuritis/ arthritis/ uveitis/ orchitis) Clofazimine is used.

Option B- Thalidomide

Thalidomide is of no value in Type I reaction. It is used in management of type II reaction. It is teratogenic hence contraindicated in women.

For Severe ENL (neuritis/ arthritis/ uveitis/orchitis) Corticosteroid is used.

questions.text: What does the observation of contracted hands with no primary relaxation during a post-mortem examination indicate?
questions.solution:
• Cadaveric spasm, or cataleptic rigidity, occurs when the muscles that are contracted during life become stiff and rigid immediately after death, without passing into the stage of primary relaxation.
  • The spasm originates by normal nervous stimulation of the muscles and hence, is usually limited to a single group of involuntary muscles and frequently involves the hands.
  • It is caused due to ATP depletion.

Incorrect Options:

  • Option A: Rigor Mortis: Rigor Mortis, also called death stiffening or cadaveric rigidity, is a state of stiffening of muscles, sometimes with slight shortening of the fibers. There is individual cell death that occurs when rigor mortis sets in. It affects all muscles in the body including voluntary and non-voluntary, contracted or uncontracted, unlike cadaveric spasms.
  • Option B: Livor Mortis: Livor Mortis, or post-mortem hypostasis, is the purplish discoloration of skin in the dependent parts of the body caused by the collection of blood in those parts due to gravitational pull. The purplish color is due to the deoxyhemoglobin.
  • Option D: Algor Mortis: Algor Mortis is the cooling of the body post death. The body does not follow Newton's law when losing temperature. The fall in temperature is because of the cessation of heat production by the somatic cells of the body.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Postmortem changes include immediate changes (somatic death), early changes (cellular death), and late changes (putrefaction and skeletonization).

REFERENCE: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, 33rd edition, Page no: 163

questions.text: Which of the histopathological finding is not seen in lichen planus?
questions.solution:
Histopathological findings of Lichen planus:

  • Mild hyperkeratosis
  • Irregular acanthosis
  • Focal wedge shaped hypergranulosis (Responsible for Wickham’s striae) - Choice D
  • Basal cell degeneration. Sometimes lead to clefts in dermoepidermal junction called Max joseph spaces
  • Saw tooth rete ridges
  • Colloid bodies/ civatte/apoptotic bodies in lower epidermis and upper dermis - Choice C
  • Dense band like mononuclear infiltration at dermoepidermal junction
  • Interface dermatitis - Choice B
  • Pigment incontinence, presence of melanophages

Camel foot rete ridges- As a result, to accommodate the increasing population of basal cells, rete pegs take a plunge in the dermis in the form of regular elongation of rete ridges, giving the "camel foot" appearance to dermal rete ridges

Seen in Psoriasis vulgaris. (Choice A)

Histology of psoriasis

KEY TAKEAWAYS – histology differences between psoriasis and lichen plains

Source: Lichen planus

Reference: Fundamentals of pathology of skin, 4th edition, Pg no 74

questions.text: Koebner's phenomenon is seen in all except
questions.solution:
Koebner or isomorphic phenomenon is the develop[ment of new lesion along the line of trauma in a previously normal skin. This new lesion have ‘iso’ (same) and ‘morphic’ (morphology) as the existing lesions.

questions.text: The method of autopsy carried out en-masse to remove organs from tongue to prostate is:
questions.solution:
• Letulle technique is named after Maurice Letulle, which involves the removal of organs together in one mass from tongue to prostate.
    • This method of autopsy is thus also called "en masse."
    • The anatomy of the organs and organ systems can be preserved in the greatest possible way due to this.
    • Forensic pathologists can get a better overall picture due to the preservation of anatomical linkages.

Incorrect Options:

  • Option A: Virchow technique: This approach is named after Rudolf Virchow. Instead of removing all organs at once, this method involves the sequential removal and examination of individual organs. The Virchow technique does not fit the description in the question because it does not involve the "en masse" removal of organs.
  • Option B: Rokitansky technique: In situ dissection(inside the body itself) is done in the Rokitansky technique.
  • Option C: Ghon's technique: Anatomical relationships are maintained by using the Ghon's approach, often known as "en bloc." Instead of one enormous block, the thoracic, abdominal, and pelvic organs are removed using this procedure in three separate blocks. The dissection is made much more manageable by dividing the huge block into these three portions while still keeping the anatomy between the organs.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Letulle technique is named after Maurice Letulle, which involves the removal of organs together in one mass from tongue to prostate.

REFERENCE: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, 33rd edition, Page no: 121
